entries: You briefly stop the flow of time for everyone but yourself. No time passes for other creatures, while you take {@dice 1d4 + 1} turns in a row, during which you can use actions and move as normal.

This spell ends if one of the actions you use during this period, or any effects that you create during this period, affects a creature other than you or an object being worn or carried by someone other than you. In addition, the spell ends if you move to a place more than 1,000 feet from the location where you cast it.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, the spell's effects last for up to 1 week, during which you and each participant in the ritual can act normally and interact with other creatures and objects , which are otherwise frozen in time.
In addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires two living androsphinxes and two living gynosphinxes, both of which the spell consumes.

spell.name: Amerac's Hourglass (reckoning)

m.text: a marble hourglass filled with gold dust worth at least 5,000 gp

entries: You call forth the sands of time to restore the former glory of the ancient past. Choose a 500-foot cube centered on a point you can see within range. All objects within the area are rebuilt to their original state. Any displaced parts within range are moved into their original resting place, and the golden sand replaces those that have been removed or destroyed. The sand takes on the  form and properties of the original material.
Any creature or object in a space that a rebuilt object would occupy is safely moved to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the object.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, it also targets the corpses and skeletons of creatures in the area. Each creatures' remains are restored and reconstructed, as if they immediately died a natural death, even if the creature died of unnatural causes or parts of their body are missing. If you cast this spell with a reckoning value of 350, the spell restores corpses you choose to life as described in the {@spell revivify} spell.
In addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires diamonds worth at least 300 gp for each creature resurrected (if any), which the spell consumes.

spell.name: Animate Armor (reckoning)

m.text: a nonmagical suit of plate armor worth at least 1,500 gp

entries: You imbue a nonmagical suit of plate armor with magic, turning it into an {@creature animated armor|MM} for the duration. Once the spell ends, or if the armor is reduced to 0 hit points, it reverts back to a nonmagical suit of plate armor.

The armor is under your control, and understands and obeys your spoken commands. Roll initiative for the armor, which has its own turns. It obeys any verbal commands that you issue to it (no action required by you). If you don't issue any commands to the armor, it defends itself from hostile creatures but otherwise takes no actions.
The DM has the armor's statistics.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, the spell's range increases to 1 mile, its duration increases to Instantaneous and longer requires {@status concentration}, and it targets any number of suits of armor, even if those suits are occupied.

You can exclude any number of suits of armor, or creatures you name that may or may not be wearing armor, from the effects of this spell. An unoccupied suit of armor becomes an animated armor, while an occupied suit of armor becomes a helmed horror under your control and seals the wearer inside. You choose the three spells that each helmed horror is immune to. A creature inside a helmed horror is immune to all damage until the armor is destroyed, has total cover from effects originating from outside the armor, is {@condition blinded} and {@condition incapacitated}, requires no food, drink, or sleep, cannot speak, and does not age.
In addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires 8 ounces of {@item sovereign glue}, which the spell consumes.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: If you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the duration is {@status concentration}, up to 10 minutes. If you use a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the duration is 8 hours. If you use a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the duration is 24 hours. If you use a 9th level spell slot, the spell lasts until the armor is reduced to 0 hit points. Using a spell slot of 5th level or higher grants a duration that doesn't require {@status concentration}.

spell.name: Animate Claw (reckoning)

m.text: a silver ring worth at least 25 gp

entries: Choose a severed hand within range. The hand must be from a murderer, and must have been severed no more than 24 hours ago. The target is animated into a {@creature crawling claw|MM} (the DM has the creature's game statistics).

On each of your turns, you can use a bonus action to mentally command the claw if it is within 60 feet of you. You decide what action the claw will take and where it will move during its next turn, or you can issue a general command, such as to guard a particular chamber or corridor. If you issue no commands, the claw only defends itself against hostile creatures. Once given an order, the claw continues to follow it until its task is complete.
The claw is under your control until you cast this spell again, after which it stops obeying any command you've given it.

spell.name: Avalanche (reckoning)
entries: Massive chunks of ice, rock, and snow tumble to the ground from the top of a 50-foot-radius, 100-foot-high cylinder centered on a point within range. Each creature in the area must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes {@damage 6d6} cold damage and {@damage 6d6} bludgeoning damage, is knocked {@condition prone}, and is buried in the rubble, requiring a DC 18 Strength (Athletics) check to escape.

The DM can adjust the DC higher or lower, depending on the nature of the rubble within the avalanche and the temperature outside it. Any ground within the cylinder becomes difficult terrain after the spell ends.
Any structure caught within the area takes 50 points of bludgeoning damage, and if destroyed, is reduced to rubble and tumbles down the cylinder with the snow and ice.
If you cast this spell and orient the height of the cylinder to be parallel to an existing hillside, mountain, or other natural slope, the spell's bludgeoning damage increases by {@dice 3d6}.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, you must align its area to an existing hillside, mountain, or other natural slope, and target its highest point. The spell's range increases to Sight, and the height and radius of the cylinder increase to match the largest dimensions of the slope, and its duration increases to Concentration, up to 1 hour.

Each creature and structure in the area is affected by the spell at the start of each of your turns until the spell ends, and the slope is stripped of all loose materials, such as snow, soil, and boulders.
In addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires a {@item horn of blasting|dmg}, which the spell consumes.

m.text: a horn made of red pine inlaid with brass worth at least 5 gp

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 8th level or higher, the cold and bludgeoning damage both increase by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 7th.

spell.name: Black Hole (reckoning)
entries: You condense gravity into an immeasurably dense orb at a point you can see within the spell's range. The orb fills a 10-foot radius sphere around it with darkness, which no light, magical or mundane, can illuminate.

When a creature enters within 30 feet of the orb for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it must make a Strength saving throw or be pulled 10 feet toward the orb. When a creature enters within 5 feet of the orb for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it must make a Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 10d10} bludgeoning damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one.

The orb's gravitation makes moving away from it incredibly difficult. While within 10 feet of the orb, a creature moving away from the orb must spend 4 feet of movement for every 1 foot it moves. While within 30 feet of the orb, a creature moving away from the orb must spend 2 feet of movement for every 1 foot it moves.
In addition, unsecured objects that are completely within the area of effect are automatically pulled into orb. Small nonmagical objects that come within 5 feet of the orb are immediately destroyed.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, its range increases to 10 miles, the sphere's radius increases to 100 feet, its duration increases to {@status Concentration}, up to 10 minutes, and the area that draws targets into the sphere increases to 1 mile. The sphere affects objects, structures, and natural landmarks as well as creatures, and it instantly obliterates all matter it touches it rather than dealing damage.

In addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires a talisman of the sphere and an onyx medallion in the shape of a star worth at least 5,000 gp, both of which the spell consumes.

spell.name: Dark Star (reckoning)

m.text: a shard of onyx and a drop of the caster's blood, both of which the spell consumes

entries: This spell creates a sphere centered on a point you choose within range. The sphere can have a radius of up to 40 feet. The area within this sphere is filled with magical darkness and crushing gravitational force.

For the duration, the spell's area is {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. A creature with darkvision can't see through the magical darkness, and nonmagical light can't illuminate it. No sound can be created within or pass through the area. Any creature or object entirely inside the sphere is immune to thunder damage, and creatures are {@condition deafened} while entirely inside it. Casting a spell that includes a verbal component is impossible there.

Any creature that enters the spell's area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must make a Constitution saving throw. The creature takes {@damage 8d10} force damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature reduced to 0 hit points by this damage is disintegrated. A disintegrated creature and everything it is wearing and carrying, except magic items, are reduced to a pile of fine gray dust.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, its range increases to 10 miles, the sphere's radius increases to 100 feet, its duration increases to {@status Concentration}, up to 10 minutes, and the area that draws targets into the sphere increases to 1 mile. The sphere affects objects, structures, and natural landmarks as well as creatures, and it instantly obliterates all matter it touches it rather than dealing damage.",

In addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires a talisman of the sphere and an onyx medallion in the shape of a star worth at least 5,000 gp, both of which the spell consumes.

spell.name: Drown (reckoning)
entries: You choose a creature you can see within range, which can be extended through hydromancy, and conjure a liquid within its lungs. Roll {@dice 12d8}; if the target has hit points equal to or fewer than the total, it begins suffocating and becomes unable to breathe or speak for the duration. If the target has hit points greater than the total, the spell is still cast but doesn't take effect until the target's hit points drop below the total. Creatures that don't have lungs, don't need to breathe, or can breathe water are unaffected by this spell. As an action, the creature can make a Constitution saving throw. On a success, the spell ends.
Until the spell ends, you can use a bonus action on your turn to cause liquid to swell inside the target's lungs and cause it take {@damage 2d6} bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, its range increases to Sight, it targets all creatures of your choice in a 1-mile-radius within range, and its duration increases to 1 week. The air within the spell's area becomes humid, cool, and clammy, and mist fills that air, lightly obscuring the area. When you cast the spell, and again every 8 hours until the spell ends, roll the dice for each creature in the area.

Each creature with hit points equal to or fewer than the total suffers 1 level of {@condition exhaustion}; after suffering 3 levels of {@condition exhaustion} it loses the ability to speak and is instead racked with a bitter wet cough until the {@condition exhaustion} is removed.
In addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires a {@item decanter of endless water} and a {@item bag of holding}, both of which the spell consumes.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, roll an additional {@dice 2d8} for each slot level above 4th.

spell.name: Golden Glow (reckoning)

m.text: a golden orb worth at least 100gp, which the spell consumes

entries: You point at a spot within 30 ft. of you that you can see, a bright orb of sunlight takes form there. This orb emits bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet, the orb will hover 15 ft. above the ground unless you're pointing at a wall or ceiling.

When a creature enters the bright light for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it must make a Constitution saving throw. It takes {@damage 6d8} radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
An undead makes its saving throw with disadvantage, and the spell deals maximum damage to it.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, its duration increases to {@status Concentration}, up to 8 hours, its range increases to 5 miles and the area it targets changes to a 1-mile-radius, 1-mile-high cylinder that must appear at least half a mile above the surface of the ground or water beneath it, where the orb of light appears. The spell's area inflicts extreme heat and is filled with bright light, which is natural sunlight. Creatures within the area are vulnerable to radiant and fire damage.
In addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires two sun blades, which the spell consumes.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the spell deals an additional {@damage 1d8} damage for each slot level above 5th.

spell.name: Ice Rink (reckoning)
entries: You coat a solid surface in a 20-foot-radius circle centered on a point within range with slippery, mirror-smooth ice.

If you froze a lateral surface, such as a floor, any creature that moves onto or within the surface must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the target loses its footing and slides to the far end of the area in the direction it moved. It continues to slide until it reaches the opposite side of the area or collides with another creature or object within it (even if it runs out of movement).

If you froze a vertical surface, such as a wall or a cliffside, any creature that enters the frozen area or starts its turn there must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, it slides to the bottom of the area, though it catches itself once it reaches an unfrozen surface (if any).
In either case, an affected creature expends 1 foot of movement for every foot it slides along the frozen surface. Sliding across the ice doesn't trigger opportunity attacks.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells} targeting land, the spell's range becomes 1 mile, the radius increases to 500 feet, and its duration becomes Instantaneous. If you target the surface of water, the spell's area changes to a 500-foot-radius, 100-foot-high cylinder which originates from the surface of the water. Creatures, objects, and structures entirely within the area are instantly frozen. A frozen target is {@condition unconscious}, has total cover against attacks and other effects that originate from outside its space, does not require air, food, drink, or sleep, and does not age. The ice thaws through normal means, and its surface has all the properties of ice created by this spell when it is cast normally.
In addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires a {@item frost brand} and a scroll of {@spell cone of cold}, both of which the spell consumes.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the spell's radius increases by 10 feet for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Instant Iceberg (reckoning)
entries: You cause water to freeze within a 20-foot cube within range, forming an iceberg. Each creature in the area can make a Dexterity saving throw. On a success, it can use its reaction to move up to its speed so that it is no longer in the area. Otherwise, a target becomes trapped within the transparent ice. A creature in the iceberg is {@condition restrained} and has total cover against attacks and other effects that originate from outside of its own space.

The iceberg is a Gargantuan object with AC 12 and 100 hit points, and it is vulnerable to fire damage. It floats on the surface of water, and rises at a rate of 60 feet per round at the start of each of your turns if it is submerged in water. If the iceberg is reduced to 0 hit points, it shatters, freeing any creatures trapped within it.
When a creature moves more than 5 feet for the first time on a turn while standing on top of the iceberg, it must succeed on a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells} targeting land, the spell's range becomes 1 mile, the radius increases to 500 feet, and its duration becomes Instantaneous. If you target the surface of water, the spell's area changes to a 500-foot-radius, 100-foot-high cylinder which originates from the surface of the water. Creatures, objects, and structures entirely within the area are instantly frozen. A frozen target is {@condition unconscious}, has total cover against attacks and other effects that originate from outside its space, does not require air, food, drink, or sleep, and does not age. The ice thaws through normal means, and its surface has all the properties of ice created by this spell when it is cast normally.
In addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires a {@item frost brand} and a scroll of {@spell cone of cold}, both of which the spell consumes.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast the spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, ice's maximum hit points increase by 20 and the size of the cube you can target increases by 10 feet for each slot level above 5th.

spell.name: Slippery Ice (reckoning)
entries: You create a layer of slick ice, 6 inches thick, in a 30-foot radius circle centered on a point on the ground or on the surface of water that you can see within range, which lasts for the duration. The ice suppresses any underlying terrain that doesn't protrude past the surface of the ice.

A creature moving across the ice spends 1 foot of movement for every 2 feet it moves, and must succeed a Dexterity saving throw when it moves more than 5 feet across the ice for the first time on a turn or be knocked {@condition prone}. When a creature attempts to get up from {@condition prone} while on the ice, it must succeed on a Dexterity check against your spell save DC. On a failure, it falls {@condition prone} again. When you cast this spell, you can designate any number of creatures you can see to automatically succeed on ability checks and saving throws made against this spell.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells} targeting land, the spell's range becomes 1 mile, the radius increases to 500 feet, and its duration becomes Instantaneous. If you target the surface of water, the spell's area changes to a 500-foot-radius, 100-foot-high cylinder which originates from the surface of the water. Creatures, objects, and structures entirely within the area are instantly frozen. A frozen target is {@condition unconscious}, has total cover against attacks and other effects that originate from outside its space, does not require air, food, drink, or sleep, and does not age. The ice thaws through normal means, and its surface has all the properties of ice created by this spell when it is cast normally.
In addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires a {@item frost brand} and a scroll of {@spell cone of cold}, both of which the spell consumes.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the radius of the ice increases by 10 feet for each slot level above 4th.

spell.name: Moonfall (reckoning)
entries: You materialize a minor moon from its place in the stars to use as an instrument of doom. A large stone moon of 100-foot radius appears 1500 feet above a point you can see within range. The spell fails if you can't see a point in the air where the moon could appear, or if you do not have a clear view of the sky.

The moon falls 500 feet at the start of each of your turns. Each creature in the moon's path as it falls must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 6d6} bludgeoning damage and is {@condition grappled} until the end of its next turn, pinned by the moon. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage and is pushed out of the moon's path, up to 100 feet away from the moon.

Once the moon collides with the ground, each creature within 100 feet of the point of collision takes {@damage 12d12} bludgeoning damage. The spell deals maximum damage to structures. The moon then break into pieces, leaving a 100-foot radius impact crater, which becomes difficult terrain until cleared, with each 5-foot-diameter portion requiring at least 1 minute to clear by hand.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, its school changes to transmutation, and its range becomes Unlimited. Rather than conjure a stone moon, the spell takes hold of a natural satellite made of solid matter that you can see and draws it toward a point you choose on the same plane of existence. The satellite reaches the chosen point 3 days later (adjusting its course to account for planar and planetary movements) and strikes the point.

The impact instantly destroys everything in a radius around that point equal to its own radius times 25. While it is en route, and for 1,000 years afterward, any location on that plane within 500 feet of a body of water that is at least 1 mile across is subjected to the {@spell flood|AbiDalzims} spell once every 24 hours.

In addition to its normal components, casting this spell requires the egg of an {@creature adult amethyst dragon|FTD|amethyst dragon} and a horrific carved mask worth at least 1,500 gp, both of which the spell consumes.

spell.name: Muffle (reckoning)
entries: A cloud of pillowy snowflakes fall in the air around you, muffling sounds within the spell's area. For the duration, all creatures within range have resistance to thunder and falling damage, and the audible distance of sound made within the area is halved.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, its range becomes Sight, its radius becomes 1 mile, and its duration becomes 1 week. After casting the spell, snow falls for 8 hours at a rate of 1 foot per hour. Creatures, objects, and structures within the area react normally, including collapsing under the weight of the snow. The snow melts at a normal rate through normal means.

Until the spell ends, all creatures within the spell's area are immune to thunder damage, and cannot hear sounds that originate more than 15 feet away from them. Any creature that falls on the snow takes no damage, and creatures within the area suffer from extreme cold.
In addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires the heart of an {@creature abominable yeti}, which the spell consumes.

spell.name: Night Sky (reckoning)
entries: With a wave of your hand, you force the sky above you to clear and become night, in a radius of 1 mile. Within the spell's area, spells that can be cast only at night (such as create undead) can be cast regardless of time of day.
When you cast this spell, choose one of the following effects. On each of your turns until the spell ends, you can use your action to choose an effect, selecting the same effect or a different one.

entries.name: Dreamland
entries: The terrain within the spell's area shapes to your desires. The tactile characteristics of the terrain are unchanged, so creatures entering the area are likely to see through the illusion. If the difference isn't obvious by touch, a creature carefully examining the illusion can attempt an Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC to disbelieve it. A creature who discerns the illusion for what it is, sees it as a vague image superimposed on the terrain. You can end this effect as an action on your turn.

entries.name: Grim
entries: You imbue false life into a corpse you can see within the spell's area. It rises as a {@creature skeleton} if you choose a pile of bones, or a {@creature zombie} if you choose a fleshy corpse. On each of your turns, you can use an action to mentally command any creature you made with this spell if the creature is within the spell's area (if you control multiple creatures, you can command any or all of them at the same time, issuing the same command to each one). You decide what action the creature will take and where it will move during its next turn, or you can issue a general command, such as to guard a particular chamber or corridor. If you issue no commands, the creature only defends itself against hostile creatures. Once given an order, the creature continues to follow it until its task is complete. The creature reverts to a corpse or pile of bones when the spell ends.

entries.name: Shooting Star
entries: A star streaks across the sky. One creature of your choice who can see the star gains 25 temporary hit points. While the creature has these hit points, it immune to {@condition frightened|PHB|fear}.

entries.name: Slumber
entries: You inflict drowsiness on a creature of your choice within the spell's area. If the target has less than 50 hit points, it falls {@condition unconscious} until the spell ends, it takes damage, or someone uses an action to shake or slap it awake.

entries.name: Star Storm
entries: Ten stars fall from the sky. Each star hits a creature of your choice within the spell's area. Each star deals {@damage 1d4 + 1} force damage to its target (roll damage for each star separately). The stars all strike simultaneously, and you can direct them to hit one creature or several. Each time you use this effect, the sky grows darker. After the 10th use, the sky above becomes entirely dark, and you can no longer use this effect.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, its duration increases to 24 hours. Choose one of the spell's effects. All the spell's participants, rather than just you, can use the chosen action.
n addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires a sphere of polished moonstone or a moon rock worth at least 50,000 gp, either of which the spell consumes.

spell.name: Rust Metal (reckoning)
entries: You touch a nonmagical ferrous metal object you can see within range. If the object isn't being worn or carried, the touch destroys a 1-foot cube of it. If the object is being worn or carried by a creature, the creature can make a Dexterity saving throw to avoid the spell.

If the object touched is either metal armor or a metal shield being worn or carried, its takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to the AC it offers. Armor reduced to an AC of 10 or a shield that drops to a +0 bonus is destroyed. If the object touched is a metal weapon, it takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to damage rolls. If its penalty drops to −5, the weapon is destroyed.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, its range increases to 1 mile, it targets a 300-foot cube, and it ignores all cover. All metal objects within the area are instantly destroyed, and creatures made of metal inside the area take 500 force damage.
In addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires 300 {@creature rust monster} eggs, which the spell consumes.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the spell can destroy an additional contiguous 1-foot cube of material, and the penalty applied to metal armor, shields, and weapons increases by 1 for every two slot levels above 2nd.

spell.name: Starlight Spear (reckoning)
entries: You weave threads of starlight together to create a spear of solidified light in your hand. This magic spear lasts until the spell ends. It counts as a simple melee weapon with which you are proficient. It deals {@damage 2d12} radiant damage on a hit and has the reach and thrown (20/60 ft.) properties. In addition, if you move at least 20 feet straight toward a target, your next attack with this weapon deals an additional {@damage 1d12} radiant damage on a hit.
If you drop the weapon or throw it, it dissipates at the end of the turn. Thereafter, while the spell persists, you can use a bonus action to cause the spear to reappear in your hand.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, its duration increases to {@status Concentration}, up to 24 hours, and its range increases to Self (1,000-foot radius). Each creature of your choice within the area gains a spear of solidified light identical to the one you gain.

In addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires a {@item spear|dmg} made of gold or adamantine worth at least 3,500 gp and a diamond prism worth at least 500 gp, both of which the spell consumes.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a 3rd- or 4th-level spell slot, the damage increases to {@damage 3d12}. When you cast it using a 5th- or 6th-level spell slot, the damage increases to {@damage 4d12}. When you cast it using a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the damage increases to {@damage 5d12}.

spell.name: Projectile Vomit
entries: You induce violent spasms in your gut to expel foulness from your body and launch it at a creature you can see within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 3d6} acid damage and is {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn. Hit or miss, the globule of digestive fluids splashes in all directions. The target and each creature within 15 feet of it must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 2d8} acid damage.
If you are {@condition poisoned} when you cast this spell, the initial attack deals an extra {@damage 2d6} damage and the {@condition poisoned} condition ends.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: If you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the spell's damage increases by {@dice 1d8} for every slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Judgement (reckoning)
entries: You summon a judge with dominion over all creation (such as an Inevitable or the servant of a god of law) to sentence one creature within range that you can see.
The target must make a Charisma (Deception) or Charisma (Persuasion) check against your spell save DC. On a failed save it suffers one of the following effects of your choice:

entries.name: Forgotten
entries: The target's name disappears from all written records. Any creature that tries to remember its name must first succeed on a DC 20 Intelligence saving throw, after which it remembers the target and information about it for the next hour.

entries.name: Exiled
entries: Exiled. The target is teleported to a location on the current or another plane of existence of your choice, and any spell, ability, or device that would teleport it or return it to its home plane automatically fails for 1 month.

entries.name: Betrayed
entries: Every creature that sees the target becomes hostile to it for one month, even those with a positive relationship with the target. A creature prone to violence may attack the target, while others are unfriendly and may deny the target hospitality, business, or aid.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, its range increases to Sight, and it targets a 1-mile radius instead of a single creature. You can exclude any creature or type of creature, such as dwarves, humanoid children, or beasts, from this effect when you cast this spell, or target a single type of creature such as elves or demons.

spell.name: Place of Honor (reckoning)

m.text: a holy symbol worth at least 10 gp, which the spell consumes

entries: You inter the corpses of up to 500 creatures within 1 mile of you that died of similar causes (such as a plague or a battle) within 1 month of each other in a 50-foot square mass grave.
As you finish casting the spell, you can raise a memorial to mark the field of dead, such as a burial mound, a stele, an obelisk, a pyramid, or a field of inverted swords.

These corpses can't be turned into undead. Any creature in the area that attempts to attack another creature or desecrate the grave site in some way (such as by excavating bodies or damaging the grave marker) must make a Wisdom saving throw.
On a failed save, the creature loses the attack or spell, or cannot attempt to desecrate the mass gave for another 24 hours. A target is unaffected if it is immune to being {@condition charmed}.

entries.name: As a Reckoning
entries: When you cast this spell {@book as a reckoning|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, {@dice 2d100} celestial spirits, construct spirits, or fiendish spirits (your choice) patrol the spell's area. They guard the area against intrusion and desecration with their lives, and will leave it if necessary, but cannot be convinced or compelled to take on another mission, including through magical means. They are under no obligation to obey your commands, and usher visitors in and out of the area at their sole discretion.
In addition to its normal components, casting this spell as a reckoning requires 200 suits of plate armor, which the spell consumes.

spell.name: Weight of Years (reckoning)

m.text: a timekeeping device worth at least 5 gp

entries: You twist the flow of time within one creature that you can see within range, rapidly aging it. The target must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 1d6} necrotic damage and ages one year. The target repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns. On a failed save, it takes an additional {@damage 1d6} necrotic damage and ages another year. On a success, the spell ends.
This spell cannot mature a creature past your age.

entries.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6}, and the number of years aged on a failed save increase by 1 for every slot level above 2nd.

trait.name: Inscrutable
entries: The black quartz sphinx is immune to any effect that would sense its emotions or read its thoughts, as well as any divination spell that it refuses. Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) checks made to ascertain the black quartz sphinx's intentions or sincerity have disadvantage.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The black quartz sphinx's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Oath Awareness
entries: The sphinx knows if it hears a lie.

trait.name: Vow Judgement
entries: When the sphinx looks at a creature, it knows every promise it has ever made and broken.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The black quartz sphinx is a 10th-level spellcaster.
The black quartz sphinx's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell
save {@dc 19}, +11 to hit with spell attacks). The black quartz sphinx knows the following sorcerer spells:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sphinx makes two claw attacks and casts one spell it knows.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) slashing damage.

reaction.name: Guilty Verdict
entries: If the sphinx hears a creature tell a lie, the sphinx can make one weapon attack against it. It can then choose to grapple the target (escape {@dc 21}).

legendary.name: Claw
entries: The black quartz sphinx makes one claw attack.

legendary.name: Teleport (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The sphinx magically teleports, along with any equipment or creatures it is wearing or carrying, up to 120 feet to an unoccupied space it can see.

legendary.name: Cast a Spell (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: The sphinx casts a spell from its list of known spells, using a spell slot as normal.

Where their models savor riddles and puzzles, these statues carved from black stone obsess over honesty and vows. Scholars speculate they originate from the depths of the law-plane Mechanus, but no clockwork manipulates their stone bodies. While no one but the black quartz sphinxes know their origins, each knows every other—a clear sign of a common creator.

Black quartz sphinxes require no food, air, or sleep, and seem unconcerned with entertainment or stimulation. Generations pass around a statue of a black quartz sphinx before it moves, often to engage with an overheard promise.

Vows and oaths fascinate black quartz sphinxes above all else. They probe the speaker for context behind their decisions to swear and keep their vows with intimidating but genuine enthusiasm. {@spell Zone of truth} appears in these conversations, though the sphinx discloses the magic and insist all participants (including itself) stand inside.

Black quartz sphinxes have a pleasant demeanor and take much to anger. Oathbreakers are an exception; they remain courteous but cold to adulterers, traitors, and deserters. They only attack to defend themselves—or when lied to directly.
If deceived, the black quartz sphinx lashes out with its deadly claws before the liar finishes a sentence. It pulls the target close, takes it in its jaws, and burrows or teleports away.

If negotiations fail, the black quartz sphinx brings the full might of its magic to bear against. If in a merciful mood, it separates the liar and casts {@spell geas} upon them. The most common instructions force the target to speak only truth for the rest of their lives, or to find those they harmed, confess, and beg forgiveness. Otherwise, it brutalizes them with languid precision, ignoring their banished or sleeping allies. In such moments, they resemble cats playing with their food.

Though they obsess over honesty, black quartz sphinxes understand no one can always tell the truth. They dismiss petty lies told by children or those told to comfort or protect. Fraudsters, deserters, and oathbreaking paladins, however, attract their ire. The sphinx targets such liars in combat, even to its detriment.

monster.name: Brown Jenkin
languages: Understands all languages but can't speak

trait.name: Familiar
entries: With the DM's permission, the {@spell find familiar |PHB} spell can summon a brown jenkin

trait.name: Human Hands
entries: The brown jenkin can manipulate objects with the same dexterity that a humanoid of its size could.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) damage.

At first glance, a brown jenkin resembles an ordinary rat. The unlucky soul given the opportunity to examine the freak instead discovers a mammal with the body of a large rat, gnarled humanoid hands, and the face of a disfigured, bearded man. Inside its mouth lies a nest of sharpened snaggleteeth.
Summoned as a familiar, a brown jenkin uses these teeth to rip tiny patches of skin from its master or victims and drink their fresh blood. It can sustain itself through no other source.

Despite its diet, brown jenkins have no relation to vampiric undead. Instead, warlocks sworn to great old ones spawn them after their unholy communions with their patrons. Their psionic heritage grants them an inherent understanding of all languages, though no one can understand their loathsome tittering

A brown jenkin servant combines all the benefits of an imp and rodent: small size, deft fingers, and a nondescript appearance. They rarely fight in combat, but are known to attack commoners about to discover their masters' secrets. When they attack, they leap upon the terrified victim, gnaw through their rib cages, and consume their heart from inside.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The burning cream can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Heated Body (Azer)
entries: A creature that touches the burning cream or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The burning cream can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The burning cream makes two pseudopod attacks.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 2d6 - 2}) acid damage, plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Napalm Fountain {@recharge}
entries: The burning cream unleashes a torrent of burning slime that rains in a 15-foot-radius, 30-foot-high cylinder centered on a point within 60 feet of it. Each creature in the cylinder must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes {@dice 3d8} fire and {@damage 3d8} acid damage on a failed save, or half damage on a success

Open flame burns on the surface of these hunks of off-white caustic sugar. The smell of burning vanilla fills the air for miles around a burning cream's lair; experienced adventurers who smell dessert know to ward themselves against flame.
The fires burning across its body consumes a burning cream's flesh, and it will burn to fragrant cinders if it does not feed.

Thus, a burning cream has a voracious appetite which it satisfies at every opportunity. The oldest and most powerful creams maintain multiple lairs (cramped spaces that smell like bakeries, defensible from behind tight cover with fireballs) from which they venture to devour anything they can find. A burning cream can and will consume anything organic; the ruins of building destroyed by a burning cream contain nothing but stone foundations, iron nails, and skeletons that stink of pastry.

When confronted, the burning cream uses its amorphous body to squeeze through tight spaces where others cannot follow, then hurls flames through the gaps. When it recognizes its foes outmatch it, it instead blasts them with waves of caustic sugar. Many burning creams flee from cover only when given no alternative. Their appetites force them to devour anything and everything in their desolate, sweet-smelling territories, and to expand the moment they deplete its resources.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the calcite sundae fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The calcite sundae has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Telepathic Hub
entries: The calcite sundae can use its telepathy to initiate and maintain telepathic conversations with up to ten creatures at a time. The calcite sundae can let those creatures telepathically hear each other while connected in this way.

trait.name: Lord of Bones
entries: Spells and features that detect the presence of undead, such as the {@spell detect evil and good} spell, identify the calcite sundae as a powerful undead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Multiattack. The calcite sundae uses its Frightful Presence. It then makes two attacks: one with its Dragon Bite and one with one of its other available attacks, if any.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the calcite sundae's choice that is within 120 feet of it and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 19} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the calcite sundae's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Dragon Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Behir's Gut {@recharge}
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 14} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}40 ({@damage 6d10 + 7}) lightning damage.

action.name: Purple Worm's Shell Wrap {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 60 ft., one target. {@h}29 ({@damage 4d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage. If the calcite sundae isn't already grappling a creature, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 21}) and {@condition restrained} until the grapple ends.

action.name: Charm Ray Stalk {@recharge 5}
entries: The target creature must succeed on a {@dc 19} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} by the calcite sundae for 1 hour or until the calcite sundae harms it.

action.name: Mind Blast
entries: The calcite sundae magically emits psychic energy. Creatures of the calcite sundae's choice within 60 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 19} Intelligence saving throw or take 25 ({@damage 4d10 + 3}) psychic damage and be {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. A target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Solar's Sword {@recharge}
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 60 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d6 + 7}) slashing damage, plus 13 ({@damage 3d8}) acid damage.

legendary.name: Bite
entries: The calcite sundae makes one attack with its Dragon Bite.

legendary.name: Allocate Nutrients (costs 2 actions)
entries: The calcite sundae recharges one of its attacks.

A sleeping calcite sundae looks for all the world like a massive pile of bones and offal. When they rouse and begin to move, many mistake these massive oozes for a mighty undead; the sheer power of the butchered remains stored within itself make it even appear such to powerful magic. Only the wise, the clever, or the soon-to-be dead recognize its true nature—an ooze with a ravenous appetite for the corpses of other powerful creatures.

Enzymes in a calcite sundae's slime preserve the massive bones and powerful organs it collects. The viscous fluid also slips between cracks and into empty cavities, which allows the calcite sundae to puppet its chosen parts with impressive dexterity.

Every calcite sundae maintains a collection of body parts within itself. Beholder eyestalks, electrical organs from behir, dragons' skulls charged with elemental energy, and half-rotted elder brains often appear inside their translucent blue bodies.

The lingering spirits soaked into the bones and brains of the creatures it absorbs influence each calcite sundae's personality, which makes them eclectic and eccentric in the best of circumstances. Their overriding desire for more parts overcomes any other changes to their mindset, but a diet of devils or undead may make the calcite sundae violent and unmanageable.

Beyond these rare exceptions, most calcite sundaes have a genial, if cunning, disposition. Some hunt alone, while others order their followers to scour the world for mighty monsters. They often travel across the world to duel dragons and demons before brave heroes arrive to slay them.

In these one-sided battles, the calcite sundae burrows underground while its weapons rejuvenate and erupts from the earth to strike. The target's summoned minions fall to the powerful charms or slashing blades of fallen extraplanar warriors. After a calcite sundae defeats its foe, it asks no payment beyond supplies for its followers and the corpse of the fallen beast. Many a calcite sundae has found a new home and an army of loyal followers after claiming a new corpse.

Adventurers who beat a calcite sundae to the proverbial punch may receive a surprising letter carried by a calcite sundae's followers. Without fail, the message promises magic items or wealth from another creature's hoard in exchange for the corpse's delivery. The letter includes no threats; most calcite sundaes have no objection to polite denials.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The conductive slurry can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The conductive slurry has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Seepage
entries: A 60-foot-radius area on the ground the conductive slurry is covered with an {@condition invisible} layer of slime. The conductive slurry has {@sense blindsight} within this radius, so long as the objects or creatures it is attempting to perceive are touching the ground.

action.name: Razor-Thin Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage, plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) acid damage.

reaction.name: Redistribute
entries: When the conductive slurry is targeted by a spell or other magical effect or within the area of such an effect, it instead takes no damage or suffers any other effects, and redistributes the damage and effects evenly among creatures in its space or standing in the area touched by its Seepage.
A passive conductive slurry possesses impeccable camouflage—a puddle of water. These thin oozes lurk on the cave floors or upon the surface of scummy water in search of unwitting prey.

Conductive slurries live underfoot, which makes them difficult to hit. Many attacks pass right through the unharmed slurry to smash against stone. When weapons fail, most adventurers turn to magic. This reasonable choice has led many heroes to their doom.

When struck by a spell or other magical effect, a conductive slurry digests the magic in an instant. An efficient metabolism spreads the energy throughout its entire body...and back into the hapless enemies that stand upon it. This massive range makes conductive slurries dangerous to fight at any distance.

Fortunately, conductive slurries, like most oozes, are stupid. Slurries have just enough intelligence to attack prey and foes with razor-sharp acid sheets, and no more tactical acumen. This efficient hunting lifestyle makes conductive slurries lazy ambush predators; few care to recognize or pursue escaping foes.

More obstacle than enemy, a conductive slurry flees through tiny cracks in stone walls when threatened. Unwilling and unable to conquer new territory, a conductive slurry cedes its position only until the threat departs. When quiet returns, the slurry slips back into its favorite spot and spreads itself thin once again.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the diaphanous mousse fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The diaphanous mousse regains 40 hit points at the start of each of its turns if it has at least 1 hit point and is immersed in water.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The diaphanous mousse deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Transparent
entries: Even when the diaphanous mousse is in plain sight, it takes a successful {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check to spot a the diaphanous mousse that has neither moved nor attacked. A creature that tries to enter the diaphanous mousse's space while unaware of the diaphanous mousse is {@status surprised} by the diaphanous mousse.

trait.name: Ooze Mass
entries: The diaphanous mousse takes up its entire space. Other creatures can enter the space, but a creature or object that does so is subjected to the diaphanous mousse's Engulf and has disadvantage on the saving throw.
Creatures and objects inside the diaphanous mousse can be seen but are otherwise considered to have full cover.

A creature within 5 feet of the diaphanous mousse can take an action to pull a creature or object out of the outermost parts of the mousse's space. Doing so requires a successful {@dc 21} Strength check, and the creature making the attempt takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) acid damage.
The diaphanous mousse can have any number of Huge or smaller creatures or objects inside it at a time.

trait.name: Juggernaut
entries: When the diaphanous mousse begins to move on a turn, it can only move in that direction until the end of the current turn.

action.name: Engulf
entries: The diaphanous mousse moves up to its speed. While doing so, it can enter Huge or smaller creatures' and objects' spaces. Whenever the mousse enters a creature or object's space, the target must make a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw.
On a successful save, the creature can choose to be pushed 5 feet back from the mousse. A creature that chooses not to be pushed suffers the consequences of a failed saving throw.

On a failed save, the mousse enters the creature's space, and the creature takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) acid damage and is engulfed within the outermost part of the ooze. The engulfed creature can't breathe, is {@condition restrained}, and takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the cube's turns. When the cube moves, the engulfed creature moves with it.

An engulfed creature can try to escape by taking an action to make a {@dc 21} Strength check. On a success, the creature escapes and enters a space of its choice within 5 feet of the mousse. A creature further inside the mousse can uses its action to swim to the edge itself.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. {@h}52 ({@damage 10d8 + 7}) acid damage.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 4 ft., one target. {@h}51 ({@damage 8d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage. This attack can only target an object or structure.

action.name: Melt Away (1/day)
entries: ). So long as the diaphanous mousse is submerged in water, it begins to dissolve. It deals halved damage with all attacks and other abilities, and has resistance to all damage. At the end of its next turn, it disappears. After 24 hours, it reappears at a point of its choice within 5 miles, so long as the point is connected by water to the body of water it was in when it used this action.

reaction.name: Perpetual Motion
entries: If a structure or object enters the diaphanous mousse's space, it makes a Ram attack against it.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The diaphanous mousse makes one Pseudopod attack.

legendary.name: Digest (costs 3 actions)
entries: Each creature and object within the diaphanous mousse's space takes 22 ({@damage 5d8}) acid damage and is pulled into the center of the ooze's space.

Ethereal and humongous, a diaphanous mousse resembles a shapeless gelatinous cube—if scaled to the size of a battleship. Diaphanous mousse drift just below the surface of lakes and oceans, where they sun themselves. Their favored positions make them a devastating threat to ships, for they, like their dungeon-dwelling cousins, are invisible.

Few ships' lookouts notice the bones and rust-free nails floating in the sea within a mousse's body. A crushing impact announces a diaphanous mousse's presence instead. Most captains would prefer to run aground than collide with a diaphanous mousse, for a grounded ship stops on impact.

Inertia carries the ship's draft through a caustic gel that disintegrates the hull. The loss of buoyancy and great weight drive the rest of the ship and its unfortunate crew down into the mousse's body. These passive creatures don't recognize the sudden meal when it strikes them, but their digestive currents pull unfortunate sailors closer to its center. There, as their lungs give out and muscles strain to swim in acidic gelatin, unfortunate sailors melt alive.

Diaphanous mousse are, however, easy to avoid. They cannot abide shallow water or dry land, and flee to another massive body of water of damaged. Massive damage—a barrage of cannonfire or powerful magic—can convince a diaphanous mousse to abandon its newest meal. It fades in instants, leaving scoured corpses, clean white bones, and the traumatized wounded to drift Conductive Slurry in harsh saltwater

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Dunwich horror's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 21}, {@dice +13} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells:

trait.name: Invisibility
entries: The dunwich horror is {@condition invisible}.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the dunwich horror fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The dunwich horror deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Implacable
entries: When the Dunwich hororr moves, anyobject or structure in its path takes 55 ({@damage 10d10}) bludgeoning damage if it isn't being worn or carried. This damage is then doubled by its siege monster trait.

trait.name: Child of Yog-Sothoth
entries: Though native to the material plane, the Dunwich horror is onsidered a native of the Far Realm when targeted by the {@spell banishment} spell and similar magic.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Dunwich horror uses its Frightful Presence. It then makes two stomp attacks or one hurl rubble attack.

action.name: Frightful Presence (Dragon)
entries: Each creature of the Dunwich horror's choice that is within 120 feet of the Dunwich horror and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 19} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the Dunwich horror's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}41 ({@damage 10d6 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Hurl Rubble
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 13} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 4d10 + 1}) bludgeoning damage.

legendary.name: Flail
entries: The Dunwich horror makes one hurl rubble attack.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The dunwich horror moves up to its speed.

Alien biology defines the outer gods. Some wonder if they have bodies of flesh and blood at all. Yet one such being, the watcher Yog-Sothoth, fathered two children by a human woman: the freak Wilbur Whateley and his younger brother: the Dunwich Horror.

lbur Whateley and his younger brother: the Dunwich Horror. Named for its hometown, the titanic Dunwich Horror's size belies its age. Still an infant, suckled on the blood of livestock, the mindless beast avoids discovery only through its stench, which repels passersby.

When unleashed, the Dunwich Horror leaves a trail of destruction as it barrels through forests and homes. This massive creature, "as big as a barn," hurls the rubble it leaves in its wake when threatened, but is no mindless beast. Though intelligent enough, it has few needs: food, solitude, and the degenerate cultist family who raised it. When denied them, it rampages.

In theory, heroes can stop a Dunwich Horror with ease. Though born in the Material Plane, its heritage and insane biology make it for all intents and purposes a native of the Far Realm. The caster of the {@spell banishment} spell, unfortunately, must see the target. Few wish to behold the Dunwich Horror, and even fewer remain unchanged after seeing it.

The {@spell see invisibility} spell or similar magic reveals an oblong creature made of dozens of fleshy tendrils tied together. Eyes and mouths cover its entire body, which walks on dozens of massive trunklike legs. A chinless humanoid face sits at the middle of the slimy mess, which is made of gel as much as muscle.

Even those who never see such an unpleasant sight fear the thing. Its smell and the sound of its uncanny toddler's voice paired with the destruction it causes terrify all who come near it. Those who persevere to cast banishing magic find themselves the targets of a wild charge that tears apart buildings around it, for the Dunwich Horror attacks such spellcasters the moment they reveal magic that can shift between planes, or lift its invisibility.

The Dunwich Horror runs when wounded and begs its father for aid via the {@spell contact other plane} spell. It is wiser to banish the creature than attempt to kill it. No hunter of eldritch things survives Yog-Sothoth's undivided attention.

trait.name: False Appearance (Cloaker)
entries: While the dust bunny remains motionless it is indistinguishable from a normal pile of lint.

trait.name: Familiar
entries: With the DM's permission, the {@spell find familiar} spell can be used to summon a dust bunny.

trait.name: Lint Body
entries: The dust bunny can squeeze through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing, and can gain sustenance from consuming dust, lint, or textiles.

action.name: Nibble
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit -2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} {@damage 1} piercing damage.

action.name: Poof {@recharge}
entries: The dust bunny exhales a 5-foot-cube of fuzz. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded} and unable to speak until the end of the dust bunny's next turn.

Weak and unassuming, a single dust bunny struggles to threaten even infants and the infirm. Their small size and penchant for cramped, dark spaces makes them difficult to discover, and they avoid conflict at all costs. The few homeowners who don't mistake them for dust often declare them harmless and leave them alone. Most regret their decision for years after.

Dust bunnies are miniscule balls of living lint and fluff that resemble cartoonish lagomorph silhouettes when in motion. They lurk beneath beds, behind furniture, and at the bottom of closets, where they consume fluff and breed. They reproduce like their namesakes; weeks after a pair of dust bunnies enter a home, dozens more fill every dark corner.

These piles freeze when confronted. Indistinguishable from an ordinary pile of dirt, a dust bunny colony acts like the detritus it resembles. The caretaker sweeps up the mess and deposits it outside...and the dust bunnies creep right back in. Though not intelligent, these fey know to wait for the cover of darkness or the owners' temporary absence to return. They then return to their favorite spots and stay motionless.
This process understandably confuses, then infuriates the
victims of an infestation. Most enter a cycle of ever-morefrenzied cleaning until the dust bunnies slip and reveal their true
nature. Even then, they remain non-confrontational. They flee and
hide when confronted as monsters rather than dirt, and use a
sudden burst of lint to blind attackers and cover their escape.

Their stealthiness, tiny size, and unusual diet of natural human byproducts makes them difficult to exterminate. Most colonies are obstinate enough to win a battle of wills against the residents. Many dust bunny colonies have driven families out of their homes as mounds dust coat their clothing, furniture, and food. The dust bunnies are all too happy to stay behind and revel in their new untouchable nest.

There are two ways to defeat a dust bunny infestation: burn the building down, or tame them. Standing still and holding out a hand filled with fluff makes dust bunnies accustomed to human presence. In time, they can be trained as any other animal. Dust bunnies make amazing budget familiars or a tertiary alarm network in palaces and mage towers. Few enjoy this tedious training and the endless dirt that results.

monster.name: Ectoplasm Golem
languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

immune.note: from nommagical attacks that aren't adamantine

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The ectoplasm golem can move through other creatures and objects as if they were {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The ectoplasm golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The ectoplasm golem's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Ethereal Sight
entries: The ectoplasm golem can see 60 feet into the Ethereal Plane when it is on the Material Plane.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ectoplasm golem makes two Withering Slam attacks.

action.name: Withering Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d8 + 5}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Ethereal Winds {@recharge}
entries: The ectoplasm golem rips energy from the Ethereal Plane in a 30-foot radius around itself and pulls it toward it. The ectoplasm golem gains 18 ({@dice 4d8}) temporary hit points, and creature within the area must make a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes 40 ({@damage 9d8}) force damage and is pulled 15 feet toward the golem. On a success, a target takes half as much damage and is not pulled. This ability ignores cover.

Most golem-makers mold their creations from mundane materials. Flesh golems' creators skirt the bounds of decency as they knit sinew and sew meat. And ectoplasm golems' creators revel in their horrible origins: the distilled remains of sentient souls.

Ectoplasm golem recipes rely on a few simple principles. Amass souls through any means necessary (the more powerful and intelligent the creature, the better). Distill the victims and mix the still-conscious remains into a half-sentient goop. Pour the goo into a mould and charge it with animating magic to give it all the powers of a ghost with none of the free will.

The process requires incredible necromantic and golem-crafting talents and even more incredible sadism. The result: an unpredictable creature that serves its master's will or the desires of the strongest spirits inside it. Many ectoplasm golems flee, return home, and live out a primitive recreation of their former lives, where their presence horrifies the living.

The process requires incredible necromantic and golem-crafting talents and even more incredible sadism. The result: an unpredictable creature that serves its master's will or the desires of the strongest spirits inside it. Many ectoplasm golems flee, return home, and live out a primitive recreation of their former lives, where their presence horrifies the living.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the halbird moves at least 15 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with its tusks on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The halbird makes two attacks: one with its beak and one with its spike.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) damage.

action.name: Spike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) piercing damage.

Halbirds take their names from the long, straight spikes that grow from the top of their heads. Even as early adolescents, these mutant axe beaks tower over their nestmates and kin. Their aggression matches their size, and their influence molds the flock's social dynamics into a territorial hierarchy.

Most axe beaks are aggressive. A halbird's presence intensifies their xenophobic attitudes, sending flock on the attack. The flock's numbers explode, and the new horde expands outward. Like locusts, the children experience inexplicable physical changes. Their plumage changes color, teeth extend from their beaks, and the birds acquire a taste for large animals. Prey and predator animals disappear as the flock expands its territory, as do isolated farms and even villages. Surrounded by dust and feathers, the screaming flocks overwhelm and devour cattle and caretaker alike.

trait.name: Twin Sisters
entries: The Hemwick hag can form a hag coven with one other hag, rather than two. The rules for coven creation and associated spellcasting can be found on page 177 of the Monster Manual and page 58 of Volo's Guide to Monsters. Most Hemwick hags will form a Prophecy Coven, if able.

trait.name: Sneak Attack
entries: Once per turn, the Hemwick hag deals an extra 14 ({@dice 4d6}) damage when it hits a target with a weapon attack and has advantage on the attack roll, or when the target is within 5 feet of an ally of the Hemwick hag that isn't {@condition incapacitated} and the Hemwick hag doesn't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Hemwick hag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring only somatic components:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Hemwick hag attacks with its eyegouge sickle, and uses its Charnel Caller ability, if able.

action.name: Eyegouge Sickle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d4 + 3}) slashing damage. If the Hemwick hag scores a critical hit, it rolls damage dice three times instead of twice, and the target is {@condition blinded}. To end this condition, the target must receive a total amount of magical healing equal to half the damage taken.

action.name: Charnel Caller {@recharge}
entries: The hag chooses a point within 60 feet of it. A {@creature shadow} rises from that point. The shadow is friendly to the hag and its allies, and pursues the nearest hostile creature to attempt to kill it. The DM has this creature's statistics.

reaction.name: Reposition
entries: If the Hemwick hag takes more than 5 damage from a single attack or other effect, it casts the {@spell invisibility} spell on itself and teleports to a point it can see within 120 feet of it.

Named for the village in which the first pair of Hemwick hags lived, these vicious viragoes tuck themselves away in lairs as grim and gory as their dispositions. They favor hideaways in butcher's districts, corpse-wax factories, necropolises, temples of mummification, and all places that disassemble bodies. Their proclivity for torture and butchery ingratiates them and their strange habits to their equally-freakish neighbors. These healthy relationships among sinister creatures grant them the freedom and flexibility necessary to gather eyes.

Hemwick hags have an unhealthy obsession with eyes. They adore these organs above all else, as they cannot complete their rituals without them. Harvested eyes allow them to peer into the Far Realm, shielded against the worst of the mind-breaking mysteries they encounter. Through them, they glimpse fragments of secrets that would drive most mad.

Each ritual consumes dozens of eyes, so Hemwick hags always seek more. A jar of preserved eyes all but guarantees a hag's favor, while a gift of clothing or jewelry adorned with eye imagery can placate an irritated one. Such practices save lives—for when one sees a Hemwick hag, another lurks in the shadows.

Sorties into the Far Realm taught the first Hemwick hags how to cheat the flow of magic between hags. Thus, they can form a coven with a single fellow hag, rather than two, with all the power such a relationship entails. If both members of the coven are Hemwick hags, one hides away, invisible, when others are present. The second welcomes guests in their bloodstained lairs, a filth-streaked amalgam of butcher's shop, laboratory, and observatory. This invisibility serves them well in combat; the two pop in out of reality, surrounded by summoned specters, to carve their victims' eyes out.

Not content with such vicious attacks, Hemwick hags conjure the eyeless specters of the creatures they harvested, which appear as lanky black humanoid silhouettes with blazing white lights in place of eyes. These ghastly creatures pursue the hags' victims with mindless hatred, granting the invisible hags openings. A hag may also hex a target's Wisdom, reducing its ability to perceive the pair, or cast hold person to lock their unfortunate target in place, giving the hag ample time to work.

trait.name: Eight-Dimension Mathematician
entries: . The Keziah Hag does not need to see a point to teleport to it with one of her spells.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Keziah Hag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}, {@hit 8} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Keziah Hag attacks twice with its Cosmic Visions

action.name: Sacrificial Dagger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 4d6 + 2}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@dice 2d6}) psychic damage.

action.name: Cosmic Visions
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 4d6 + 1}) psychic damage, and the target is banished to a harmless area of the Far Realm. It reappears in the nearest safe, unoccupied space at the end of the Keziah Hag's next turn.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The Keziah Hag makes one sacrificial dagger attack.

legendary.name: Teleport
entries: The Keziah Hag casts {@spell misty step}.

Keziah hags are invariably born as ordinary humanoid women, and retain that appearance throughout their entire lives. Their supernatural understanding of the underlying mathematics behind time and space, however, prove their time in the Far Realm transformed them into something far more.

Their newfound freedom from the evolutionary burdens of aging, hunger, and thirst gives Keziah hags the freedom to fulfill their greatest wish: to drift unmoored and aimless through space and observe Great Old Ones from afar.

The years she spends with her unblinking eyes affixed to the ever-shifting form of the Crawling Chaos or the endless births of the Black Goat of the Woods opens a Keziah hag's mind to secrets of the cosmos incomprehensible to mundane scientists. On the rare occasion she descends to the Material Plane, the ordinary three dimensions bend before her whims.

Keziah hags can pass through solid matter unimpeded. Their magic produces sticky reddish fluid, which often pools at the points where walls and floors meet—a solid boundary that they walk through with ease.

Their abilities make attempts to capture them almost impossible...as do their centuries of opportunity to create bizarre contingencies. One might allow heroes to imprison her in a remote temple, only to use a particular celestial alignment there to complete a ritual after years of miserable captivity. If she were to change her mind she could, of course, leave at any time.

If part of a coven, a Keziah hag acts as its face. Mortals can stomach the sight of them much longer than their sisters, and let their guard down around them all too often. But Keziah hags are just as powerful as the others and when pressed, simply share the knowledge they've gathered

With the touch of a single finger, a Keziah hag can hurl her enemies' minds into the Far Realm. Even a few moments' exposure shatters lesser minds, and leaves the hag free to turn on her other foes in the meantime. If somehow put on the back foot, the {@spell blink} and {@spell misty step} spells let her flee to safety, passing through walls and floors without a second thought.

Safe, isolated, and bearing a grudge, the Keziah hag watches and waits through the eyes of her brown jenkin familiar. She torments enemies in their dreams for years, then rips them apart after their sanity has frayed.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The parasite phloem can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the parasite phloem remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a patch of {@hazard green slime}.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The parasite phloem's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 13}, {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material or verbal components:

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit -1} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Cerebral Takeover
entries: The parasite phloem initiates a Constitution contest with an immobile plant or {@condition restrained} or {@condition incapacitated} beast, humanoid, or plant, within 0 feet of it. If it wins the contest, the parasite phloem slithers into the target's ear, mouth, or other orifice and spreads throughout its vascular system and over its brain, taking control of it.

While inside a creature, the parasite phloem has total cover against attacks and other effects originating outside its host. The parasite phloem retains its Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores, along with its spells. It otherwise adopts the target's statistics, including its senses, knowledge, proficiencies, class features, and hit points.

The host remains conscious and aware throughout the process, is aware of everything the parasite phloem perceives through its senses and can telepathically communicate with the parasite phloem. Telepathic spells can reveal a hidden consciousness beneath the parasite phloem's mind (which appears to be its victim's), but not the mind's identity.

These tiny purple blobs stand as still as possible as they lie in wait for prey. Most make their homes in dungeons, where they nest in patches of naturally-occurring green slime. All but helpless outside another creature, they flee from one lair to the next if discovered.

Though weak, parasite phloem combine superhuman intelligence and sinister ambitions. Though they can survive inside the vascular systems of almost any creature, most consign themselves to dungeon plants or weak animals. They all crave far more. A select ambitious few expose themselves to great risk and lie in wait for powerful monsters, or even humanoid adventurers.
