Parasite phloem have a simple and terrifying approach to hunts: they restrain or paralyze an isolated victim with magic, drop from the ceiling onto its body, and slither into an orifice. Though they prefer mouths, parasite phloem can pass through noses, ears, or even eyes to reach their final target—the brain.

As the phloem's physical body settles into the wrinkles of the organ, its mind begins to overcome the target's. The process takes only a few seconds and, if it succeeds, the parasite phloem experiences all its victim's memories, preferences, and emotions in a split second. It gains every one of the target's natural and earned powers, so long as it remains in the poor creature's body.

It takes time for to process this information. A parasite phloem prefers to ambush a solitary victim while it is separated from its group. When the pair return, the phloem feigns illness or fatigue and withdraws. This temporary leave gives it the time it needs to analyze the victim's memories and better adopt its identity.

The parasite phloem uses this information to adopt its victim's identity and live an ordinary life. Some even consult the fully-aware consciousness of their hosts for details, which few give without extreme duress. The trapped host watches as the parasite phloem lives in their place, a horrific and alienating experience.

Parasite phloem do not live this double life for its own sake; they grow infant parasite phloem in their host's digestive system. The droplet-sized oozes pass through the host's excretions and flee as far as possible from their parent to avoid exposure.

An infestation can overcome a small village in months and a city in a few years...but parasite phloem have no way to identify who their peers and children have enslaved. In a battle of extermination, parasite phloem employ the same tactics of careful deception and games of intrigue as their hunters.

monster.name: Poroniec
languages: understands the languages of its parents but can't speak

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the poroniec to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the poroniec drops to 1 hit point instead.

trait.name: Familiar
entries: With the DM's permission, the {@spell find familiar} spell can summon a poroniec.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The poroniec's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 12}, {@hit 4} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring only somatic components:

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Wail {@recharge 5}
entries: The poroniec lets out a withering wail. Any creature within 90 feet of the poroniec that can hear the wail must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 level of {@condition exhaustion}.

Also called "botchlings," poroniecs are the ghosts of stillborn or aborted infants that rise when their remains are not properly interred. These tiny reddish undead resemble a malformed infant, though they can toddle along on their grotesque, swollen legs with shocking speed.

Few use this speed to its fullest potential. Most prefer to hide in the walls of their would-be families' homes. Like a living newborn, their incessant wails keep the other residents from sleep. Sanity frays and tempers flare as the cries of an invisible ghost permeates the household. A poroniec's ability to cast invisibility at will lets it creep between hiding spots as the family tears the house apart in futile attempts to find it.

Most keep themselves hidden, content to torment their families with wails and curses. Even in direct combat, most hide in the house's inner structures use fleeting lines of sight through cracks in floors and walls to choose targets for their spells.

Most, however, fight only as a last resort. Most prefer to make life painful for their would-have-been families. They focus on parents and siblings, with a special and vicious preference for the younger siblings who live the lives the poroniec could have had.

Poroniecs are a curse on entire families, and that curse follows them where they go. These vengeful infants will follow their families, invisible, across entire continents. They always know where their parents are, and where to find them. Even a second death cannot stop them. If destroyed, they rise from the home's foundations the first midnight after their destruction, and resume their crusade.

A poroniec can be dispelled in only one way. The family must name the infant, locate its remains (if any), and properly inter them. Shrines or markers to honor a bodiless infant can also appease these creatures. When calmed, the infant either moves on to the afterlife, or transforms into a Tiny, neutral good {@creature shadow} (Monster Manual page 269) and surreptitiously protects the family from harm.

trait.name: Aura of Decay
entries: Creatures and objects within 10 feet of the rot haggis can't regain hit points. Any creature or object (including objects being worn or carried) that starts its turn within 10 feet of the rot haggis takes 3 ({@dice 1d6}) necrotic damage. A nonmagical weapon or piece of armor that takes this damage takes a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to damage rolls or the AC it offers, and is destroyed if the penalty drops to -5 or reduced the AC the armor offers to 10.

trait.name: Putrid Form
entries: A creature that touches the rot haggis or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 13 ({@damage 3d8}) necrotic damage. Any nonmagical weapon used to make the attack is destroyed. Nonmagical ammunition made of metal or wood that hits the rot haggis is destroyed after dealing damage.
When the rot haggis starts its turn in the same space it ended its last turn, a 1-foot cube of all material it is touching disinte-
grates and is absorbed into the rot haggis' body. If the destruction would cause the rot haggis to fall, it clings to the surface beneath the destroyed material instead.

trait.name: Ontological Impurity
entries: If the rot haggis is targeted with a {@spell purify food and drink} spell cast at 6th level or higher, it loses its Putrid Form, Stench, and Aura of Decay features and its alignment changes to neutral good. In this state, the rot haggis can be safely consumed as food if killed, which can sustain up to 15 humanoids for 24 hours

trait.name: Stench
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the rot haggis must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the rot haggis's stench for 24 hours.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) acid damage.

action.name: Corrosive Bile {@recharge 5}
entries: The rot haggis chooses 4 points it can see within 150 feet. Each creature within 10 feet of a point must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 21 ({@dice 6d6}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a success.

When a {@creature gelatinous cube} absorbs a nest of {@creature rust monster|mm|rust monsters} or dozens of other destructive creatures, it becomes a rot haggis. These meat-filled slimes lose their natural transparency and perfect cube shape, but transform into a mass of half-digested material glued together by sticky liquid. Rot haggises resemble a combination of vomit and rubble, and appearances are not deceiving: they are as disgusting as they are dangerous.

A rot haggis dissolves material at a fraction of its former speed, but gains unmatched digestive versatility. In addition to any organic material, a rot haggis can consume bone, metal, and even stone through contact. An idle rot haggis dissolves the material it sits upon, even at rest. When watched over a long time, the haggis appears to move down (or inward, if clung to a wall) as it dissolves the surface while clinging to the layer underneath. Rot haggises are loathe to move unless forced by circumstance, because they can eat without the slightest expenditure of energy.

When roused, a group of rot haggises are a force of nature. Their very presence melts everything around them into sludge, and their ever-hungry bodies suck up everything in their path. Weapons and ammunition crumble against their reeking bodies, but magic provides an unconventional way to defeat them. A powerful {@spell purify food and drink} spell rips through the rot haggis and transforms the embodiment of rotten foodstuffs into a serviceable meal. Few can stomach the idea of a meal of a creature they saw dissolve offal and bone a few hours before. But in a dungeon, desperate times often call for desperate measures.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The sanguine custard can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The sanguine custard regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point and isn't in sunlight or running water. If the sanguine custard takes radiant damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the sanguine custard's next turn.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The sanguine custard can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Vascular Flow
entries: The sanguine custard can enter or leave the corpse of a Small or larger creature through an open wound or orifice as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing. While inside, it has total cover from all attacks and other effects, and has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks.

trait.name: Bloody Leftovers
entries: A vampire can use a bonus action on its turn to command the sanguine custard to sacrifice itself to it. If it is willing, the sanguine custard moves as close to the vampire as it can through the safest route possible. If it ends the movement within the vampire's reach, it flows into the vampire's mouth and is consumed. The vampire regains a number of hit points equal to twice the custard's current hit points.

action.name: Bloody Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 2d6 - 3}) necrotic damage.

reaction.name: Drink
entries: When another creature within 15 feet of the sanguine custard takes piercing or slashing damage, it regains hit points equal to half the damage taken so long as it is not behind total cover.

When a messier vampire tears a victim apart to devour their innards, the undead curse in the blood causes the leavings to congeal into an ooze. A sanguine custard is a mindless mass of living blood that slithers from room to room in a vampire's lair, where they can hide in exsanguinated corpses in relative comfort. A single vampire lair often contains dozens of sanguine custards. They only leave their hiding places to engage intruders, which they attack on sight. While weak and easily killed, the sodden cacophony of their clumsy attacks alerts other guards. Many a party of brave vampire slayers has met their end because they failed to slip past a single sanguine custard.

Sanguine custards serve vampires in another way when in direct combat. Though they have an unpleasant flavor, vampires can use them as emergency rations. When threatened, the vampire calls the custard to leap into its mouth. With its last thoughts, the custard flows through the vampire's digestive and circulatory systems and restores it to health.

trait.name: Bulky Swarm
entries: Creatures within the swarm of rust monsters' space have disadvantage on saving throws against its features and traits.

trait.name: Iron Scent
entries: The swarm of rust monsters can pinpoint, by scent, the location of ferrous metal within 30 feet of it.

trait.name: Reactive
entries: The swarm of rust monsters can take one reaction on every turn in combat.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm of rust monsters can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Medium rust monster. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points, and is immune to any effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Rust Metal
entries: Any nonmagical weapon made of metal that hits the swarm of rust monsters is destroyed after dealing damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The swarm of rust monsters makes four bite attacks, or two bite attacks if it has half its hit points or fewer.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Feeding Frenzy
entries: The swarm of rust monsters corrodes every nonmagical ferrous metal object it can see within its space and within 5 feet of it. If the object isn't being worn or carried, the touch destroys a 1-foot cube of it. If the object is being worn or carried by a creature, the creature can make a {@dc 11} Dexterity saving throw to avoid the rust monster's touch. On a failed save, the object is destroyed.

Few monsters inspire dread in an adventuring party more than a group of rust monsters. The bravest knights flee in terror at the sight of even a single creature; chivalry matters little when faced with the loss of invaluable and expensive armor.

When whipped into a frenzy, rust monsters form massive swarms. Packed tight together, the mass charges toward any source of metal, surround it, and dissolve it in seconds. They rarely attack directly except to stop bearers of particularly large or tasty ferrous objects from fleeing with their next meal.
It is fortunate that most buildings are made of wood or stone. A swarm of rust monsters can turn a metal skyscraper into dust in a few hours, and few can stop their crazed feast.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The tormentor locust has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The tormentor locust doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the tormentor locust fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Trampling Charge
entries: If the tormentor locust moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a hooves attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 22} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the tormentor locust can make another attack with its hooves against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Thundering Wings
entries: While the tormentor locust is flying, all creatures within 500 feet of it are {@condition deafened}.

trait.name: Targeted Wrath
entries: Celestials, beasts, plants, and humanoids of good alignment are unaffected by the tormentor locust's attacks, spells, or other abilities. When such a creature would target the tormentor locust with an attack or harmful spell or effect, it must first make a {@dc 22} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature must choose a new target or lose the attack, spell, or effect. This feature forces the creature to reposition areas of effect, such as the {@spell fireball } spell.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The tormentor locust can move through other creatures and objects as if they were {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Abyssal Smoke
entries: Caustic smog rises from tormentor locust in a 5-foot radius around it; it is lightly obscured and has half cover (included in its statistics). A wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses it.

trait.name: Agony Bringer
entries: When the tormentor locust reduces a creature to 0 hit points, it is reduced to 1 hit point instead. Until the target completes a long rest, it is afflicted by the {@spell power word pain|XGE} spell, even if it is immune to the {@condition charmed} condition. The tormentor locust knows when a {@spell power word pain|XGE} spell it inflicted ends so long as it is within 10 miles of the target, and when another tormentor locust inflicts {@spell power word pain|XGE} upon that target.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tormentor locust makes three attacks: one with its hooves, and two with its sting.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}35 ({@damage 8d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 4d8 + 7}) piercing damage plus 33 ({@damage 6d10}) acid damage.

Only the strongest-willed scholars can overcome the existential dread that comes of understanding tormentor locusts' true nature. They are undeniably demonic, living packed together in a sealed pit within the Abyss that only a prophesied meteor impact can open. Yet they serve at the heavens' command, no evil can sway them, and their very essence is cosmologically aligned with the forces of cosmic Law and Good.

Even a single locust can threaten an entire city, and they will ride out in multitudes when Judgement Day comes. For now, few will encounter the stragglers that remain on the Material plane. Those few are terrifying enough.

Fortunately for the heroic, a tormentor locust cannot harm a good creature. Though they can harm neutral creatures as they could any other, they prefer to reserve their wrath for evildoers—which cannot escape them.
Invisible creatures cannot hide from a tormentor locust, and few can outrun them. They can even pass through walls and soil at breakneck speed in their single-minded pursuit.

They are not, however, stupid. Their strength allows them to endure damage of Incorporeal Movement that ghosts and creatures with similar abilities could not. They use this ability to strike from unexpected directions, from inside walls and beneath the floor. Few will reveal themselves, but the horrible sound of their droning wings announces their presence across the world.

A tormentor locust is determined, among all else, to make the wicked suffer. When the pain of a tormentor locust's sting fades, it returns to the sinner at its earliest convenience—if another member of the swarm doesn't reach it first. Thus the cycle of injury and agony continues, until the next stage of the apocalypse begins. Then, the locusts will fade away into the cosmos, their mission complete.

Deployed in the days before the final destruction of sin, prophesy tells these instruments of divine wrath will pour out of the Abyss when the blare of the fifth of seven trumpets calls a meteor to earth, which shatters their prison when it lands. The army that pours from the Abyss will be so numerous that, when viewed from a distance, it resembles a column of smoke. The cloud disintegrates moments later as the legion soars across the world to torture sinners.

A tormentor locust cannot kill. But its victims will beg for death as its attacks inflict terrible pain. Their appearance is as nightmarish as the torture they in a cloud so dense they resemble smoke. The sight of the nightmarish locusts is prophesied to terrify sinners before their stings rain upon them. Though undeniably insects, they have the faces of men with long, unbraided hair. Golden crowns rest upon their brow above a rictus grin of lion's teeth. A breastplate wraps around their armored breastplate, protecting the base of its wings, which roar like thunder. The sight, like an eldritch horror, can drive men mad—and is a sign that the end times have arrived at last.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The troll meat casserole can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The troll meat casserole regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If the troll meat casserole takes fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the troll meat casserole's next turn. The troll meat casserole dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Bile Body
entries: A creature that touches the troll meat casserole or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) acid damage.

action.name: Hurl Bile
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 30/60 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) acid damage.

reaction.name: Agonized Flailing
entries: If the troll meat casserole takes fire damage, it makes four hurl bile attacks. It must also make a Wisdom saving throw with a DC equal to the damage taken (after applying its vulnerability to fire damage). On a failed save, it moves up to its speed away from all hostile creatures without provoking opportunity attacks.
The deranged or desperate often look at a troll and see a source of unlimited food. In some cases, their mad idea works well.

Cooked by fire and digested by stomach acid, well-done troll meat loses its regenerative properties. It makes for a rancid meal of gamey protein that can nevertheless sustain the starving indefinitely.
Troll meat tastes best when cooked low and slow in a pot of seasoned water, for at least three days. When time becomes scarce, only troll meat fire-grilled to near charcoal is safe to eat.
Otherwise, even chewing can't save the unfortunate eater.

As digestive juices flow into them, the clumps of shapeless, half-living muscle fibers grow immune to stomach acid and begin to regenerate. Within a few hours, the internal pressure evolves from indigestion to agony.

The muscle fibers fuse together and roil in the stomach, growing rapidly. Once they reach sufficient size, the troll meat casserole is born, and bursts out of the nearest weak spot. The fortunate vomit the ooze up. An excruciating process, but better than a half-formed mass of troll parts bursting from the torso.

A single tainted stew thus turns the aftermath of a feast into puddles of gore and flailing meat that flees into the shadows as soon as possible. Troll meat casseroles are confused, stupid, and terrified of the world around them, and seek safety wherever they can find it. The lives of these misshapen clones are nasty, brutal, and short; few grow into a proper troll. Most end their days as a puddle of vomit that flails desperately at everything in its path.

trait.name: Ballooning Body
entries: The vapor slop cannot use its hover speed unless it is Large or larger. It is also not slowed by dragging a {@condition grappled} creature.

trait.name: Encompassing Cloud
entries: Other creatures can enter the vapor slop's space. When a creature enters the vapor slop's space or it enters another creature's space, the creature must make a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature enters the vapor slop's space. The creature can't breathe, begins choking, and is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 20}). At the start of each of its turns, the creature must make a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw against poison or spend its turn retching and reeling. Creatures that don't need to breathe or that are immune to poison automatically succeed on this saving throw.

trait.name: Invisibility
entries: The vapor slop is {@condition invisible}.

action.name: Inflate (3/day)
entries: The vapor slop's size increases by one category. If there isn't enough room for it to become grow to its full size it attains the maximum possible size in the space available. The vapor slop gains access to its hover speed for 10 minutes, after which it returns to its normal size. If another creature is within the vapor slop's new space when it expands, it must succeed on a {@dc 20} saving throw or be engulfed as described in the vapor slop's Encompassing Cloud feature.

reaction.name: Pop
entries: If the vapor slop takes damage while inflated, it returns to Medium size, releases any creature it is grappling, and flies up to 180 feet without provoking opportunity attacks. After it stops moving, it is no longer inflated.

reaction.name: Steal Prey
entries: When a creature fails its saving throw against the vapor slop's Encompassing Cloud, the vapor slop can use its Inflate action and move up to its speed.

Comprised of gas rather than gel and shockingly intelligent for an ooze, vapor slops share one attribute with their larger and more common gelatinous-cube cousins: transparency. Clever ambush predators, vapor slops hover in tight dungeon pathways with a convenient chimney or empty shaft nearby. When an unwitting creature passes through a vapor slop's permeable outer skin, acrid toxins flood its lungs. The gossamer skin contracts and forces the gases inward, which catches its prey in a viselike air current. Air is similarly forced outward, which swells the slop's balloonlike body and renders it lighter than air.

The vapor slope then soars away on its newfound buoyancy, with a struggling, choking victim caught in its center. Vapor slops fly to their preferred nests, where they deflate around the now-suffocated target and begin to digest. If the poor creature lived through the flight, it will not for much longer.

Though they may appear as passive as other oozes, vapor slops recognize danger before or after they hunt and defend themselves accordingly. They never stand and fight unless forced, and only engage if they've captured a meal too nutritious to abandon. Stinking cloud, a concentrated burst of its potent gases, keeps the most dangerous threats at a distance. Incendiary cloud detonates those same gases, and blocks the vision required for many spells. These floods of deadly gas force enemies back down the tight passages between the vapor slop's lair and hunting grounds. The vapor slop then settles in to enjoy its prey, often a friend of its recent enemies.

Vapor slops prefer a simple life in all aspects, not only hunting and combat. Though clearly intelligent and perceptive, they remain content to rearrange dust and sand into patterns. An idle vapor slop settles onto a dusty surface and, through dexterous contractions in its bubble-like skin, arranges particles into whorled partners that resemble "zen gardens" maintained in some eastern lands.

Despite this clear interest in art and patterns, no vapor slop can understand language. Communication with one is nearly impossible, but a large meal distracts most. Many dungeon-goers sacrifice horses and cattle to the vapor slop. The prey must be alive or slain only moments ago; vapor slops ignore abandoned supplies and detest carrion. One will, however, leave the travelers in peace while it enjoys the hearty meal. Spellcasters that summon a temporary creature can only trick a vapor slop once...and the jilted ooze will remember the devious mage and take appropriate revenge at an opportune moment, even if it must leave its hunting grounds to do so.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Wilbur Whateley's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 13}, +5 to hit with spell attacks). He can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Stench
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of Wilbur Whateley must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to Wilbur Whateley's stench for 24 hours.

trait.name: Unnatural Presence
entries: When a beast with an Intelligence of 3 or less sees Wilbur Whateley for the first time on a turn or can see him at the start of its turn, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} of him until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Concealable Biology
entries: When fully clothed, Wilbur Whateley appears to be an ordinary human.

action.name: Light Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage.

Though far less horrific or notorious than his half-mad younger sibling, the elder Whateley brother is no less devoted to his inhuman father than the Dunwich Horror. Only half an eldritch being, Wilbur's human mind endows him with a ferocious curiosity for learning. He channels his scholarly ambition in the forbidden archives of Miskatonic University, where he researches lore on summoning Yog-Sothoth, his inhuman sire.

Wilbur's inhuman nature makes him unpleasant and offputting. Even well-behaved pets grow aggressive when they enter Wilbur's presence, and his unusual body odor repels otherwise tolerant and open-minded scholars. He is an ugly, goatish man, with yellowish sallow skin, crumbling hair, and distorted eyes that contain a terrible intelligence.

Despite these quirks, his wardrobe gathers the most attention. He wears bulky clothing that covers his entire body even in sweltering summer heat, hiding a body like a plague-ridden satyr beneath his billowing pants. A rudimentary yellow eye sits on each hip and distorted, bruise-like patterns cover his back. Though slain by a simple guard dog many years ago, most other elder god-human hybrids share his characteristics. A careful hunter of extraplanar horrors learns to recognize the smell of such beings, which clings to their homes and possessions no matter how hard they work to disguise it. Tracking and killing these hybrids has prevented countless catastrophic confluences between the Far Realm and Material plane.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The word eater's weapon attacks are magical.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The word eater is a 5th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 12}, +4 to hit with spell attacks). The word eater has the following spells prepared:
footerEntries: *The word eater casts these spells on itself before combat

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The word eater uses its paper cuts. It then makes two attacks with its slice.

action.name: Slice
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 4d4 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Consume Book
entries: The word eater touches a book or scroll within 5 feet of it. The book is destroyed, and added to the word eater's body, granting it 11 ({@dice 2d10}) temporary hit points. If the book or scroll is a spellbook or spell scroll, then the word eater permanently learns any abjuration spells contained in it. If the book is worn or carried by a creature, the creature can make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw to avoid the word eater's grasp.

action.name: Paper Cuts
entries: A 5-foot cube appears, centered on a point the word eater can see within 60 feet of it. A creature takes 10 ({@damage 4d4}) slashing damage when it enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there. This cube persists for 1 minute.

As fighters and paladins fear rust monsters, warlocks and wizards dread encounters with word eaters, these air elementals have a genuine and voracious passion for learning. In another world, they would have made perfect assistant and apprentices...but a word eater enthusiastically devours books in a very literal sense. When a word eater touches a book, the air currents in its body rip the pages to shreds and knowledge floods its incorporeal mind.

Word eaters favor specific schools of magic, and whenever one consumes a spellbook, it learns spells from that school. Most crave deeper understanding of the arcane, and don't care where they get it. Word eaters happily make arrangements with powerful wizards for a steady flow of spellbooks in exchange for their service, even powerful evils like necromancers and liches.

For wizards with the time and funds to copy and re-copy spells again and again, word eaters make powerful, loyal allies. Few can convince one to stop serving a practitioner of their preferred school of magic, and it will not betray its ally on empty promises.

In combat, word eaters transform the scrap paper in their bodies into whirling twisters full of razor-sharp pages. These attacks cut weaker targets to ribbons, but they prefer to hone their skills and focus on spellcasting...or new knowledge. Word eaters recognize arcane magic on sight, scan the area for spellbooks and their users, and prioritize those targets until it can devour the book and the knowledge within. A successful word eater delights in its new discoveries and practices those spells moments after learning them, often against the wizard it took them from.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The word eater's weapon attacks are magical.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The word eater is a 5th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 12}, +4 to hit with spell attacks). The word eater has the following spells prepared:
footerEntries: *The word eater casts these spells on itself before combat

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The word eater uses its paper cuts. It then makes two attacks with its slice.

action.name: Slice
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 4d4 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Consume Book
entries: The word eater touches a book or scroll within 5 feet of it. The book is destroyed, and added to the word eater's body, granting it 11 ({@dice 2d10}) temporary hit points. If the book or scroll is a spellbook or spell scroll, then the word eater permanently learns any abjuration spells contained in it. If the book is worn or carried by a creature, the creature can make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw to avoid the word eater's grasp.

entries: The word eater's weapon attacks are magical.

monster.name: Yellowcake Batter
languages: understands Common but can't speak it

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

trait.name: Armor-Piercing
entries: Whenever the yellowcake batter hits an object with a weapon attack, the hit is a critical hit.

trait.name: Synthetic Biology
entries: The yellowcake batter is immune to diseases, and is considered a construct for spells and other effects that target constructs.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The yellowcake batter is immune to diseases, and is considered a construct for spells and other effects that target constructs.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 1} to hit, range 120/300 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d12 - 2}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Particle Burst
entries: When the yellowcake batter takes acid, bludgeoning, fire, lightning, radiant, or thunder damage, it releases a burst of magical energy. Each creature within 10 feet of the yellowcake batter must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be afflicted with the {@condition Flesh Rot} disease ({@spell contagion} spell, PHB page 227), which manifests at the end of its next long rest. This disease cannot be cured by any means short of a {@spell wish} spell.
These rare slimes are born from the decay of a rare, alchemical fuel. They make their homes in remote, buried vaults of ancient storage facilities meant to contain dangerous waste—or weapons.
Yellowcake batters have no magical association with fire, or a metabolism to produce heat. Yet unexplainable internal warmth melts their bodies into viscous fluid with human-level intellect.

These xenophobic slimes have no interest in outsiders. They are cautious enough to not attack intruders on sight, but rarely allow them to stay for long. When roused, groups of yellowcake batters telepathically coordinate to encircle them and attack.
Though inaccurate, yellowcake slimes prefer to attack with hyper-hard metal slugs fired from their bodies at long range.

Suppressing fire from one slime forces targets behind cover...where its allies swarm them from all directions. They are even more dangerous when approached, for certain magical energies cause a surreal chemical explosion. The waves of radiation trigger other yellowcake batters, devastating living tissue nearby.

Yellowcake batters know all about this power, and even keep magical items at the ready to trigger it. Immune to the effects, they crowd around enemies and blast them with a series of explosions that leave survivors scarred and plague-ridden.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Abi-Dalzim is a 20th-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 22}, +14 to hit with spell attacks). He has the following wizard spells prepared:
footerEntries: *Abi-Dalzim is always under the effects of these spells

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: Abi-Dalzim wears a {@item ring of mind shielding}, {@item ring of invisibility}, and a turban of command undead (see below). He carries one {@item dust of disappearance}, one {@item dust of dryness}, and one {@item dust of sneezing and choking} in pouches on his belt. His turban is fastened with three brooches, each of which is a {@item stone of controlling earth elementals}.

trait.name: Turban of Command Undead
entries: While wearing this turban, Abi-Dalzim knows the exact location and type of undead within 1,000 feet of him.

Abi-Dalzim can telepathically communicate with one undead in range, or he can broadcast his thoughts to all undead within range at once. The undead receiving a broadcast have no special means of replying to him. Additionally, Abi-Dalzim can only use his Command Dead action while wearing this turban.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the abi fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Grave Magic
entries: Living creatures within 60 feet of Abi-Dalzim can't benefit from resistance to necrotic damage and have disadvantage on death saving throws.

action.name: Withering Touch
entries: {@atk msp} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 6d6+7}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Horrid Wilting
entries: Abi-Dalzim draws the moisture from everything in a 60-foot cube centered on a point within 300 feet of him. Each living creature in that area must make a {@dc 22} Constitution saving throw, taking 81 ({@dice 18d8}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much on a success. Plants and water elementals make this saving throw with disadvantage. A creature that fails its save by 5 or more has its speed halved until the end of its next turn. Casting this spell does not expend a spell slot.

action.name: Vanish (Ring of Invisibility)
entries: Abi-Dalzim and everything he is wearing or carrying becomes {@condition invisible} until his ring of invisibility is removed, he attacks or casts a spell, or he uses a bonus action to become visible again.

action.name: Command Dead (Turban of Command Undead)
entries: Abi-Dalzim targets one undead he can sense with his turban of command dead. The target must make a {@dc 20} Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the target falls permanently under his control, and must follow his commands to the best of its ability. An undead of CR 20 or higher can repeat the saving throw every 24 hours, ending the effect on itself on a success.
A creature that succeeds on its saving throw is immune to this effect for 24 hours.

legendary.name: At-Will Spell
entries: Abi-Dalzim casts one of his at-will spells.

legendary.name: Vanish
entries: Abi-Dalzim uses his Vanish action.

legendary.name: Spellcasting (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Abi-Dalzim regains one spell slot of 5th-level or higher.

legendary.name: Summon Undead
entries: Five {@creature skeleton||skeletons} or {@creature zombie||zombies} appear in unoccupied spaces within 60 feet of Abi-Dalzim. They remain until destroyed, and take their turn immediately after his. Abi-Dalzim can have up to fifty undead summoned by this ability at a time.

Few spell-namers spawn more speculation than the necromancer Abi-Dalzim. The few who study his writings believe him to be an ancient Baklunish mage whose esoteric powers and experiments allow him to live for centuries.

Abi-Dalzim maintains multiple lairs, favoring opulent palaces centered around oases and warren-like catacombs decorated with gems and precious stones. Masses of undead attend to his every whim, and would handle his basic needs—food, water, and sleep—if he required them. Though not believed to be a lich or other undead, Abi-Dalzim needs no sustenance. Many seek him to learn his immortal secrets. Few succeed.

feat.name: Benthic Servant
entries: You are adapted to life in labyrinthine seafloor caves. You require no extra movement to squeeze through tight spaces, have resistance to cold damage, and are immune to the effects of extreme pressure. While partially or entirely submerged, you have {@sense blindsight} with a range of 60 feet, except for points in that area outside that body of water.

feat.name: Castiron Stomach
entries: Your unnatural biological fortitude allows you to eat anything. You can gain sustenance from any organic or inorganic material that you eat, and things you ingest cannot deal poison damage to you, poison you, or affect you with a disease or curse.
Your Constitution score also increases by 1.

feat.name: Darklurker
entries: Your emergence strikes fear into the hearts of your targets, granting you the following benefits:

items: You gain proficiency in your choice of Stealth or Intimidation.

When you become visible on your turn, such as emerging from a {@spell fog cloud}, ending the invisible condition, or taking the Hide action, the first creature you damage before the end of your turn is frightened of you until your next turn ends.
Creatures that are frightened of you have disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks against you.

entries.name: Frightened of Invisible Creatures?
entries: The Darklurker feat encourages characters who enjoy inflicting fear to pass in and out of line of sight. DMs and players have three options to adjudicate this playstyle's interaction with the {@condition frightened} condition, which states "the [frightened] creature can't willingly move closer to the source of its fear.
The first: if the frightened creature does not know where the source of its fear is, no movement willingly moves it toward the source of its fear, as it approaches unknowingly.
The second: the frightened creature cannot willingly move closer to the last place it knows the source of its fear was.
The third: the frightened creature has no idea where the source of its fear is. As it could be anywhere, the frightened creature cannot move at all.

Discuss your choice with the group and its ramifications when any member, including the DM, plans to use the feat or the associated playstyle in any way. Abi-Dalzim's Abhorrent Adventurers recommends the second option.

feat.name: Geneseed
entries: You unlock an uncanny understanding of your people's influence on modern evolution, which grants you the following benefits:

items: You gain proficiency in your choice of Alchemist's Supplies, Medicine, or Animal Handling.

You learn the {@spell command} spell, and can cast it an unlimited number of times with this trait. You can only target aberrations, beasts, or plants with this spell, and the target must have a challenge rating equal to or lower than half your level. When you cast command with this feature, you and the target do not need to share a language. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

feat.name: Regal Presence
entries: You begin to grow into a myconid sovereign. The range of your rapport spores increases to 150 feet, and you can allow creatures you choose within that radius to telepathically respond to you and communicate with one another. Your maximum lifespan increases to 250 years.

You also learn the {@spell command} and {@spell calm emotions} spells, and can cast each once per long rest, though you can target plants with these spells any number of times. Each spell cast in this way has a range of 300 feet and requires no components; any requisite communication is carried through your Rapport Spores.

feat.name: Sleepwalker
entries: As a creature born of dreams, your body remains agile while you sleep. You do not automatically fall {@condition prone} while {@condition unconscious}, and while unconscious you can move and take the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, and {@action Dodge} actions normally.

_.displayName: a prayer book written in cipher or code

entries: Some say that only two things differentiate a cult from an established religion: scale and popularity. You know otherwise. The cult to which you belonged skirted the edge of social acceptability and basic human decency, and centered around a single, charismatic leader. A witness to degenerate rituals and horrific religious punishments, only your iron will or unyielding zeal kept you from utter insanity.

Whether you belong to a sweeping conspiracy that controls society from the shadows, a remote compound dedicated to your cult's master, or an extremist offshoot an established faith, your membership in the cult determines every aspect of your behavior. Did you leave the cult and swear off their values forever? Are you on the run from their agents, who want to force you to return? Or are you a trusted lieutenant yourself, prepared to go out into the world to spread your faith or enact its terrible plans?

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Religion}, {@skill Intimidation}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@item Torturer's implements|Abidalzims}

items.name: Languages:
items.entry: Two {@table exotic languages|phb} of your choice

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: A mysterious holy symbol, a prayer {@item book|phb} written in cipher or code, a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 15 gp

entries.name: Cultist Creed
entries: Every belief system builds itself around an all-encompassing worldview. The collection of extremists to which you belonged is no different, and venerates a particular creature or set of ideals.
Choose one of the subjects and ideologies below, or roll once each table to decide the subject of your cult's veneration and the core motivation of its behavior toward it.

entries.name: Feature: One Among Many
entries: Others shun and fear your cult. Whether you are a true member or an apostate, you can use the mere implication that they support you to browbeat hapless locals into submission. Through fear, you can convince them to grant you favors that they would have otherwise rejected, or overlook your actions lest they incur the wrath of your cult. Though this technique may backfire on those who see through your facade or learn to see you as a manipulative figure, you're able to leave an impact on the uninformed through social pressure, the threat of violence or assimilation via a powerful social tool among the masses.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Many cultists are zealous and offputting, with blind devotion to an ideal that seems nonsensical or even dangerous to others. This devotion is often ironic, and they compensate for any internal doubts with ever-greater zeal. A few, however, are ardent missionaries ready to debate and disseminate their ideas to bring more loyal converts into the fold.

rows: I idolize (or fear) the subject of my cult above all else.
When opportunities arise, I share my faith with enthusiasm and sincerity.
I like to leave signs that a member of my cult was present, such as graffiti or dropped notes.
I become violently angry when someone contradicts my worldview.
I enjoy dropping hints that I know things that others could never imagine.
When I look at someone, I think about how they could best serve my cult.
I believe in endless self-improvement, so I can better serve the cult.
{@b Loyalty.} Nothing can shake my faith, and I follow orders to the letter. (Lawful)
{@b Tolerance.} I tolerate others' views, since I have to make a good impression for my people. (Good)
{@b Ascendancy.} I believe I know better than our leader, and plan to overthrow them. (Chaotic)
{@b Sadism.} My cult does terrible things to good people, and I enjoy it. (Evil)
{@b Scholasticism.} I wish to study our core tenets to learn why we believe the things that we do. (Neutral)
{@b Evangelization.} Spreading my faith is important. (Any)
I would happily die for the cult if ordered to do so.
My cult was destroyed, and I will bring the perpetrators to my own sick justice.
I will hunt down and reconvert apostates, and kill them if they refuse.
I'm hunting the lost relics or foundational tomes of my esoteric faith.
Our leader disappeared, and I must find them.
I'm on a holy mission, and will not be swayed.
I don't follow the instructions of anyone other than the cult's leader.
I argue philosophy every chance I get; even if it's polite, it wastes everyone's time.
Violence is the only solution when dealing with heretical enemies.
I resort to torture and abuse before considering more peaceful resolutions.
People who don't follow our religion aren't people at all.
I am unyielding and inflexible in my thinking.

_.displayName: a tiny roll of tearable parchment scraps
a symbol of the organization you infiltrated, such as a signet ring or badge

entries: For some, the ends justify the means. You are an enforcer of law and order, and belong to a prominent organization that hunts lawbreakers and evildoers—but you specialize in infiltration and mimicry. It is your job to join cults, thieves' guilds, slaver rings, and other organizations that commit dangerous and heinous acts. Once you infiltrate them, you pass information about their beliefs, movements, and plans to your superiors, so they can act accordingly—or have you stop them the moment they set their evil plans into motion. You may even rise through the ranks and attempt to twist their attention in new directions.

Throughout your tenure, your leaders and peers called upon you to commit terrible deeds to initiate you or prove your loyalty. You may even have encouraged or helped plan violent acts as you waited for your superiors to take action... and watched helplessly as your targets committed terrible crimes, unhindered.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Deception}, {@skill Stealth}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@item Disguise kit|phb}

items.name: Languages:
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: A set of {@item common clothes|phb}, a hidden badge of office, a bottle of black {@item ink (1-ounce bottle)|phb|ink}, a quill, a tiny roll of tearable parchment scraps, a symbol of the organization you infiltrated such as a signet ring or badge, and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 15 gp

entries.name: Target Faction
entries: Many types of dangerous groups, large and small, plague urban underworlds and untamed countrysides. These groups have particular goals and practices, which are often bizarre. You have intimate knowledge of their behavior, which may influence you even after you depart.

entries.name: Feature: Emergency Supplies
entries: You prefer to operate without assistance from your patron organization, to avoid suspicion. However, in times of great need, you know how to pass messages to your superiors to both report information and request material assistance.

Once every seven days, you can request a single piece of adventuring gear to be delivered to a location of your choosing through clandestine means. To do so, you must have the means to contact your patrons and choose a location for the drop that an unskilled laborer can easily access.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Double agents inhabit a world of sin, temptation, and terror, operating outside the law in a desperate attempt to uphold it. Only the best maintain their ideals to the bitter end and manage to bring evildoers to justice.

rows: I enjoy the taboo activities I'm forced to participate in a little bit too much.
I have a genuine fondness for some members of my target, and feel guilty about my inevitable betrayal.
I use charm and charisma to gain my targets' trust without following along with their harmful actions.
I'll commit any evil act to win their trust and gather the information we need to bring them down.
As soon as I have what I need, I'm getting out of here.
When I meet a new person, I study them to best decide how I can use them to further my own goals.
Nobody besides me can do this job.
I weasel my way out of as many evil acts as possible.
{@b Compliance.} Though I have opportunities to act, I defer to my superiors to decide when to strike. (Lawful)
{@b Mitigation.} I try to temper the group's actions without blowing my cover. (Good)
{@b Independence.} I know how they think. I'll act when necessary, orders be damned. (Chaotic)
{@b Contribution.} I actively seek ways to enhance the group's goals, even though it threatens others. (Evil)
{@b Curiosity.} The more information I can gather about my targets, the better. (Neutral)
{@b Study.} This group fascinates me, in a macabre way. I want to learn more about them. (Any)
This group harmed me or mine in the past, and I seek revenge.
The group spreads a corrupted version of an ideology I support—I want to set the record straight.
I am broken and disposable, so I volunteered for this suicide mission.
I can save these people, rather than destroy them.
A loved one joined the group; everything else is secondary to getting them out unharmed.
I'm not content as a rank-and-file member here. I plan to climb.
It takes every ounce of willpower not to kill these people where they stand.
I've fallen to this group's ideology and will betray my original faction.
I regularly disregard my orders to do what I think is right, even if it damages the mission in the long run.
I came to care about one or more members and will risk my mission to rescue them.
I'm in over my head. Without resources and support, I can only follow the herd.
I lied about my true goals. I love what I'm doing.

_.displayName: an {@table 25 gp art objects|dmg|art object} worth no more than 25 gp given to you by a favorite client

entries: You have a knack for the world's oldest profession, where you work for the pleasure of others. Whether in private or in public, you can identify viable targets for seduction, and have a knack for worming your way into their good graces before you please them.

Life as a prostitute, even a high-class one, is often dangerous. Some clients grow far too attached and develop expectations that threaten your life or livelihood. Others are sadistic, and their pleasures deal lasting damage to your mind and body. Society often views members of your profession as used-up and disposable, leaving you vulnerable to dangers that others could easily avoid.
Regardless, you act as a provider of relief and pleasure for your clients, and you can be secure in the knowledge that there will always be demand for your services.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Insight}, {@skill Performance}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies:
items.entry: One type of {@item gaming set|phb} or {@item musical instrument|phb} of your choice

items.name: Languages:
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: A set of {@item fine clothes|phb}, a {@item gaming set|phb} or {@item musical instrument|phb} (your choice), an {@table 25 gp art objects|dmg|art object} worth no more than 25 gp given to you by a favorite client, and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 10 gp

entries.name: Social Status
entries: Your social status determines how you find work. You may have hawked your services on the street (where you sold your body for copper coins), been a professional in a reputable establishment, or a sophisticated courtesan on an aristocrat's arm. You may have been prepared from a young age for this role, or sold into slavery as an adult.
In general, the more expensive your social status, the safer your lifestyle before you became an adventurer. Choose one of the roles below, or roll on the table.

entries.name: Feature: Eyes up Here
entries: Your charisma and the alluring nature of your profession attracts attention. You can exploit the lust and jealousy of others to make others focus on you, forcing them to drop their guard and prevent them from noticing things they might see otherwise. For example, seducing a guard lets you distract him until your party sneaks past him or your knife appears at his throat.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Most prostitutes are not as promiscuous as commonly believed, but all are shaped by both memorable and traumatic experiences. Many genuinely enjoy their work and the wealth it brings, while others prostitute themselves temporarily or out of necessity.

rows: I stay upbeat no matter how bad my circumstances get.
I'm blunt and honest about the nature of my work, and see no shame in it at all.
I resent my profession and the fact that I need it.
A gentle touch and a sweet word will get you places.
I get as much pleasure as my clients, if not more.
I drown my shame with vice and addiction.
I will never forget a face or a name.
{@b Regulation.} I am a fervent believer in the use of legislation to protect workers like me. (Lawful)
{@b Intimacy.} I provide comfort to the hurting and pleasure to the miserable. (Good)
{@b Art.} I see my work as a form of self-expression, and reject moralizers. (Chaotic)
{@b Manipulation.} Prostitution gives me access to many secrets and opportunities for blackmail. (Evil)
{@b Devotion.} Prostitution is a sacred duty in my religion and a critical part of my faith. (Neutral)
{@b Wealth.} Work is work. I'm in demand, and it makes me rich easily. (Any)
I will use my connections to climb to the top of the social and economic ladder.
I will open my own brothel, and ensure prostitutes who work for me live safely and comfortably.
I have a keepsake of a client I was once close to. I can't bear the thought of losing it.
Once I have enough money to live comfortably, I will quit this lifestyle and never return.
A client humiliated or even assaulted me, and I will avenge myself.
I care about the others I work with like my own family.
I assume any kindness or courtesy I receive is motivated by lust.
I think the best of my clients too easily, which in my career is naive and dangerous.
I care only about the coin provided, not the duties or dangers of my job.
I have fallen into other self-destructive habits like gambling and addiction.
I am crass and crude about my encounters, and like to bring them up in inappropriate situations.
I will do anything to undercut the competition.

entries: Whether you committed a terrible crime or your people banished you due to circumstances beyond your control, you have no place to call home. Your shallow friendships end as fast as they begin, and you struggle to form stable relationships of any kind.

You drift from place to place or inhabit the very edge of a town or city. When you dare venture into civilization, you draw the eyes of all you meet, who whisper as you walk by. Though not often met with violence, you may find yourself "encouraged" to leave by authorities, or have businesses close their doors to you.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Stealth}, {@skill Survival}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@item Herbalism kit|phb}

items.name: Languages:
items.entry: One of your choice

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: A tent, {@item blanket|phb}, {@item tinderbox|phb}, a spare pair of shoes, a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 15 gp

entries.name: Original Sin
entries: No group banishes one of their own without justification, though the legitimacy of their grievance is often questionable. Choose a transgression or roll on the table below to determine why your homeland cast you out.

Some sins are entirely outside your control, while others involve your past mistakes or use you as a scapegoat. Your reputation often precedes you, which makes socialization difficult even as you travel. While you can find far-off lands that know nothing of your past shame, you likely struggle to integrate and adopt their foreign ways.

entries.name: Feature: Emergency Stash
entries: Accustomed to self-sufficiency, you rely on yourself and your foresight to survive. When you enter or leave an area that you have visited once before (such as a town or a large forest), you can excavate a hidden cache of food, water, and a simple weapon. The food and water can sustain a single humanoid for 3 days. If you attempt to excavate a second cache before 30 days pass, you must roll a d20. On an 11 or higher, you find another.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Outcasts are, as a rule, haunted by the dozens of betrayals they experience over the course of their lives. Many are wary and slow to trust, though desperate for companionship. Their experiences intensify their good and evil inclinations, further separating them from the masses with their extreme behavior.

rows: I am desperate for companionship of any kind.
The most basic kindness is enough to win my loyalty.
I am uncomfortable in crowds and other social settings.
I am slow to trust but loyal to the end.
I haven't learned my lesson, and will stubbornly repeat the same mistake.
I always expect the worst of people.
I lie as easily as I breathe.
{@b Penance.} They were right to banish me. I accept my punishment. (Lawful)
{@b Support.} When I meet others in similar situations, I share my experiences to help guide them. (Good)
{@b Liberation.} The society that banished me felt stifling. Now I'm free to express myself. (Chaotic)
{@b Spite.} I'll take whatever I want from the society that rejected me. (Evil)
{@b Survival.} I focus on my everyday needs rather than dwell on the past. (Neutral)
{@b Discovery.} I don't understand why I was banished, and want to find out. (Any)
I was wrongly accused and hope to set the record straight.
I yearn to return home a changed person.
I can protect others from my fate...if only I could get them to listen.
Through introspection and exploration, I hope to find a way to forgive myself.
Tearing down corrupt social structures is the only way to achieve the justice I crave.
I'm being hunted—and will do anything I can to hide.
I refuse to trust anyone with my deepest emotions.
I bear a grudge against everyone involved in my banishment, including bystanders and people absent.
I push everyone away, even the sympathetic.
I replay the last days of my life before my exile over and over again in my mind.
I intentionally terrify others with my presence because I enjoy their fear.
Now that I've committed one crime, I have no reason not to commit many more.

_.displayName: A set of artisan's tools of your choice

entries: A master artisan never wants for work. But mastery takes decades, so you elected to take a shortcut and studied advertising. You sell your goods with nothing more than a clever pitch, without the slightest concern for their quality.

Often, you make shoddy replicas that pass as real treasures made by master artisans under rudimentary inspection. Why build your own reputation when you can benefit from someone else's hard work? If found out, you can always peddle your wares to the next set of unsuspecting customers, most of whom will never know they purchased a fake.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Deception}, {@skill Performance}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@item Forgery kit|phb}, one type of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice

items.name: Languages:
items.entry: None

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: A set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice, 10 forged certifications of authenticity, a set of {@item traveler's clothes|phb}, a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 10 gp, and 50 counterfeit silver pieces

entries.name: Fake Specialty
entries: Choose two options or roll twice on the table below to determine the business or industry whose phony goods you peddle.

entries.name: Feature: Sham Product
entries: When you craft an item with a set of artisan's tools, you can use materials equal to a tenth of the item's actual cost. When you do so, the item's apparent quality and value are equivalent to the real thing, but it breaks after a number of uses equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). An item that is not used or expended, such as jewelry, breaks when it takes any damage.

An Intelligence (Investigation) check with a DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier reveals the item as a fake. The investigator has disadvantage on the check if it does not have proficiency in the artisan's tools necessary to make the item.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Counterfeiters are master salesmen and excellent at justifying their own actions to themselves. Some harbor feelings of guilt, while others dive gleefully into their carefully-crafted personas. A minority have no idea they make subpar goods at all, fooling themselves as well as others about the quality of their craft.

rows: Fraud is my art, and showmanship my craft.
I keep getting too attached to customers and feel guilty for deceiving them.
I'm terrified of torches and pitchforks.
Swagger and bravado are constants in my life.
I wish I could be as good as a real artisan.
I charge less than legitimate sellers to get business and feel better about my lies.
My goods aren't subpar...I'm trying my best!
{@b Technicality.} I don't make false promises about my goods. Instead, I let customers draw their own conclusions. (Lawful)
{@b Fulfillment.} It makes me happy to sell poor customers a version of products they could never otherwise afford. (Good)
{@b Defiance.} I was kicked out of a guild, so I make cheap goods to spite them. (Chaotic)
{@b Fraud.} I target the most gullible or stupid customers and squeeze them for everything they're worth. (Evil)
{@b Wealth.} I want to get rich quick and this is the easiest way to do it. (Neutral)
{@b Skill.} Even though my trade is founded on lies, I put my best effort into every forgery. (Neutral)
I want to find revolutionary ways to produce cheaper goods.
Corruption seeps into every corner of the guilds...I'll outcompete them with low prices.
I'll do anything to make money for people back home who need it.
I want to prove myself to a genuine artisan who I admire.
I pursue wealth and fame to win someone's love.
I'll keep going no matter how many times I'm caught.
I stick to my story to the bitter end, even when caught.
I'll tell any lie to make a sale.
If I can't get a buyer, I'm happy to steal.
There's no such thing as too much money.
I've killed to keep my fraud secret, and I will again.
I convince myself every sucker deserves their loss.

_.displayName: A book filled with nonsensical scribblings

entries: Too much time alone does the mind no favors. Left in isolation for many years, you began the long slide into madness long ago. Now wide-eyed and babbling nonsense, most you meet avoid you out of fear or shame at what you've become.

But beneath the madness, you have a cunning mind able to make leaps in logic that others cannot. Insanity is a path to reasoning that others can't hope to grasp, and gives you the power to face horrors that would drive others mad. After all, you already lost your mind.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Intimidation}, {@skill Investigation}

items.name: Languages:
items.entry: Two {@table exotic languages|phb} of your choice, which you don't realize you understand

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: A book filled with nonsensical scribblings, a small {@item bell|phb}, a threadbare {@item blanket|phb}, a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 15 gp

entries.name: Manifestations of Madness
entries: Lunacy takes many forms. Choose an unusual behavior or roll on the table below to determine how insanity alters your behavior.

rows: You adhere to an impossibly strict routine.
You never blink, and fix people with a constant wide-eyed stare.
You constantly fidget, tap your fingers, scratch yourself, or otherwise engage in other compulsive behavior.
You can't sleep without a light on.
You protect your food with your life and eat voraciously.
You snap between rage and joy like flipping a switch.
You believe every conspiracy theory you come across.
You compulsively count the seconds, minutes, hours, and days between events.
You compare everything to legends and fairy tales.
You hallucinate vividly and often, and believe your visions are real.
You laugh and shriek like a maniac in combat, unnerving your enemies.

entries.name: Feature: Madman's Ravings
entries: Even a stopped clock is right twice a day. When not in initiative, you can begin a mad, babbling stream-of-consciousness conversation about anything and everything that comes to mind. While in this state, you have advantage on all Wisdom (Perception) and Wisdom (Insight) checks to analyze others' reactions to your ravings, which often reveals secrets and hidden conspiracies. You can use this feature twice per long rest.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: The life of a lunatic is a lonely one. Insanity is a gateway to incredible talent and insight, but strange habits and ignored social graces isolate them from others. A few lunatics live a short, brilliant life, but most die alone in shame and squalor.

rows: After so long alone, I hate being left by myself.
I lash out when restrained or held back.
I don't trust doctors or healers.
I still seek knowledge, even though my findings drove me insane.
I believe myself to be an avant-garde artist. Maybe I am.
I am only pretending to be mad. Others' reactions to my behavior entertain me.
I fixate on particular individuals and try to become like them.
I am kind to my fellow madmen; far kinder than even the well-meaning sane.
{@b Conformity.} Despite my symptoms, I try oh so hard to fit into normal society. (Lawful)
{@b Sympathy.} Though I can't be cured, I do my best to aid those who can. (Good)
{@b Self-regard.} I am who I am, and I'm not ashamed. (Chaotic)
{@b Cruelty.} I use my insanity to justify sadistic acts. (Evil)
{@b Unpredictability.} Even I don't know what I'll do next. (Neutral)
{@b Restoration.} I'll do anything to be whole again. (Any)
I was driven mad by a revelation from a creature from another plane, who I seek to bring into the world.
I have an imaginary friend or enemy who I'm convinced is real. I want to prove that to others.
I have highly-specialized expertise in one area at the expense of all else.
One day, I'll make everyone else see the world my way.
I just want to watch the world burn.
I'm trapped inside my body, watching someone else take action. I need to break out!
I have no regard for the feelings, safety, or lives of others.
I bottle up my feelings until they explode, often at the worst possible moment.
I don't need any help—I'm fine just the way I am!
I destroy things to vent stress. The more valuable, the better.
I lose all composure when someone contradicts my twisted worldview.
I love being different from everyone else.

entries: You are a veteran statesman and bureaucrat, with an intimate understanding of the inner workings of government. Whether you occupy the public eye as an elected official or hold a tiny role in a labyrinthine bureaucracy, you belong to a modern government.

Though a politician has an essential role, you often face ire from every direction. You may need to shake the hand of a political rival while they scheme up the best ways to demolish your reputation—while you do the same to them. In lean times, the common people despise you and your decisions, or even hate you for policies entirely outside your control. All too often, you must enforce rules whose creation you had no part in with ruthless efficiency, lest you find yourself cast out of government and among the rabble that despise you.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Deception}, {@skill Persuasion}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@item Calligrapher's supplies|phb}, {@item Forgery kit|phb}

items.name: Languages:
items.entry: None

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: A set of {@item fine clothes|phb}, a {@item signet ring|phb}, {@item ink (1-ounce bottle)|phb|ink}, a quill, twenty sheets of {@item parchment (one sheet)|phb|parchment}, and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 10 gp

entries.name: Position
entries: No one in government holds exactly the same role. Each job in a bureaucracy has a unique functional niche and sphere of influence. Choose a position or roll on the table below to determine the scope of your jurisdiction and how you serve the people or government that appointed or elected you. Unlike a noble, you did not inherit your position; you earned it through honest work or underhanded maneuvering.

entries.name: Feature: Official Business
entries: With your intimate knowledge of political vocabulary and official terminology, you can often bluff your way into important locations. If a person or group recognizes the authority of the government from which your power derives, you can call on that authority to reinforce your barrage of jargon. With these intangible tools, you can bulldoze your way into locations and situations that you could never reach otherwise.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Some politicians are truly the slimy, unscrupulous, and corrupt officials the people believe them to be. Others are former idealists in over their heads, or even zealots ready to fight for their beliefs to the bitter end. Only the passionate personalities can survive the political arena, whether they care about others or themselves.

rows: I empathize with my opponents and easily understand their perspectives.
I have plans for enormous, sweeping reforms.
Despite my experience with bureaucracy, I loathe waiting and small talk.
I watch my words and actions with great care lest a scandal mar my career beyond repair.
I speak slowly, choosing my words carefully and with gravitas.
For better or worse, I love to exercise my authority and expertise.
I am often tempted to abuse my power, but refuse to give in to corruption.
{@b Compliance.} The machine of government has checks and balances that I follow to the letter. (Lawful)
{@b Service.} I serve the people, not the other way around. (Good)
{@b Infiltration.} I joined this system to bring it down from within. (Chaotic)
{@b Greed.} My position will enrich me and my prospects, no matter what it takes. (Evil)
{@b Routine.} I once had great ideas, but now I'm just here for the stable paycheck. (Neutral)
{@b Reform.} Government has many benefits, but also much that we can improve. (Any)
I lost a home and loved ones due to a governmental oversight, and I'll not let it happen again.
I or my family were once nobility, and I'm fighting to remain at the top in this new system.
Every day is an intellectual exercise and an opportunity to study the law, which I find thrilling.
I will work my way to the top and earn the highest position I can.
I will not let the people who appointed me down.
I adore the attention brought by the public eye and will do anything to maintain it.
I cheated to earn the position I have now and will eliminate anyone who tries to find out.
I can't imagine my rulings being wrong.
Anyone who stands in the way of my righteous crusade is an enemy to be crushed.
I am susceptible to bribes and flattery.
I insult opponents and misrepresent their arguments.
My blunders and antics keep me in the public eye for all the wrong reasons.

entries: Like an outlander, you grew up in the wilds far removed from the trappings of civilization. But most outlanders live in organized tribes, remote nomadic nations, and other societies. You did not. Instead, you were raised among inhuman creatures, who left you with a unique sense of normalcy.

Even if you have lived among more typical humanoids, giants, or other 'civilized' species for many years, your odd behaviors and inadequate education on social mores can cause mutual discomfort—or even lead to violence.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Animal Handling}, {@skill Survival}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@item Herbalism kit|phb}

items.name: Languages:
items.entry: One of {@language Bullywug|mm}, {@language Gnoll|mm}, {@language Grell|mm}, {@language Grung|mm}, {@language Hook Horror|mm}, {@language Otyugh|mm}, {@language Sahuagin|mm}, {@language Troglodyte|mm}, {@language Umber Hulk|mm}, {@language Worg|mm}, {@language Yeti|mm}, or another language spoken by a giant animal such as a {@language Giant Owl|mm}.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: A {@item dagger|phb}, 50 feet of {@item hempen rope (50 feet)|phb}, a {@item net|phb}, {@item fishing tackle|phb}, a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, and a {@item pouch|phb} containing 5 gp

entries.name: Brutish Behaviors
entries: Your near-alien origins make you conduct yourself in ways that seem entirely reasonable to you and bizarre or even horrific to others with more delicate attitudes. Choose a behavior or roll on the table below.

rows: Violent responses to surprises or insult

entries.name: Feature: Breath of the Wild
entries: Wild beasts often recognize you as kin, and respond accordingly. Through gestures, tone, guttural sounds, and body language, you can share simple concepts and ideas with most beasts and monstrosities.
You also gain sustenance from almost any vegetable or protein source, including normally indigestible substances like compost, bone, fur, and feces.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Feral children are no strangers to being strangers in strange lands. They often feel out of place and alienated by those around them, even if they are more like their new acquaintances than they are the animals that raised them.

rows: The civilized world is full of wonders to experience.
I find the strongest creature in any given area so I can challenge it for dominance.
I love testing myself in dangerous situations and grow bored when comfortable.
I wish I could kill the people who annoy me, the way I can animals.
I want to learn more about my biological heritage.
My way of living is superior; civilization makes you soft.
I am terrified of magic and technology I don't understand.
A united pack under a strong leader makes me happiest.
{@b Education.} I want to experience more of the trappings of civilization and immerse myself in it. (Lawful)
{@b Preservation.} The wilds and civilization both have merits, but nature needs more protection. (Good)
{@b Expression.} Society ties us down and restricts our ability to be our true selves. (Chaotic)
{@b Regression.} Humanity must be returned to a more primal state by force, for its own good. (Evil)
{@b Survival.} Life is dangerous and I must do whatever I can to meet my needs. (Neutral)
{@b Exploration.} The world holds many wonders, and I'm determined to see them all. (Any)
Encroaching humanoids destroyed my home and I want to stop it from ever happening again.
I recognized my true species and left (or was banished) to discover my true identity and origins.
A great predator stalks me; our past and future battles guide my behavior now.
I have an insatiable drive for knowledge about my heritage and to act like those who look like me.
I would do anything to return to the wilds, but can't.
Danger makes me feel truly alive.
Rank, station, and social standing mean nothing to me.
I hate wearing clothes any more than I have to.
Violence gets both people and animals to back off. I refuse to accept the long-term consequences.
