Gifts confuse, trouble, or even offend me.
I enjoy others' reactions to my antics and 'misbehave' on purpose.
I don't respect the sanctity of property unless forced to.

_.displayName: Three scroll cases, one with a false bottom

entries: Some knowledge is forbidden. Occultists are the dark side of academia, who hunt secrets that should have been locked away forever. Favoring taboo subjects, occultists bribe, blackmail, and butcher their way into the forbidden sections of sophisticated libraries and private collections. Obsessive to a fault, these scholars summon creatures and breach seals that should have been left unbroken, all in the pursuit of knowledge. More than one reckless occultist has risked the world's safety for the sake of the answer to an esoteric question only they care about.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Arcana}, {@skill Investigation}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies:
items.entry: Your choice of {@item Calligrapher's supplies|phb} or {@item Thieves' tools|phb}

items.name: Languages:
items.entry: One {@table exotic languages|phb|exotic language} of your choice

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Three {@item map or scroll case|phb|scroll cases} (one with a false bottom), a bottle of {@item ink (1-ounce bottle)|phb|ink}, a quill, a piece of charcoal, five {@item candle|phb|candles}, a piece of chalk, an empty {@item vial|phb}, a set of {@item fine clothes|phb}, and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 10 gp

entries.name: Deepest Lore
entries: Though you study many subjects and master many more, you have an area of interest that fascinates you above all others. This enthusiasm is both a blessing and a curse; it makes you a noteworthy figure in your chosen field but your obsession lures you to dangerous situations and places. Choose a topic or roll on the table below.

rows: The origins of life, and immortality

entries.name: Feature: Secret Texts
entries: Foolish moralizers do their best to censor the secrets you seek, but you are wise to their tricks. When you look at an object or surface that has or once had writing upon it, you can tell if the text has been written over, blotted out, erased, burned off, carved away, or otherwise modified. You cannot uncover its original meaning without other skills or techniques. You can also tell if invisible ink, spells, or other methods were used to hide writing on a surface, but can't discern its contents or meaning without other methods.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Occultists are obsessed, knowledge-hungry, dangerous, and off-putting. They are slaves to their mission to gather knowledge, whether they intend to hoard it or share it with the world. They are often willing to sacrifice anything to obtain ultimate knowledge.

rows: I often forget to eat, sleep, or bathe when engrossed in a new tome.
Sharing my findings with a willing listener makes me happy.
I'd do anything for a new source of information.
Intricate plans guide every moment of my day.
I collect idols, amulets, and other trophies from my findings.
I hum forgotten hymns in a language no one can speak.
I worship forgotten gods instead of the pantheon typical of my people.
I only let a fraction of my true knowledge slip through; enough to intrigue, but nothing more.
{@b Chronicle.} No matter my fate, I must record what I find for those who come after me. (Lawful)
{@b Preparation.} To fight evil, one must know it. Ignorance makes us weak. (Good)
{@b Defiance.} I refuse to let my small-minded peers dictate what I study. (Chaotic)
{@b Jealousy.} I don't grow close to people; they will steal my secrets if I let my guard down. (Evil)
{@b Truth.} The only dangerous knowledge is hidden or misrepresented. (Neutral)
{@b Fervor.} I'll gather new knowledge no matter the cost to myself or others. (Any)
I want to learn more about my area of study... which terrifies me.
I had a premonition of a terrible evil and became an occultist to better understand the vision.
I forgot my goals a long time ago. Now I research for its own sake.
I will use my findings to enrich and empower myself.
Inadequacy fuels me; I want to learn things nobody else does so I'll feel special.
My mentor disappeared in search of a mysterious power and I'll do whatever I can to get them back.
I like to terrify others with my findings, on purpose.
Mortals are a currency that I can trade with higher powers for secrets.
I enthusiastically murder to keep my studies secret.
When I work on a risky project, I put others in danger before myself.
After I learn all I can from a teacher, peer, or student, I betray or discard them.
Nothing matters save my obsession. Nothing.

entries: Few have the stomach for war. Even fewer have the courage to flee from it. You forsook your oaths of honor or the promise of payment and fled the field of battle—or never reached the killing grounds at all.
Whether your former superiors believe you died in battle or you face execution for your desertion if ever caught, you know one thing for certain: you will never belong to an army again.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Deception}, {@skill Survival}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies:
items.entry: One type of {@item gaming set|phb} of your choice

items.name: Languages:
items.entry: One {@table standard languages|phb} of your choice

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: A {@item two-person tent|phb|tent}, 5 days of {@item rations|phb}, one simple {@item weapon|phb} of your choice, a {@item compass|phb}, a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 10 gp

entries.name: Justification
entries: Just as your peers had reason to fight, you had a reason to run. The reasoning for your cowardice might haunt you, or strengthen your resolve. Choose a rationale or roll on the table below to determine why you fled the military.

rows: Abuse; I refuse to suffer under cruel officers any more.
Cowardice; I fear combat and death.
Deception; I have orders to pretend to desert.
Defeat; I never managed to rendezvous after a loss.
Family; my loved ones need more than this army.
Rout; my unit fled together to escape the slaughter.
Surrender; I was a prisoner of war, now released.

entries.name: Feature: Secret Intelligence
entries: Your firsthand experience as a former soldier gave you a wealth of information. While useless and obvious to you, a skilled strategist would kill to gain your valuable insights into morale, training, supplies and logistics, attitude, army composition, and more. You may even have details about a force's long-term goals or overarching strategies.
You can use the promise of this information to gain asylum with a military enemy or ally... but many despise traitors regardless of the gifts they bring.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Deserters are often broken, fearful creatures who dread discovery. They hold secrets close to their chest and may struggle to make lasting relationships. Some fear reprisal from a faction long gone, while others drown themselves in hedonistic pleasures.

rows: I'm wary of getting close to people lest I slip up and reveal my shameful past.
I committed terrible crimes and will atone in every small way I can.
I revel in the slightest luxury.
Exhausting days are no obstacle; they are nothing compared to what I faced before.
Rare is the conversation in which I speak more than a few words.
Pleasurable company is all well and good, but I prefer to be left alone.
I fear nothing for I am already broken.
Exuberance is the best disguise; if I don't act like a deserter then I won't get caught.
{@b Obedience.} I regret disobeying orders and won't do it again. (Lawful)
{@b Rejection.} "Just following orders" is no excuse. (Good)
{@b Freedom.} No one tells me what to do. (Chaotic)
{@b Avoidance.} I always shift blame to others. (Evil)
{@b Renewal.} I will put my past behind me. (Neutral)
{@b Impermanence.} Keep moving. I'll be executed if found out. (Any)
I will find and support the families of the comrades I failed to save.
I must escape 'justice' and reach a safe haven.
I will return to my family and live out my days in peace.
Inner peace guides me to a new future.
I'll never leave someone behind again.
I lost something valuable at my last battlefield.
I drown my misery in drink and vice.
I believe everyone is out to get me.
I wallow in guilt and accept any abuse to punish myself.
I blindly hate both my former allies and old enemies.
I curse the gods and belittle anyone religious.

_.displayName: a set of rags that were once common clothes
a pair of manacles and a length of chain

entries: Confined in the damp, rotten bowels of cities and castles, prisoners are lifelong captives left to rot in dingy cells. Forgotten save for their few abusers and even fewer friends, many wretches go months or years without a glimpse of the sun or a friendly face. Weighed down by the remains of their physical and spiritual confinement, escaped prisoners often struggle to reintegrate into normal society.

Many feel these wretches deserve their lot. They suffered a fate more terrible than death, reserved only for the worst criminals. These starved, desperate, and traumatized creatures can barely be described as human. They evoke pity on sight, but when they snap, rage built by decades of abuse bursts forth in a horrific surge of hatred for everyone and everything around them.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@skill Insight}, {@skill Perception}

items.name: Tool Proficiencies:
items.entry: {@item Torturer's implements|Abidalzims}, one {@item gaming set|phb} or {@item musical instrument|phb}

items.name: Languages:
items.entry: None

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: A set of rags that were once {@item common clothes|phb}, a pair of {@item manacles|phb} and a length of chain, a {@item pole (10-foot)|phb|10-foot pole}, a {@item sack|phb}, and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing miscellaneous small coins worth 5 gp

entries.name: Grim Keepsake
entries: A special torture marked your time in prison. Mutilations are likely, as are pieces of equipment placed around or in your body. These trappings have become part of your identity, accompany you in your freedom, and on the rare occasion that you remove them (if possible), you keep them close.
Choose a keepsake or roll on the table below.

entries.name: Feature: Pariah
entries: Your demeanor betrays your past and makes members of polite society uncomfortable. You can use this discomfort to your advantage; you can slip into places others couldn't as guards and passers-by look away to avoid eye contact, or put others on the back foot in social situations such as haggling. Those used to the traumatic and the wretched, like jailers or veteran soldiers, have no such reaction.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: In many cultures, no one is lower than a lifelong prisoner. Years isolated from the rest of society mark them as eternal outcasts, fit for nothing beyond an early and shameful death.

rows: I snatch up vermin and eat them on reflex.
Now that I have a chance to bathe, I preen over my own reflection.
I rub my wrists or ankles as a nervous tic.
I struggle without strict, enforced routine.
I crave the illicit substances common in my prison.
I am aggressive with people who remind me of rival prisoners.
No one is more vicious to people found innocent in controversial trials than I am.
{@b Penance.} My crimes were terrible and my sentence warranted. I served my time with honor. (Lawful)
{@b Atonement.} I will do right by the victims of my actions, whether they know it or not. (Good)
{@b Liberation.} I'm free! Now I'll find a way to free my fellow prisoners, at any cost. (Chaotic)
{@b Dominance.} I learned that might makes right. (Evil)
{@b Negotiation.} I have a knack for figuring out what people want, and how to get it. (Neutral)
{@b Innocence.} I was falsely accused, and will prove it. (Any)
I am terrified of an authority figure obsessed with hunting me down.
I refuse to sleep without my back to a wall.
I shy away from open spaces and the sun.
I do everything I can to feel well and healthy.
I unconsciously rub my scars while thinking.
I have a new lease on life and spread joy wherever I go.
I lash out at anyone who reminds me of my tormentors.
I refuse to improve my hygiene or health.
I try to hoard food, clean water, and medical supplies.
I kill quickly before taking the chance to talk or think.
I pick at wounds, refusing to let them heal.
I'm sadistic, like my captors. I learned from the best.

optionalfeature.name: Body Block
entries: When you are hit by an attack, you can use your reaction to expend one superiority die and attempt to a grapple a creature within your reach. You add the superiority die to the Strength (Athletics) check made to grapple, and if you succeed, you and the target switch places. Your target becomes the target of the attack instead.

optionalfeature.name: One-Two
entries: When you attack a creature, you can expend a superiority die and add it to the attack roll. If the attack hits, it deals halved damage, but you have advantage on all subsequent attack rolls against the target until the start of your next turn..

optionalfeature.name: Opportunist
entries: You gain a +4 bonus to weapon attack rolls made as a reaction.

optionalfeature.name: Inescapable Spell
entries: When a creature succeeds on a saving throw to end one of your spells of 1st-level or higher that is already affecting it, you can spend a number of sorcery points equal to the spell's level to make it fail instead.

optionalfeature.name: Devilish Dealer
entries: The first creature other than you that touches or attunes to this item must make a saving throw against the {@spell bestow curse} spell, which afflicts it until this infusion ends or it spends 24 hours at least 100 feet from the item. The creature is not aware it makes the saving throw, and if it succeeds, it must repeat the saving throw each time it finishes a long rest until it fails. A cursed creature becomes unwilling to part with the infused item.

optionalfeature.name: Replicate Magic Item
entries: This infusion adds a number of magic items from this book to the artificer's {@optfeature Replicate Magic Item|TCE} infusion.

optionalfeature.name: Entrance Undead
entries: As an action, you present your holy symbol and speak a command directing nearby undead. Each undead that can see or hear you within 30 feet of you must make a Wisdom saving throw. A willing undead can choose to fail this save. An undead that fails its saving throw is entranced for 1 minute or until it takes any damage.
An entranced undead will not attack you or target you with spells and other harmful effects, and when it makes an attack roll or saving throw, you can choose to grant it advantage on the roll.
If you are an undead, you cannot use this feature on yourself.

optionalfeature.name: Dominate Undead
entries: Starting at 5th level, when an undead fails its saving throw against your Entrance Undead feature, the creature falls under your control if its challenge rating is at or below a certain threshold, as shown in the Dominate Undead table.
While the undead is entranced, you can command it as described in the {@spell animate dead} spell.

optionalfeature.name: Pact of the Brand
entries: Your patron marks you with a symbol of service, such as a tattoo, scar, or brand, on a concealed part of your body. You can spread this brand to a creature when it fails its saving throw against one of your warlock spells of first-level or higher or takes damage from one. You can also use an action to touch a willing creature and apply the brand.

Your brand can appear on a maximum number of targets no greater than half your Warlock level. If you spread the brand to more targets, one brand of your choice is removed. All creatures with your brand are cursed by you, and a {@spell remove curse} spell removes the brand.

You know the direction toward each branded creature's location, so long as it is within 10 miles of you. Branded creatures can't hide from you, and if a branded creature is invisible, you ignore all of that condition's benefits.

You can use a bonus action to grant a willing branded creature all the benefits of one of your Eldritch Invocations for 10 minutes, so long as it meets that invocation's prerequisites. If an invocation has a level prerequisite or requires warlock spell slots, levels in or spell slots from any class (of the appropriate slot level) meet those requirements.
Once you share any invocation, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Cattle Brand
entries: You can cast {@spell dominate beast} at will, without expending a spell slot, on a beast you've branded. When you do so, you don't need to see the target, and the spell no longer requires concentration and has a range of 1 mile. The spell lasts until you successfully target another creature with it or the brand is removed.

optionalfeature.name: Amulet of Resurrection
entries: Your talisman is no longer destroyed if you die, and can be used in place of your corpse to restore you to life. If the talisman is on your corpse or used in place of your corpse, the spell used to resurrect you doesn't require material components.

optionalfeature.name: Claim Chattel
entries: You can cast {@spell charm person} at will, without expending a spell slot, on a humanoid you've branded. When you do so, you don't need to see the target, and the spell no longer requires concentration and has a range of 1 mile. The spell lasts until you successfully target another creature with it or the brand is removed.

optionalfeature.name: Cult Assembly
entries: You can use an action to touch your brand and choose any number of willing creatures branded by you. Each target is teleported to a space within 5 feet of you so long as it is on the same plane of existence as you. You can use this action once, and must complete a long rest before you do so again.

optionalfeature.name: Devil's Tattoo
entries: When you spread your brand to a willing creature, you can expend a warlock spell slot to choose a warlock spell of 1st level or higher that you know and inscribe the spell in your brand. The spell must have a casting time of 1 action or 1 bonus action.

You or the target can use an action to release the stored magic from its skin and cast the spell, immediately removing the brand. The spell uses your spellcasting ability and the target's senses and concentration (if required). You cannot force the target to concentrate on the spell.

optionalfeature.name: Fire Proof
entries: You can spread your brand to an object as if it were a willing creature, embossing your brand into its surface. You can cast the {@spell heat metal} spell on the object with a range of 10 miles, expending a spell slot as normal, even if it is not made of metal, or within your line of sight. If you brand another object with this invocation, the brand disappears.

optionalfeature.name: Guardian Sigil
entries: You learn the {@spell symbol} spell and can cast it once per long rest without material components.

optionalfeature.name: Icon of the False Prophet
entries: Your talisman appears to be a holy symbol, and anyone who scrutinizes your magic and abilities through any mundane or magical means concludes that they originate from a deity of your choosing, unless the observer is a god.
So long as you are wearing or carrying your talisman, you can attune to any item that requires a good alignment or levels in cleric or paladin to attune to it.

optionalfeature.name: Initiation Ritual
entries: When you share an invocation with another creature, it lasts for 1 hour, rather than 10 minutes. You can also share each invocation once per long rest instead of just one, though a creature can have no more than one invocation at a time.
You cannot share this invocation.

optionalfeature.name: Mark of Cain
entries: When you finish a long rest, you come under the effects of the {@spell sanctuary} spell. The save DC for this spell is 19 or your warlock spell save DC, whichever is higher.

optionalfeature.name: Marked for Death
entries: You can use a bonus action to force a creature within 60 feet of you that you've branded to make a Charisma saving throw against your Warlock spell save DC. On a failed save, the target becomes vulnerable to a damage type of your choice other than bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage for the next minute. The damage type is typically associated with your patron (such as psychic for The Archfey or The Great Old One, or lightning for The Fathomless).
Once a creature fails its saving throw, you can't use this invocation again until you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Sign of Sin
entries: You learn the {@spell malignant brand|AbiDalzims} and {@spell righteous brand|AbiDalzims} spells, and can cast each one once a day without expending a spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Suckle Cambion
entries: You gain a pool of hit points equal to thrice your warlock level that you can only use to heal creatures you summoned with a spell, such as {@spell find familiar} or {@spell conjure elemental}. If a creature you summoned ends its turn touching you, it regains 1 hit point and depletes the pool by the same amount. The pool replenishes when you finish a long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Voodoo Doll
entries: Using a piece of hair, a nail, or other part of a living creature's body, you form your talisman into a crude facsimile of that creature as you conjure it, which destroys the body part.

If you attack the talisman or target it with a spell, you can affect the creature it replicates regardless of cover, distance, visibility, or current plane of existence. You have advantage on any attack rolls made against the target, and spells that create an area of effect only affect the target. Any attack roll that hits is a critical hit. Once you target the creature, your talisman is destroyed and must be replaced.

entries.name: Age
entries: Elder things take five decades to reach adulthood. Their lifespan has no known limit.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Elder things live in a society with a complex bureaucracy and extensive trade, fueled by experiments that seem amoral and terrifying to modern scientists. They are usually lawful, and tend toward neutrality rather than good or evil.

entries.name: Size
entries: Elder things stand about 6 feet tall, and have a wingspan of 7 feet in diameter. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet, and you have a swimming speed of 30 feet. When in a vacuum, the astral plane, or outer space, you have a flying speed of 30 feet.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: Despite overwhelming evidence to the contrary, you are humanoid.

entries.name: Mental Discipline
entries: When you take a long rest, you instead can put yourself into a state of deep hibernation from which you cannot be unwillingly woken until a length of time you choose passes or a trigger you specify when you enter this sleep occurs (such as a creature you don't know entering the building in which you sleep). While in this state, diseases, curses, and other effects that inflict effects over time do not progress, you require neither food nor water, and you do not age. If you rest in this state for longer than 8 hours, it takes you 24 hours to regain consciousness.

entries.name: Lungless
entries: You don't need to breathe and can't be choked or suffocate. Inhaled poisons, spells that affect the air, and similar effects still affect you.

entries.name: Natural Armor
entries: You have rough, chitinous skin that protects your body from the harshest conditions. When you aren't wearing armor, your AC is 12 + your Constitution modifier. You can use your natural armor to determine your AC if the armor you wear would leave you with a lower AC. A shield's benefits apply as usual when you use your natural armor.

entries.name: Radial Symmetry
entries: You have five arms, five wings, five eyes, and five legs. You have a number of object interactions on your turn equal to your number of free hands, to a maximum of three.

You can wield a weapon, shield, tool, or item in each hand, but cannot make more attacks on your turn than your class features allow. If you wield multiple shields, you gain only the highest available AC bonus. Thanks to the unwieldy size of two-handed weapons, you cannot wield a two-handed weapon and a shield at the same time.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You know Common and Deep Speech.
God, what intelligence and persistence! What a facing of the incredible...radiates, vegetables, monstrosities, star-spawn—whatever they had been, they were men!
entries.by: Dr. William Dyer, Miskatonic University Professor

entries: Billions of years ago, the first ships of elder things landed on the surface of the material world. Inscrutable and alien, their cities of cyclopean stones lie buried in caverns beneath the underdark and frozen in remote glacial mountain ranges. There, intricate stone carvings detail their history and host cells of ancient, hibernating citizens. These bizarre people can hibernate indefinitely, untouched and unchanging. Some may wake when intruders delve into their lairs, and find themselves just as confused and horrified as their unfortunate trespassers.

entries.name: Bizarre Normalcy
entries: Elder things have an appearance unlike any other humanoid. Their bodies resemble vertically-oriented barrels, which measure nearly four feet at their widest and taper to one foot at the top and bottom. Five ridges run vertically along the surface of their chitinous skin. Leathery, batlike wings unfold from each one.

What the number two is to typical humanoids, the number five is to the elder things. Their heads are five-eyed and five-mouthed, five strong, thick legs support their bodies, and five tentacles extend from their torsos.

et elder things have more in common with modern   humanoids than their ancestral foes. Able to breathe both underwater and in the astral sea, the elder things built both terrestrial and aquatic colonies after they arrived. Their uneasy treaties with aboleths below and mind flayers above placed them in a position much like that of elves, dwarves, and humans today. They have no psionic powers, and their biology occupies a strange yet entirely mundane midpoint between animal and vegetable.

For this reason, the few elder things that emerge from the depths of their ruins find much common ground with the "new" humanoids that now walk the surface—provided their prospective friends can overcome their horror at the elder thing's appearance.

entries.name: Wisdom of the Elders
entries: The elder things' civilization possessed a vast collection of advanced technology, including spelljamming spacecraft, genetic engineering, and cosmological mapping.

oday, miniscule scraps of their knowledge remain. Those able to translate the fragments of their pictorial language or glean information from conversations with skilled elder things can achieve vast leaps in knowledge and natural philosophy.

entries.name: Ancient Colonizers
entries: The elder things built an empire that spanned the continents and oceans of multiple planets. Their long lives made deaths rare, so they practiced careful population control to maintain a sustainable society.

The prehistoric world contained no subjects for the elder things to rule...so they created their own. Elder things influenced the evolution of many plants and animals, and their experiments birthed the horrific shapeshifting shoggoths, whose descendants live on as gibbering mouthers. Designed as beasts of burden with durable bodies able to form any shape, shoggoths adapted to every task demanded of them.

The shoggoths' brains adapted to more complex tasks as their bodies grew. In time, they became more intelligent than their masters and destroyed the elder things' empire. Many, shadows of their former selves, still haunt the ruins their masters designed and they constructed.

entries.name: Elder Thing Names
entries: Elder things' names are as well-ordered and direct as their society. They take their names from their profession or role, followed by the number of 5-year intervals since their birth. The mouth with which they introduce themselves indicates to other elder things the year in that cycle they've reached. Their names remain the same for decades; name changes represent a major shift in an elder thing's life.
Elder things' names do not differentiate between sexes, and they translate their names into the dominant local language (typically Common) for the convenience of their neighbors.

items.name: Names
items.entry: Doctor-37, Geneticist-29, Student 6, 82 the Singer, Speaker 26, Apprentice 3, Sleeper 684—the Knower of All.

entries.name: Age
entries: Half-giants live long lives, but not nearly as long as true giants. They reach adulthood in their 30s and can live as long as 200 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Half-giants stand between 7 and 8 feet tall and weigh between 300 and 400 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Muscle Mass
entries: You are proficient in Athletics.

entries.name: Powerful Build
entries: You count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity, the weight you can push, drag, or lift, and the creatures you can grapple or shove.

How dare you bring this grotesque hybrid into my presence! I will conduct no further business with your 'party' till you remove it. Its foul nature violates the sanctity of my gardens. Stable it with the haugjotunen!
entries.by: Baroness Vinkova, Cloud Giant Ruler of Cirroway

entries: Beneath or outside the Ordning—the caste system of true giants—these radically-different groups share many physical traits. Some are hybrids, while others cluster together to survive in a world that has good reason to despise them.

In addition to their raw strength, the half-giants share a mutual hatred for one another. The nephilim possess a racial arrogance that rivals even the drow and consider themselves superior to all other races. Oni find troll and nephilim infants just as delicious as humanoid children. Half-trolls' and half-ogres' relationships with each other are the sole exception. Both find a grisly existence in roving warbands of orcs and goblins, or as brutish shock troops in hobgoblin armies. There, they enjoy the company of the few creatures that can sympathize with their circumstances.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Your Constitution score increases by 2.

entries.name: Age
entries: Myconids grow quickly, reaching maturity by the age of four and living just under a quarter of a century. A myconid sovereign instead lives roughly 250 years, and myconids of any meld can become a sovereign.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Myconids care little about the world outside their melds. The overwhelming majority are neutral.

entries.name: Size
entries: Myconids vary in size. Your meld determines your size.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 25 feet.

entries.name: Hybrid Nature
entries: You have two creature types: humanoid and plant. You can be affected by a game effect if it works on either of your creature types.

entries.name: Rapport Spores
entries: Myconids cannot speak, but you can communicate telepathically with all creatures within 30 feet of you, provided you and the creature share a language.

You are not, however, nonverbal; myconids still hum, whistle, and grumble, which forms the verbal components for any spells you cast. If you are silenced by an effect, you can still communicate telepathically with your spores, but you cannot use spells with a verbal component.

entries.name: Rot Eater
entries: You can touch an object made of dead organic material, such as an animal carcass, a wooden door, or a pile of feces, and accelerate its decomposition as you digest it. It takes 10 minutes to absorb 1 cubic foot of material. Doing so satisfies your needs for food (but not water) for the next 24 hours.

entries.name: Language
entries: You can read, understand, and write Common. You cannot speak it, or any other language.

entries.name: Subrace
entries: Choose one of the Melds below, which determines your physique and role in myconid society. You gain additional features and traits based on your choice.

Oh, dear. I'm afraid even {@spell resurrection} will not help your dear friend now. His corpse has joined the meld; the spores that infest his muscles cannot be removed. I offer my sincerest apologies for such an embarrassing affair, but he belongs to the circle, now and forever.

Also called mushroom men or fungus ones, myconids are intelligent, ambulatory fungi that live in the Underdark and the deepest, darkest depths of forests, seeking enlightenment and deploring violence. If approached peacefully, myconids gladly provide shelter or allow safe passage through their colonies. Battle fury taints their melds, so the myconids enter combat only in defense or as a last resort, viewing violence as part of the abhorrent nature of fleshy outsiders.

Instead, the moving mushrooms prefer a peaceable lifestyle, finding joy in pastoral commonality and shared happiness. Living in circles of roughly twenty myconids or settlements of larger groups, myconids cultivate non-sentient mushrooms and myconid sprouts in gardens. The precise 8-hour divisions of leisure, work, and melding creates a satisfying, if regimented, existence for these creatures, which regard such a lifestyle as completely ideal.

entries.name: Circles and Melds
entries: The largest myconid in a colony is its sovereign, which presides over one or more social groups called circles, which live in quiet groves bereft of speech but exploding with the color of the diverse plants, fungi, and compost within. The circle works, lives, and melds together under its sovereign, which settles disputes and makes decisions for the group.

A meld is a form of communal meditation that allows myconids to transcend their damp, pastoral existence. The myconids' rapport spores bind the participants into a group consciousness. Hallucination spores then induce a shared dream that provides comfort and social interaction. Myconids consider this shared dream, called melding, an enlightening act and the purpose of their existence. They use it in the pursuit of higher consciousness, collective union, and spiritual apotheosis. Myconids also use their rapport spores to communicate telepathically with softies who come seeking shelter or conflict.

entries.name: The Power of Spores
entries: In addition to the versatile rapport spores and sublime hallucination spores, myconids use reproduction spores to plant their children. The new young are cultivated in gardens to become myconid sprouts, precocious young raised communally by the circle. Pacifying spores stun hostile intruders so the group can flee or send a spore servant against them.

In contrast to this idyllic, pacifist lifestyle, spore servants represent a terrifying aspect of the fungal race—the corpses of once-living creatures raised to serve as soldiers, guards, and scouts. Creatures controlled by these animating spores serve the myconids for years, until years of decay and hard labor disintegrate their desiccated remains.

entries.name: Anatomy of a Fungus
entries: Myconids are bipedal, with thick, trunk-like legs capped by vestigial toes supporting their strong, squat bodies. Each myconid has two arms that ends with a pair of fingers and a single thumb, which are more than sufficient for their simple agriculture. Their bodies, made of tough mycelium, give them incredible durability, but can make their movements stiff and slow. Myconids grow dramatically over their lives, with sprouts barely reaching two feet and sovereigns towering to almost twelve.

entries.name: Flight from the Sun
entries: Myconids cannot abide sunlight. Even their most durable members, who can travel the world of softies, cannot stand it for long. The majority are even more vulnerable. Direct sunlight makes them deathly ill, and an hour of exposure kills most myconids outright. Myconids instead flock to the Underdark or shelter in the moist darkness of twilit forests. There, they find shelter among marshes and springs and a space to cultivate the moss and mushrooms they consume.

entries.name: Myconid Adventures
entries: Few myconids leave their circles for long. Their love of community and the dangers of the sun restrict nearly all myconids to their homes. The few myconids that dare venture out have distinct reasons for leaving their comfortable, insular lifestyle and joining the wider world:

rows: The regimented structure of myconid life seemed oppressive to you, so you left in search of adventure.
You left your circle as part of a scouting party; when you returned the circle had been destroyed, leaving you homeless.
You were sent to experience the outside world to prepare you to lead the circle as a new sovereign.
Your circle became too large. You are looking for the perfect place to spread your reproduction spores and found a new circle.
You slew a fellow myconid. Whatever your reason, such an act cannot be allowed to taint the meld, so you were banished.
You met an outsider taking shelter with your circle who regaled you with tales of the outside world, so you left to see it yourself.

entries.name: Names
entries: Myconid names sound nonsensical to outside ears, and they rarely use them within their circles. Rapport spores and melding let them to refer to one another with concepts rather than words.

When speaking with softies, myconids often take names from sounds each finds pleasing to the ear. Others borrow names from past visitors or use mushroom-related vocabulary to describe themselves, which amuses them.
Names: Basidia, Breberil, Brelup, Gasbide, Hebopbe, Loobamub, Phylo, Posbara, Rasharoo, Rumpadump, Stool, Yestabrod.

entries.name: Age
entries: Regarders are born with a fully-realized personality and intellect, an exact copy of their parent's personality that only diverges at birth. They live as long as a typical human.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Most regarders consider themselves the ultimate life-form, and all others beneath them. They are almost always evil, and tend toward lawful alignments as they seek control over their surroundings.

entries.name: Size
entries: Regarders have the same height and build as a malnourished humanoid. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Your immense eye takes in great quantities of light. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Beholderkin Magic
entries: You can use your eye to cast {@spell detect magic} once with this trait, and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. Starting at 3rd level, you can cast {@spell levitate} once this trait, targeting only yourself, regaining the ability to do so after a long rest. When you reach 5th level, you can cast {@spell dispel magic} once with this trait and regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Sharp Eyes
entries: You gain proficiency in your choice of Investigation or Perception.

entries.name: Eye Rays
entries: You can use a bonus action to shoot a beam of light from your eye at a creature you can see within 60 feet of you. Roll a d6 to determine the ray you fire. If the ray requires a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your Intelligence modifier + your proficiency bonus. Once you use an eye ray, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest or expend a use of one of your Beholderkin magic spells of your choice without casting the spell (no action required).

rows: Charm Ray. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be charmed by you for 1 minute or until it next takes damage.

Fear Ray. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be frightened of you for 1 minute. The target can repeat the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
Sleep Ray. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or fall unconscious for 1 minute or until it takes damage.
Slowing Ray. The target must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the target's speed is halved for 1 minute.
Weakening Ray. The target must make a Constitution saving throw or suffer disadvantage on Strength saving throws for the next minute.
You choose the ray that strikes the target.

entries: Don't let your dreams be dreams. Mine serve me as I see fit! The children of my dreams do my bidding, whether they realize their true purpose or not. Of course, some of them resemble me too much. Those, I slaughter the moment I wake. Can't stand upstarts that believe themselves my equal.
entries.by: Ghorgirsake, Eye Tyrant of Blackbottom Reach

entries: Beholders' dreams have the power to alter reality. The terrible creatures reproduce through these dreams (and one often destroys the other upon waking). When a beholder dreams of a humanoid avatar of itself, a regarder springs fully-formed into being nearby.

Each regarder possesses an exact copy of its parent's personality and most of their memories. Some even believe themselves to be the true beholder, and their parent an empty shell without a soul. Despite this arrogance, regarders have only a fraction of their parent's power.

entries.name: Utter Narcissimism
entries: All beholders are the epitome of ego. They believe beholders to the perfect life-form and culmination and all creation, and themselves the perfect expression of beholder form. Regarders, born as adults with a fully-realized beholder personality, believe much the same.
Newborn beholders rationalize their horrible humanoid form as a new evolution of beholderkin. As the most advanced beholders, they are obviously superior to all others.

These newborns lack the power to support their arrogance. Their eye rays are flickering candles before the blazing suns of a true beholder. Most beholders destroy their regarder spawn seconds after their birth or grind away their arrogant wills to mold them into servants and heralds. The rest manage to flee.
The hidden shame of their cowardice marks a regarder's early life, and they often overcorrect and become even more arrogant than a legitimate beholder...if such a thing were possible.

entries.name: Cyclopean Sages
entries: A regarder's head is an exact replica of its creator, without its eyestalks. Scaly, scabrous skin stretched over an exaggerated sphere of a skull filled with razor-sharp teeth below a noseless face and single massive eye does not make for an attractive traveling companion. Most beholders learn—quickly—to disguise their perfect faces from the ignorant and fearful eyes of other humanoids. The rest of their bodies share these attributes, so they often cover their hands and any deformities, as well.

Once disguised, regarders easily worm their way into the centers of spy rings and scholarly circles of forbidden knowledge. All beholders crave power and prestige, and regarders share both their desires and their centuries of experience. Their esoteric knowledge makes them invaluable to all organizations that seek long-forgotten secrets.

entries.name: Lingering Rays
entries: A beholder's eye rays are its most famous and deadly weapons. Without their parent's eyestalks, regarders lose access to most of their sheer power. Some of their craftier abilities still linger.

Regarders can use their eye rays to charm, frighten, weaken, or slow their opponents, or to put them to sleep. With loss of power comes greater control; they have a chance, unlike their parents, to choose which rays they unleash. They can also hover for a short time and have a limited ability to dispel magic with a glance.

Their natural talents could never compete with a true beholder, but adventuring regarders balance their weakness with other methods. Many bend their absurd intelligence to the study of wizardry. They may even, in time, outstrip their parent.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: If you replace a race with this lineage, you retain the ability score increases of that race. Otherwise, your Strength score increases by 2, and your Constitution score increases by 1.

entries.name: Age
entries: Your lifespan is triple that of the race from which you were transformed.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Slaves to the whims of aboleth and often unable to break away from their masters, skum are almost always lawful.

entries.name: Size
entries: Skum vary widely in height, from just over 5 feet to barely under 7 feet. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet, and you have a swim speed of 30 feet.

entries.name: Hybrid Nature
entries: You have two creature types: humanoid and aberration. You can be affected by a game effect if it works on either of your creature types.

entries.name: Ancestral Legacy
entries: If you replace a race with this lineage, you can keep the following elements of that race: any skill proficiencies you gained and any climbing, flying, or swimming speeds you gained from it. If you don't keep any of those elements or you chose this lineage at character creation, you gain proficiency in two skills of your choice.

entries.name: Locked Brain
entries: You have resistance to psychic damage and have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}. You instead have disadvantage on saving throws against being charmed or frightened if the creature that inflicted the saving throw is an aberration. You automatically fail all saving throws inflicted by any {@creature aboleth}.

entries.name: Mind Break
entries: You can use this feature as an action to attempt to shatter the mind of a creature within 5 feet of you and that is not immune to psychic damage. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw (DC 8 + your Intelligence modifier + your proficiency bonus). On a failed save, the target takes psychic damage equal to your level and has disadvantage on Intelligence and Wisdom saving throws until the end of its next turn.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (a minimum of once) and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. You do not expend a use when a target succeeds on its saving throw.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can read, speak, and write Common and Deep Speech. You can communicate with any creature that initiates a telepathic connection with you, even if you don't share a language with it or the connection is typically one-way.

"I have no diea who I once was. And I do not care. My flesh is slime, my limbs more articulate than any human's, elf's, or dwarf's. The water is my home and my master my god. I would have been content to serve him forever. You slew him...and so with nothing left, I suppose I will travel with you.

When the disease carried by an aboleth's touch runs its course, the victim undergoes a painful transformation that forever alters its mind and body. The unfortunate souls transformed into skum bear little resemblance to their past forms. With slimy, translucent skin and limbs transformed into tentacles, they resemble deep-sea oddities more than their former terrestrial species.

These wretched creatures are forever enslaved to their aboleth creators through sheer psionic might. Even without a master, skum are slaves to their new environment; without regular exposure to water, their skin erupts with excruciating lesions that distract them from even the most basic tasks.

entries.name: Enslaved Victims
entries: An ordinary skum is subject to its aboleth master's every sinister whim. A deep psychic bond communicates its desires to the skum immediately, even across vast distances. A skum has no say in the orders it receives, but is still intelligent and independent enough to carry out its orders without step-by-step instructions.

entries.name: Unexpected Liberation
entries: Ordinary skum remain in their master's lair for the rest of their unnaturally-elongated lives. You, however, earned the opportunity to take a different path without your master's overbearing will.Roll or choose an option from the table below to determine how you gained your freedom.

rows: Adventurers or mind flayers slew your master, but you escaped the carnage.
Your master released you in a rare moment of mercy...or to amuse itself.
You broke free before the aboleth could enslave your mind, but your body is gone.
Your master lives on a different plane and your connection broke when you came here.
Your master disappeared, as did your psychic connection. It might return at any time.
A servant of the gods freed you from the aboleth's service rather than slay you.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Half-oni experience an instinctive thrill when they terrify and harm others, and tend to operate in shadowy places outside the bounds of the law. They tend toward evil and are rarely lawful; persecution often pushes them deeper into chaos.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Your Charisma score increases by 1.

entries.name: Haunt
entries: You gain proficiency in your choice of Stealth or Intimidation.

entries.name: Kanabo Affinity
entries: You gain proficiency in {@item club|phb|clubs} and {@item greatclub|phb|greatclubs}.

entries.name: Bump in the Night
entries: You know the {@spell message} cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell sleep} spell with this trait, and you regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. Once you reach 5th level, you can cast the {@spell invisibility} spell once with this trait, and you regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

How dare you bring this grotesque hybrid into my presence! I will conduct no further business with your 'party' till you remove it. Its foul nature violates the sanctity of my gardens. Stable it with the haugjotunen!
entries.by: Baroness Vinkova, Cloud Giant Ruler of Cirroway

entries: Beneath or outside the Ordning—the caste system of true giants—these radically-different groups share many physical traits. Some are hybrids, while others cluster together to survive in a world that has good reason to despise them.

In addition to their raw strength, the half-giants share a mutual hatred for one another. The nephilim possess a racial arrogance that rivals even the drow and consider themselves superior to all other races. Oni find troll and nephilim infants just as delicious as humanoid children. Half-trolls' and half-ogres' relationships with each other are the sole exception. Both find a grisly existence in roving warbands of orcs and goblins, or as brutish shock troops in hobgoblin armies. There, they enjoy the company of the few creatures that can sympathize with their circumstances.

Fearsome boogeymen that haunt the nightmares of children and adults alike, onis' terrible appetites drive them to commit acts of savage, yet precalculated, violence. Oni resemble demonic ogres with brightly-colored skin, black or pure white hair, and a pair of short ivory horns. Their black eyes have strikingly white pupils, and they wield jet-black claws and teeth in combat alongside their massive clubs.

The children of shapeshifted oni and humanoids, most half-oni have little knowledge of their parentage and struggle to control their instinct to devour infants and inflict terror. Their black eyes and horns lead many to mistake them for tieflings, and only their immense bulk marks them as creatures born of nightmarish giants rather than the depths of Hell—a poor distinguishing feature.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Half-troll's prodigious durability and athletic abilities in a society of weaker peers tends to make them as cruel and arrogant as full-blooded kin. Half-trolls are often unlikeable bullies who hold positions of petty local power and tend toward evil alignments. They are often selfishly neutral, rather than lawful or chaotic.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Your Constitution score increases by 1.

entries.name: Territorial
entries: You gain proficiency in Perception. After you finish a long rest, your scent covers the ground in a 30-foot radius around you. When you enter the area or start your turn there, you can tell whether creatures whose identity you do not know or are hostile to you entered the area within the last 24 hours.

entries.name: Robust Regrowth
entries: While you cannot regenerate body parts without magical assistance, you can reattach one of your severed limbs or other body parts if you hold it to your body as part of a short rest.

In addition, you die after 1 minute if you are decapitated, rather than instantly, unless your head is reduced to 0 hit points or is destroyed. Your head has an Armor Class equal to 10 + your Constitution modifier, and hit points equal to your level. You cannot operate your body while decapitated, but you can speak.

entries.name: Stone in Sunlight
entries: When in natural sunlight, you can cast {@spell barkskin} at-will, without expending a spell slot and requiring no components. Instead of bark, matte stone covers your skin. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

How dare you bring this grotesque hybrid into my presence! I will conduct no further business with your 'party' till you remove it. Its foul nature violates the sanctity of my gardens. Stable it with the haugjotunen!
entries.by: Baroness Vinkova, Cloud Giant Ruler of Cirroway

entries: Beneath or outside the Ordning—the caste system of true giants—these radically-different groups share many physical traits. Some are hybrids, while others cluster together to survive in a world that has good reason to despise them.

In addition to their raw strength, the half-giants share a mutual hatred for one another. The nephilim possess a racial arrogance that rivals even the drow and consider themselves superior to all other races. Oni find troll and nephilim infants just as delicious as humanoid children. Half-trolls' and half-ogres' relationships with each other are the sole exception. Both find a grisly existence in roving warbands of orcs and goblins, or as brutish shock troops in hobgoblin armies. There, they enjoy the company of the few creatures that can sympathize with their circumstances.

The offspring of humanoids and one of the myriad troll subspecies, half-trolls live a life marked by constant shifts within their flesh. Half-trolls often suffer nausea, muscle cramps, and joint pains, yet are remarkably resilient in the face of hard labor and shrug off major injuries.

Their troll parent's plasticity of form allows their body to adapt to their surroundings much better than the other giant hybrids. They look no different from the other humanoids around them save for a hawkish nose, unusual height and strength, long limbs, or nevus-studded skin with a gray-green tinge.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: The nephilim strive to conquer and subject the races that succeeded them. They are usually evil, and tend toward law and order that oppresses the "lesser" races.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Your Charisma score increases by 1.

entries.name: Born Crusader
entries: Nephilim are fearsome fighters and raiders, trained for battle. You gain one fighting style of your choice.

entries.name: Language of the Gods
entries: You can speak, read, and write Celestial. As a bonus action, you can issue inspiring chants or terrible challenges in that mighty tongue. Choose a number of creatures up to your Charisma modifier (a minimum of 1) within 60 feet that can hear you. A target has advantage or disadvantage (your choice) on the first attack roll or ability check it makes before the start of your next turn.
You can give this oration a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

How dare you bring this grotesque hybrid into my presence! I will conduct no further business with your 'party' till you remove it. Its foul nature violates the sanctity of my gardens. Stable it with the haugjotunen!
entries.by: Baroness Vinkova, Cloud Giant Ruler of Cirroway

entries: Beneath or outside the Ordning—the caste system of true giants—these radically-different groups share many physical traits. Some are hybrids, while others cluster together to survive in a world that has good reason to despise them.

In addition to their raw strength, the half-giants share a mutual hatred for one another. The nephilim possess a racial arrogance that rivals even the drow and consider themselves superior to all other races. Oni find troll and nephilim infants just as delicious as humanoid children. Half-trolls' and half-ogres' relationships with each other are the sole exception. Both find a grisly existence in roving warbands of orcs and goblins, or as brutish shock troops in hobgoblin armies. There, they enjoy the company of the few creatures that can sympathize with their circumstances.

Born from unions between fallen angels and sinful mortals in eras past, these antediluvian warrior- poets ruled the world before the rise of elves, men, and dwarves. With a flawless, uncannily- beautiful aspect, their haunting-battle-hymns echo from the hidden warcamps and prehistoric ruins where they linger, longing for days they ruled the world.

Modern nephilim harbor a potent nostalgia for bygone days, when their bronze-armored warriors controlled fertile farmlands and dominated their inhabitants. After centuries of brutal rule, their humanoid subjects and their benevolent gods overthrew the nephilim. The nephilim's own shadowy pantheon remained aloof and distant as the first empire crumbled.

The nephilim now lurk in the jagged ruins of their civilization where ancient instinct and haunting folktales ward other races away. They terrorize isolated villages for food and tribute and carve out petty empires in pale imitations of their grandiose past. Nephilim use these meager tributes to perform bloody sacrifices to their primordial gods in the hopes that they will one day return and help them form a new world order.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Awkward, immense, and brutish, with attention spans usually limited by their appetites, ogrillon are outcasts wherever they go. Unwelcome among men and monsters, ogrillon rarely find solace among their own kind. They are usually chaotic, and are rarely good.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Your Constitution score increases by 1.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Orcish or Goblin, taught to you by your fellow monsters or your non-ogre parent.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Dense
entries: You are too dull-witted for magic that twists the senses to affect you. You have advantage on all Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws against spells and magical effects.

entries.name: Menacing
entries: You gain proficiency in Intimidation.

How dare you bring this grotesque hybrid into my presence! I will conduct no further business with your 'party' till you remove it. Its foul nature violates the sanctity of my gardens. Stable it with the haugjotunen!
entries.by: Baroness Vinkova, Cloud Giant Ruler of Cirroway

entries: Beneath or outside the Ordning—the caste system of true giants—these radically-different groups share many physical traits. Some are hybrids, while others cluster together to survive in a world that has good reason to despise them.

In addition to their raw strength, the half-giants share a mutual hatred for one another. The nephilim possess a racial arrogance that rivals even the drow and consider themselves superior to all other races. Oni find troll and nephilim infants just as delicious as humanoid children. Half-trolls' and half-ogres' relationships with each other are the sole exception. Both find a grisly existence in roving warbands of orcs and goblins, or as brutish shock troops in hobgoblin armies. There, they enjoy the company of the few creatures that can sympathize with their circumstances.

The results of unfortunate couplings between ogres and either humans, orcs, or larger goblinoids, ogrillon are diminished in both size and stupidity compared to pure-blooded ogres. More cunning ogrillon even exploit their ogre parents' reputation for ignorance to surprise enemies who underestimate them.

Human parents rarely survive an ogrillon's birth, so most ogrillon are raised in ogre gangs. Their higher intelligence and more complex social needs make life within rudimentary ogre society unsatisfying. Unfortunately, their fearsome appearance and violent upbringing make them incompatible with all but the most boorish and lawless humanoid societies.

Most ogrillon thus live solitary lives on the fringes of civilization. These lonely folk are quick to make friends, but their combination of great strength, social ignorance, and short temper often turn new friends into crushed enemies in seconds. Trainable and slightly less hot-tempered than their parents, ogrillon often find homes in the hobgoblin war machine—a cruel, short life as a glorified beast of burden.

entries.name: Size
entries: Animation myconids stand far smaller than growth myconids but stand over their specialized sporemaster brethren. You stand between 4 and 5 feet tall, and your size is Medium.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Your Charisma score increases by 1.

entries.name: Animating Spores
entries: Your spores give new life to the dead. You can use an action to touch the body of a Large or smaller creature and infuse it with spores. The creature must have had a challenge rating no higher than your level divided by 4.

The corpse rises as a {@book spore servant|mm|-1,spore servant template,0|}, which acts on your initiative and follows your telepathic orders. You can use this feature once, and must finish a long rest before you do so again. You can control a number of spore servants equal to half your proficiency bonus. If you create another, the oldest one dies.

A creature without flesh and blood, such as many constructs, elementals, oozes, plants, and undead, can't become spore servants. When you create a spore servant, alter the creature's characteristics as described on page 230 of the Monster Manual with these changes:

entries.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: The servant has disadvantage on ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws while in natural sunlight.

entries.name: Rotted Body
entries: The servant can't recover hit points.

entries.name: Size
entries: Towering over all myconids and most other humanoids, your height ranges from 8 to 10 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Your Strength score increases by 1.

entries.name: Mycelial Restoration
entries: Whenever you or another creature rolls a 1 on a die roll that restores your hit points, you can reroll the die. You must use the new roll.

You can also apply this feature to up to 10 creatures of your choice within 60 feet of you when they roll hit dice during a short rest. Once you use this feature on other creatures, you cannot do so again until you complete a long rest.

entries.name: Powerful Build
entries: You count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.

entries.name: Surprising Speed
entries: Your speed increases by 5 feet.

entries.name: Size
entries: Despite their importance, sporemasters are miniscule, sacrificing size for versatility. Your height ranges from 2 to 4 feet, and your size is Small.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Your Wisdom score increases by 1.

entries.name: Spores
entries: As you increase in level, you can wield more powerful spores in battle. If a spore's effects require a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier. You can use each type of spore once, and can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Distress Spores
entries: At 1st level, you can use your reaction when you take damage to telepathically alert all creatures of your choice within 300 feet of you. The message is wordless, but a creature that receives the alert knows it originated from you and knows the direction from its location to yours.

entries.name: Hallucination Spores
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can use an action to force a creature within 5 feet of you to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target is {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While poisoned in this way, the target is {@condition incapacitated} as it hallucinates.
The affected creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

entries.name: Pacifying Spores
entries: Starting at 5th level, you can use an action you can force a creature within 5 feet of you to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is stunned for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

subclass.name: Circle of the New Moon
subclassFeatures: Circle of the New Moon|Druid|PHB|New Moon|AbiDalzims|2

subclassFeature.name: Hellraiser
entries: A Hellraiser is a master of iron and fire, and an engineer endowed with mad genius. Streaked with grime and soaked with gasoline, these mechanics launch spells from the windows of volatile war machines, careening across the battlefield and weaving between obstacles. Their manic laughter echoes through the air as their haphazard vehicles—inspired by visions of the Nine Hells' oppressive armories—belch black smoke into the sky.
Though they prefer a mobile approach, these wild-eyed mechanics are equally dangerous in close quarters, with fiery magic that makes them unstable allies.

entries.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: When you adopt this specialization, you gain proficiency with land vehicles and smith's tools. If you already have these proficiencies, you gain proficiency with one other type of artisan's tools of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Hellraiser Spells
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you always have certain spells prepared after you reach particular levels in this class, as shown in the Hellraiser Spells table. These spells count as artificer spells for you, but they don't count against the number of artificer spells you prepare.

subclassFeature.name: War Machine
entries: At 3rd level, you can conjure a Hellish war machine on the ground in an unoccupied space or a space containing only willing creatures within 30 feet of you. Creatures that exceed the machine's capacity are harmlessly shunted to the nearest unoccupied space.
Once you create a war machine, you can't create that type of machine again until you finish a long rest. If you create a second, the first disappears.

A war machine is a magical object with a number of hit points equal to five times your artificer level. It is immune to poison and psychic damage and all conditions other than {@condition grappled}, {@condition restrained}, and {@condition petrified}, and resists fire damage. If it makes an ability check or saving throw, treat its ability scores as 10 ({@dice 1d20|+0}), but any saving throw it inflicts use your artificer spell save DC. If the {@spell mending} spell is cast on it, it regains {@dice 2d6} hit points. When destroyed, it disappears, and each creature inside is knocked {@condition prone}.

You are the only creature who can pilot your war machines. On your turn, you can drive a war machine you are riding on or piloting, or get out. Doing so (or getting on) costs an amount of movement equal to half your speed.

If an effect moves your war machine while you're on it, you must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or fall off the vehicle, landing prone in a space within 5 feet of it. If you're knocked prone while driving, you must make the same saving throw. The initiative of your vehicle matches yours. It moves only as you direct it, and it has only three action options: Dash, Disengage, and Dodge.

You can infuse your war machine as you would an item. The machine meets all prerequisites that don't have a cost. Piloting a machine is considered wearing, carrying, wielding the infused item, and the machine gains any bonuses to its statistics (such as AC) that you do. If the infusion requires a part the machine doesn't have, it creates one, such as a spigot for an {@item alchemy jug} or wings for a {@item cloak of the bat}.

entries.name: Spikecycle
entries: This two-wheeled Medium bike has incredible agility. It has an AC of 10 and a movement speed of 40 feet, and its spiked wheels grant it a climbing speed of 40 feet. Its incredible maneuverability grants it a running long jump of 20 feet, instead of the normal length gained by its Strength. When you would be subjected to an area of effect while driving the Spikecycle, you can use your reaction to drive up to half its speed (20 feet), potentially removing yourself from the affected area.

entries.name: War Wagon
entries: This Huge four-wheeled war truck has an AC of 15, a speed of 15 feet, and can fit four Medium creatures. A creature inside gains half cover and can use its action to fire one of its three turret-mounted {@item heavy crossbow|PHB|heavy crossbows}, which deal force damage instead of their normal type.

entries.name: Baneful Bunker
entries: This Gargantuan, treaded titan of industry has an AC of 19, a speed of 5 feet, and can fit eight Medium creatures. It grants full cover to all occupants, but has gunports which creatures inside can use to attack outside.

subclassFeature.name: Mobile Artillery
entries: Starting at 5th level, artificer spells you cast that originate from you can instead originate from any point on a war machine you are piloting, and you can choose to allow any spell targeting only you to also target your war machine, even if the spell can't ordinarily affect objects.
In addition, the first time in a round a creature riding your war machine hits a target with an attack, the target takes an additional {@dice 1d8} damage.

subclassFeature.name: Nitrous
entries: Starting at 9th level, after you cast an {@filter artificer spell of 1st level or higher|spells|level=!0|class=artificer}, the speed of a war machine you are piloting doubles until the end of the current turn.

subclassFeature.name: Manic Mechanic
entries: At 15th level, you master recklessly efficient engineering. You can conjure a second war machine, which other creatures can pilot if you allow. This machine is always a spikecycle.

Additionally, when a war machine enters the space of a creature that is one size larger than it or smaller, the creature must succeed on a Strength or Dexterity saving throw (its choice) or be knocked prone. Your war machines can move through prone creatures' spaces without provoking opportunity attacks or expending additional movement.

As an action, or as a reaction when a war machine you can see is reduced to 0 hit points, you can make it explode. All creatures and objects inside or within 60 feet of the machine must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking {@dice 8d6} fire damage and {@dice 8d6} piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much on a success. You can't summon that model war machine again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Vector
entries: Vectors engineer horrors on a microscopic scale. Able to peer into the miniscule worlds that flourish on every surface, these medically-minded maniacs brew lethal diseases with the same equipment others use to brew potions. Vectors use the infected as a conduit to transmit their harmful spells across vast distances, building a network ready to explode into a pandemic at a moment's notice.

Many Vectors savor the power they wield over others, and select symptoms designed to facilitate misery. The most powerful Vectors manifest themselves in the fever dreams of the infected and delight in the opportunity to torment the weak and helpless.

entries.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: When you adopt this specialization, you gain proficiency in your choice of {@item alchemist's supplies|phb} or {@item herbalism kit|phb|herbalism kits}. If you already have these proficiencies, you gain proficiency with one other type of artisan's tools of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Vector Spells
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you always have certain spells prepared after you reach particular levels in this class, as shown in the Vector Spells table. These spells count as artificer spells for you, but they don't count against the number of artificer spells you prepare.

entries.caption: Vector Spells
rows: {@spell ray of sickness}, {@spell detect poison and disease}

subclassFeature.name: Latent Infection
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can coat yourself with a magical pathogen, which spreads harmlessly to any creature of your choice that you damage with an artificer spell or weapon attack, that you touch, or that ends its turn within 5 feet of you. The disease spreads from that creature to others in the same way. If you choose, infected creatures suffer a mild, ultimately harmless illness until you activate their symptoms. A creature is infected with the harmless disease for a number of days equal to twice your artificer level, after which the illness fades.

When you see a creature, you know if it's infected. If you touch an infected creature (making a melee spell attack against an unwilling creature as an action), you can cause the disease to erupt with an excruciating symptom. Roll on the Symptoms table to determine which effect manifests. Once you use this feature on a creature, you can't use it on that creature again until you finish a long rest or you expend a spell slot. The symptoms last for 1 minute unless otherwise noted in the disease, after which the flare-up ends and the asymptomatic disease continues.

You can use your action to touch a creature and remove the disease. Any disease you create, through this feature or by other means, ignores immunity to disease (including for creatures such as undead and constructs which do not live), but can be removed by the {@spell lesser restoration} spell or similar magic.

entries.caption: Symptoms
rows: Agony. Any attack roll that exceeds the target's AC by 5 or more is a critical hit.
Delirium. The target has disadvantage on saving throws against illusions and effects that would {@condition charmed|PHB|charm} it, and loses the ability to understand any language.
Malaise. The target's speed is halved, and it cannot make more than one attack roll or target more than one creature with an effect on its turn.
Pustules. Once per turn when the target is hit by an attack, it and each creature within 15 feet of it take acid damage equal to your Intelligence modifier.
Rupture. When the target is hit by an attack, it has disadvantage on the first Constitution check or saving throw it makes before the start of its next turn.
Spasms. At the end of its turn, the target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or drop whatever it is holding and fall {@condition prone}.
Wasting. The target deals halved damage with weapon attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Pathogenic Magic
entries: At 5th level, your affinity for filth seeps into your spells. Artificer spells you cast that deal necrotic, poison, or psychic damage deal one additional damage die to creatures affected by your disease.

subclassFeature.name: Doctor a Plague
entries: Starting at 9th level, you can cause your diseases to mutate in bizarre and unpredictable ways. When you activate a disease with your Latent Infection feature, you can roll twice and inflict both effects, rerolling any duplicates.

subclassFeature.name: Rage Virus
entries: Starting at 15th level, you can use an action to choose one or more creatures that you know are infected to suffer the below effects. If a target is unwilling, it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your artificer spell save DC to avoid it.

items: The target gains the benefits (and none of the drawbacks) of the {@spell haste} spell.

The target loses the ability to distinguish friend from foe, and treats any creature it sees as an enemy. When it would choose a target of an attack or other harmful ability, it does so randomly from targets within the ability's reach or range. The target will not harm other creatures suffering these effects.
The target has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks that aren't silvered, and its Armor Class increases to 18 if it is lower.

If the target is reduced to 0 hit points, it makes a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is from a critical hit. On a success, the target drops to 1 hit point instead.

entries: This rage lasts for 1 minute. After you successfully cause a number of creatures equal to your Intelligence modifier to enter this rage, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Addict
entries: The rage of desperation is powerful. Poor life choices or miserable circumstances often push unwilling barbarians down the Path of the Addict, who suffer in their struggle to break free of their reliance on potent chemical substances.

Many of these barbarians use the chemical rush that accompanies ingestion to fuel their rages. Their drugs of choice further enhance their prowess, from powerful hallucinogens that give new insight into reality, opiates that inure them to deadly wounds, or frenzied bursts of impossible energy.

subclassFeature.name: Chemical Fury
entries: When you choose this path at 3rd level, the rush of chemical euphoria you experience while raging grants you additional benefits based on your drug of choice until your rage ends. When you finish a long rest, you can choose any two drugs from the list below. When you rage, you gain the benefits of one of your choices.

entries.name: Alcohol
entries: The liquid courage coursing through your veins makes you succeed through dumb luck. You can't be {@condition frightened}, and once per rage when you roll a die with advantage or disadvantage, you can choose to roll a third die after seeing the results and choose any of the three results.

entries.name: Cannabis
entries: The overbearing serenity that seeps into your brain is contagious. After you regain hit points, you can cause yourself and another creature within 10 feet of you to regain hit points equal to half the number you regained. You can't do so again until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Crystal
entries: The reckless mania that overstimulates your body makes you dangerous and unpredictable. You gain two reactions on your turn, rather than one, and when you take damage, you can use a reaction to make a weapon attack against the attacker.

entries.name: Frenzy Ash
entries: The clarity and hyperactive focus that overstimulates your senses increase your speed by 10 feet and grants you a second bonus action on each of your turns. You can use these bonus actions to take the Dash or Disengage actions in addition to any other use for your bonus actions.

entries.name: Mushrooms
