entries: Your altered perception of reality creates mystifying illusions in a 10-foot sphere around you. When a creature enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, you can use your reaction to force it to move up to half its speed in a direction of your choice without provoking opportunity attacks, expending movement as normal.

entries.name: Snakebite
entries: The numbing chemicals in your blood make you inured to pain. You can use a bonus action to expend a number of hit dice up to your rage bonus damage and restore hit points as you would during a short rest. If you are damaged by a critical hit, you can use your reaction to turn it into a normal hit.

subclassFeature.name: Highs and Lows
entries: Starting at 6th level, you draw comfort from the rush you feel when a foreign substance enters your body. When you drink a potion, you regain hit points equal to your Constitution score.
You also gain proficiency in your choice of {@item alchemist's supplies|phb} or {@item poisoner's kit|phb|poisoner's kits}.

subclassFeature.name: Consuming Cravings
entries: At 10th level, your desperation for a fix bends reality. If a creature within 15 feet of you would take acid or poison damage or suffer the effects of a poison, you can choose to suffer those effects instead. If an area of effect, such as the {@spell cloudkill} or {@spell stinking cloud} spells, would affect multiple creatures in this radius, you can protect each one with the same reaction. You suffer the effect, such as Constitution saving throws against taking damage, once for every creature you protect.
You can also learn the {@spell detect poison and disease} spell, which you can cast as a ritual. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

subclassFeature.name: Polydrug Abuse
entries: Also at 14th level, you gain the benefits of both choices you select with your Chemical Fury feature when you rage.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Meltdown
entries: Many barbarians manifest their rage as a vicious tantrum, and a warrior mid-fit is a sight to behold. The blood of the barbarians who walk the Path of the Meltdown literally boils with anger until the acrid fluid ruptures their skin and sends it gushing forth. Bitter hatred and curdled malice liquefy their flesh and form seams in their sloughing skin, and they weep black ichor as their putrid emotions drain from their pliable skulls.

subclassFeature.name: Lash Out
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn to channel your visceral fury into an acrid lash. You become proficient in unarmed strikes and when you take the Attack action while raging, you can make an unarmed strike against a target within 30 feet of you. If you're able to make multiple attacks with the Attack action, this attack replaces one of them. This attack ignores bonuses to AC granted by shields and features that parry or deflect attacks.
On a hit, the target takes {@dice 2d6} acid damage and is pulled a number of feet toward you equal to 5 × your rage bonus damage.
You also have resistance to acid damage, and are immune to it while raging.

subclassFeature.name: Amorphous
entries: Also at 3rd level, your body and brain become as fluid and unstable as your racing thoughts. While raging, you have advantage on ability checks and saving throws to avoid being {@condition restrained}, can move through spaces as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing, and your speed is not reduced when you move through another creature's space.

Finally, if you are not wielding a weapon, you can morph your hand or hands into one of the {@filter melee weapons|items|source=phb|type=melee weapon;!treasure (gemstone);!treasure (art object);!futuristic;!renaissance;!treasure (coinage);!modern} described on page 149 of the Player's Handbook. You wield the weapon as normal, which has no special properties despite being made from your body. If the weapon leaves your grasp, it is destroyed instantly.

subclassFeature.name: Ready to Blow
entries: At 6th level, toxins erupt from your body like a geyser. When you enter a rage, creatures of your choice within 30 feet of you take acid damage equal to your rage bonus damage. Each target's space, as well as yours, is filled with a 1-inch-deep pool of acid that evaporates after 1 minute. When a creature enters this space for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there, it takes acid damage equal to your rage bonus damage.

When you use this feature, any poisons, diseases, {@condition charmed} effects, and effects that control your mind such as the {@spell dominate person} spell or a {@creature ghost|mm|ghost's} Possession feature end.

subclassFeature.name: Calm Troubled Waters
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can use a bonus action to settle your racing thoughts and expand your senses. You can use a bonus action to gain {@sense tremorsense|mm} with a range of 60 feet for 10 minutes, but you must be immersed in or touching liquid to use it, and can only sense creatures within that liquid.
You can use this feature a number of times per long rest equal to your Constitution modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Temper Tempest
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can use your reaction when struck by a critical hit to make one unarmed strike against any creatures within 120 feet of you. Each attack deals an extra {@dice 1d6} acid damage, and you gain temporary hit points equal to the acid damage dealt by one attack you choose. You then teleport to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of one target you choose.
You can also use this ability as an action. Once you do so, you can't do so again until your next rage.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Zombie
entries: Even death cannot stop some barbarians. Barbarians of the Path of the Zombie crossed over, and rose again to take up their old arms and continue the fight. These warriors emanate an uncanny aura that freezes the blood of all who suffer their vitality-sapping attacks, and their grotesque, festering wounds remind their enemies of the fate that awaits them.

subclassFeature.name: Hateful Touch
entries: Starting when you choose this path at 3rd level, you can channel the energies that animate you into your weapon strikes. The first creature you hit with a weapon attack on your turn while raging takes necrotic damage equal to {@dice 1d6} + half your barbarian level.

subclassFeature.name: Living Corpse
entries: At 3rd level, your body is marked for endless battle. If a spell, such as {@spell raise dead} or {@spell animate dead}, would restore you to life or raise you as an undead, the caster doesn't need material components to cast the spell on you. You do not fall under the caster's control when reanimated as an undead, and you retain your creature type.

subclassFeature.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: Starting at 6th level, your undead flesh absorbs excruciating injuries. If you fail a saving throw while raging, you can reroll it. You must use the new roll. You can use this ability once per rage.

subclassFeature.name: Unliving Vigor
entries: At 10th level, you can spread your unholy vitality to others with a moan infused with negative energy. Up to ten creatures of your choice within 60 feet of you that can hear you gain advantage on attack rolls and saving throws until the start of your next turn.
You can use this feature once per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Rage Beyond Death
entries: Beginning at 14th level, the necromancy that fuels your body allows you to shrug off fatal blows. While you're raging, having 0 hit points doesn't knock you unconscious. You still must make death saving throws, and you suffer the normal effects of taking damage while at 0 hit points. If you would die due to failed death saving throws, you don't die until your rage ends, and you die then only if you still have 0 hit points.

entries.name: Sound Familiar?
entries: The Path of the Zombie uses the mechanics of the Path of the Zealot. AAA reprints it with new flavor text (and one change) to demonstrate ways to use existing mechanics to create villainous characters. Similarly, Ancestral Guardian barbarians can be possessed by demons, paladins of the Oath of the Watchers can become xenophobic crusaders, and Gloom Stalkers can become bestial predators.

subclassFeature.name: Awe Domain
entries: Divine might invokes terror and reverence in equal measure. Celestials, mere shadows of the gods, must remind the creatures they visit to feel no fear in the face of their majesty, even as existential terror grips their audience. Clerics of this domain act as an open conduit for the sheer might of their gods, whose power far exceeds their breathtaking servants. The powers of this domain astonish and terrify both sinners and the devout.

Most gods can grant this domain to their followers when in short temper, and divine rulers like Zeus, Odin, El Shaddai, and Marduk favor it. Alternatively, these clerics represent divine organizations like the Circle of Greater Powers, Mount Olympus, or the Aesir, instead of one god.

subclassFeature.name: Domain Spells
entries: You gain domain spells at the cleric levels listed in the Awe Domain Spells table. See the Divine Domain class feature for how domain spells work.

subclassFeature.name: Holy Fire
entries: When you choose this domain at 1st level, you learn the {@spell sacred flame} cantrip, which doesn't count against the number of cleric cantrips you know. If you roll an 8 on a {@dice d8} when rolling damage for this spell, you can roll another {@dice d8} and add it to the damage, including whenever you roll an 8 on the additional die.

subclassFeature.name: Avatar of Authority
entries: Also at 1st level, when you cast a cleric spell that affects an area, you can expand that area by a number of feet equal to 5 × the level of the slot used to cast the spell. The spell must either be one of your domain spells or have an Instantaneous duration. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier, and can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Reverent Dread
entries: Starting at 2nd level, your Channel Divinity reveals the overwhelming power of your god. As a bonus action, you can present your holy symbol and force a number of creatures within 120 feet of you equal to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of 1) to make a Wisdom saving throw. A target must be able to see or hear you. On a failed save, a target is {@condition restrained} in place and cannot move for 1 minute, though flying creatures remain aloft.
Each target repeats its saving throw every time it takes damage, and creatures immune to being {@condition frightened} have advantage on saving throws against this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Holiest of Holies
entries: At 6th level, when you cast a spell that deals damage, you can change its damage type to radiant. When you roll radiant damage, you can reroll a number of dice up to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of 1) and use the higher result. You can reroll radiant damage dice once per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: Starting at 8th level, you add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any cleric cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: The Ten Plagues
entries: Starting at 17th level, your god answers your prayers with a fury that shakes the world.

You can use an action to expend a 9th-level spell slot and cast one of the spells below, requiring no somatic or material components. The spell's range increases to sight, and if the spell creates an area of effect, each of the area's dimensions increases to 1 mile if they are not already larger.
Each creature of your choice affected by the spell makes a Wisdom saving throw against your Reverent Dread Channel Divinity, which does not expend a use of your Channel Divinity.

Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Once you cast one of the listed spells, you can't cast it with this feature again until you cast every other spell on the list in the same way. You can still use your cleric spellcasting, spellcasting from another class feature, a magic item, or another source of powerful magic to cast these spells, which don't count against the number of cleric spells you have prepared.

subclassFeature.name: Wealth Domain
entries: Greed is a sin inherent to nearly all mortal creatures. A select few dedicate their lives to overcoming this desire, but most work to accumulate as many possessions as possible. Whether at the expense of others or not, mortals who seek affluence pray to the gods of wealth to build their fortunes.

Many of these gods, such as the dwarf-god Abbathor and archdevil Mammon, personify the evils of mortal greed. Dragon gods like Tiamat and Asilabor stoop to mortal vice and hoard wealth for themselves as they encourage their followers to do the same. However, neutral or even good gods of commerce such as Hermes, Xerbo, Kol Korran, Zilchus, and Waukeen, also grant power over wealth. Lastly, gods of precious metals like Pluto and Garl Glittergold count wealth among their many domains.

subclassFeature.name: Domain Spells
entries: You gain domain spells at the cleric levels listed in the Wealth Domain Spells table. See the Divine Domain class feature for how domain spells work.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Cantrip
entries: You learn the {@spell friends} cantrip, which doesn't count against the number of cleric cantrips you know. If a target financially profited from or otherwise gained a genuine and lasting benefit from its interactions with you while under the spell's influence, it is not aware that you used magic to influence its mood.

subclassFeature.name: Vestment Investment
entries: At 1st level, you gain the generous opulence of the gods of fortune. Whenever you would make an ability check using the Deception, Performance, or Persuasion skills, you can use your Wisdom modifier instead of your Charisma modifier.

In addition, your grandeur engenders gratitude. When you give a willing creature a gift with a monetary value, you can force the target to make a Wisdom saving throw against your cleric spell save DC. On a failure, the target is {@condition charmed} by you for a number of minutes equal to the value of the gift in gold pieces, to a maximum of 1 week. On a success, the target is immune to this feature for 1 week.

You can charm a number of targets equal to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of 1) with this feature. If you charm a new target, you choose an existing charm to end. If you or your allies attack the target, cheat it, or otherwise cause it harm, then the charm automatically ends.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Vaunted Vault
entries: At 2nd level, you can use your action and expend a use of your Channel Divinity to reach inside a demiplane maintained by your god to store offerings and treasures. For the next 10 minutes, you can use your bonus action to deposit or remove one item from the vault, which appears on your person. The vault can hold up to a number of pounds equal to your cleric level × 50.
When you remove coins or treasure from the vault, you can convert it into another currency, such as another type of coin, small bones, rare shells, colored beads, or scraps of paper.

subclassFeature.name: Good as Gold
entries: At 6th level, you can use a bonus action to open your eyes to those who would dare deceive you. Until the start of your next turn, you know if a creature or object you see has been shapechanged, has its appearance hidden by an illusion, or is a fake item, such as a {@item potion of poison}, a {@filter cursed magic item|items|miscellaneous=cursed;!reprinted}, or a {@item counterfeit art object|AbiDalzims}. You do not know the nature of the effect, only that it exists.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: Starting at 8th level, you add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any cleric cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Mandatory Donation
entries: At 17th level, you can demand offerings to your god even from those unwilling to give. When a creature you can see within 30 feet of you is targeted by a spell, you can use your reaction to make a Wisdom check with a DC equal to 10 + the spell's level. On a success, you become a target of the spell instead.
Spells that target areas of effect, such as the {@spell fireball} spell, can't be stolen in this way.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Gale
entries: Druids of the Circle of the Gale adore the elemental chaos of hurricanes and tornadoes. These druids tend to form nomadic, tight-knit groups, which wander the world in search of the next devastating storm. The strongest members even create their own storm cells, and the cults that follow them revel in the mass destruction that results.

Many of these druids live near the coast, on islands, or even on ships, but some conjure tornadoes over plains to slaughter nomadic armies or destroy prairie cities. Others form secretive cells in urban areas, and use summer thunderstorms and winter blizzards as opportunities to surreptitiously wreak havoc.

subclassFeature.name: Storm Cell
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use a bonus action to expend a use of your Wild Shape feature to whip the atmosphere in a 10-foot-radius, 30-foot-high cylinder centered on you into a frenzied cyclone. The winds go around corners, and the windstorm lasts for 1 minute or until you fall unconscious or end it (no action required).

The area is considered stormy conditions and strong wind for spells and other effects that interact with such conditions, such as strong winds imposing disadvantage on ranged attack rolls. You ignore any negative effects of your Storm Cell.

You know the location of any creature within the area and can cast spells targeting any creature within the area, even those you can't see or that are behind cover. The storm does not change the range of spells you cast.

When a ranged attack or line spell enters your Storm Cell or originates from a point within it, you can use your reaction to blow it in a new direction, potentially changing its target. Make a Wisdom check. The DC equals the attack roll or 10 + the line spell's level. On a success, choose a new target for the attack, using the check's total as the spell attack roll. If you targeted a line spell, it emanates from a point within the Storm Cell in a direction of your choice for the remainder of its length.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Your connection to the howling tempest grants you the ability to access certain spells. At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to the spells listed for that level in the Circle of the Gale Spells table. Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

entries.caption: Circle of the Gale Spells
rows: {@spell cloud of daggers}, {@spell gust of wind}

subclassFeature.name: Eye of the Hurricane
entries: At 6th level, you can exclude a 10-foot-radius sphere from the area of any druid spell you cast or effect you redirect with your Storm Cell feature.
You also ignore the effects of bad weather, including strong wind, heavy precipitation, and extreme heat or cold.

subclassFeature.name: Windscar
entries: Beginning at 10th level, you can tear down the trappings of civilization with nothing more than moving air. At the start of your turn, you can cause structures and objects not being worn or carried within your Storm Cell or within the area of a spell you cast that creates wind take slashing damage equal to twice your druid level. If the spell's duration is Instantaneous, you instead cause this damage when you cast the spell.
You also have resistance to lightning and thunder damage.

subclassFeature.name: Apocalypse Squall
entries: Starting at 14th level, the atmosphere bends to your whim. You always have the {@spell control weather} spell prepared, which does not count against your number of druid spells prepared. You can cast {@spell control weather} once per long rest without expending a spell slot.
When you cast {@spell control weather}, it changes as described below:

items: The spell has a casting time of 1 action.
Any changes to weather condition happen instantaneously, even across multiple stages.
The spell does not require concentration and does not end if you go indoors. You can still end the spell at any time, no action required.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the New Moon
entries: No druid chooses to join the Circle of the New Moon. These outcasts, degenerates, and heretics banished from the Circle of the Moon form their fetters through chance meetings and correspondences between associates of associates.

Through these tenuous connections, they share new and terrible shapeshifting techniques. Druids of this circle make a twisted mockery of nature's perfection as they use their Wild Shape, when they combine the powers of beasts that could never, and should never, be bred together. Many of these druids lose themselves to taboo thrills and live out their days as unidentifiable masses of body parts, consumed by an insatiable lust for new flesh.

subclassFeature.name: Twisted Wild Shape
entries: When you choose this circle at 2nd level, you gain the ability to use your Wild Shape on your turn as a bonus action, rather than an action.

Starting at 4th level in this class, you can transform into a beast with a challenge rating as high as your druid level divided by 4. The other limitations in the Beast Shapes table still apply to you.

entries.caption: Circle of the New Moon Forms

entries: When you transform, you can take one feature or trait from a beast you know (or from a beast form you are familiar with) and apply it to the different beast that you transform into. Your form's appearance changes to reflect any anatomy needed to grant these traits, along with other changes that solely affect your appearance as determined by you and the Dungeon Master.

For example, you can transform into a boar, and grant it a giant spider's spider climb trait. Rather than four hooved legs, eight massive spider legs support the boar's body; which could also have eight bulging eyes in its porcine face.
Finally, you can speak normally anytime your shape is changed, such as through your Wild Shape feature or the {@spell polymorph} spell, regardless of the form's anatomy.

subclassFeature.name: Blighted Touch
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can deal acid or poison damage when you make an attack with a natural weapon.

subclassFeature.name: Carrion Evolution
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can use a bonus action while in beast form to touch the corpse of any beast, humanoid, or monstrosity and destroy it instantly, adding one of the creature's traits to your beast form until the transformation ends.

You cannot target a corpse that (when alive) had a challenge rating equal or higher than twice your Twisted Wild Shape's maximum challenge rating, and cannot grant the ability to cast spells, learn spellcasting, gain additional prepared spells, regain expended spell slots, or gain hit dice of a higher level.

Each time you gain a new trait with this feature, the time you can spend in your current beast shape increases by 1 hour. Features of the same name but with different effects (such as a Keen Senses trait that grants advantage on checks made to hear, and another that enhances hearing and smell) do not extend your beast form's duration.
You can also use this feature when you kill a creature with a melee attack, without using a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Violate Natural Law
entries: At 14th level, you can use your Twisted Wild Shape feature to transform into monstrosities and humanoids as you would beasts, and add traits from a monstrosity, beast or humanoid form you know to any of your wild shapes. You can also use your Carrion Evolution in this form, as normal.

As in Carrion Evolution, you cannot gain or apply spellcasting or any spellcasting-related features. You can adopt the appearance of specific individuals, but your chosen statistics cannot exceed the challenge rating appropriate for your level.

subclassFeature.name: Executioner
entries: Tyrants and kings can slaughter whoever they want. But a public execution can subdue a rebellion with a single death, which saves them time and effort. When despots need a garish death with all the ceremony that accompanies it, they call upon an Executioner.

These inexorable warriors excel in delivering finishing blows to weakened foes, and cut through the weak or helpless without a second thought. Their unnerving presence and grim efficiency terrifies enemy and ally alike. Some executioners are no longer human at all, but undead incarnations of vengeance who terrorize the innocent or punish the wicked.

subclassFeature.name: Guillotine Cut
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you master killing blows against the cowering and helpless.
You have advantage on attack rolls against {@condition frightened} creatures.

When you make a melee weapon attack against a {@condition frightened}, {@condition paralyzed}, {@condition prone}, or {@condition restrained} creature and have advantage on the attack roll, you can choose to roll normally. If the attack hits, you deal the maximum possible damage on the weapon's damage dice, rather than rolling.
You can also use your bonus action to shove a creature {@condition prone} thrice per short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Death's Gaze
entries: Also at 3rd level, the look in your eyes after a kill makes the blood run cold.

Once on your turn when you reduce a creature with a Challenge Rating of {@filter 1 or higher|bestiary|Challenge Rating=[&1;&—]} to 0 hit points, you can choose a hostile creature within 60 feet of you that can see you and stare at it, marking it for death.

The marked target and each creature within 10 feet of it must make a Wisdom saving throw with a DC equal to the damage taken by the creature you killed. A creature that fails its saving throw is {@condition frightened} of you until the end of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Executioner's Hood
entries: Starting at 7th level, you become a faceless representation of death when you conceal your identity. So long as your face is concealed—such as with a helmet, hood, or mask—you have advantage on Charisma (Intimidation) checks.
Illusions that change your appearance but don't cover your new appearance's head do not grant this advantage.
You also gain proficiency in {@item torturer's implements|AbiDalzims}.

subclassFeature.name: Part the Crowd
entries: At 10th level your grim turn toward your next target after a kill makes fearful bystanders instinctively step aside.
A target that fails its save against your Death's Gaze feature becomes {@condition frightened} of the marked creature, as well as you. The marked creature is not {@condition frightened} of itself.

When a {@condition frightened} creature starts its turn, it must move 10 feet away from the marked target. It will only move as long as it can do so safely (such as without moving into a hazardous area or provoking opportunity attacks).

subclassFeature.name: Ominous Advance
entries: Starting at 15th level, you can use your reaction when a creature you see becomes {@condition frightened}, {@condition prone}, or {@condition restrained} to move up to your speed toward it.
If you end this movement within reach of the creature, you can make one melee weapon attack against it.

subclassFeature.name: Killing Spree
entries: Starting at 18th level, you can choose to become impossible to escape when you take the Attack action, lasting until the end of your turn.

Before you make a melee attack, you can teleport to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of a creature that you can see or hear within 60 feet of you that is {@condition frightened}, {@condition prone}, or {@condition restrained}.
If a target survives an attack you make against it in this state, it is {@condition paralyzed} until the end of your turn.
You can use this feature once, and must complete a short or long rest before you do so again.

subclassFeature.name: Mercenary
entries: The archetypal Mercenary has no interest in fame, power, or glorious causes. A Mercenary fights for anyone willing to pay. Accustomed to long hours, rough treatment, pitiful equipment, and unreliable wages, mercenaries tend to be embittered by their experiences. Most struggle to raise their station, and will never achieve more than the dirty, short life of an expendable soldier.

This archetype defies time and place; mercenaries have existed since time immemorial. It includes ninja, ronin, landsknechts, varangians, purbiya, medjays, and wandering gunslingers, as well as employees of modern private military companies. Forced to fight without magical prowess or quality gear, all Mercenaries are resourceful students of strategy and dirty tricks, willing to use any tactic to get the job done.

subclassFeature.name: Scrapper
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level you master methods of adjusting your equipment, position, and movement to your advantage.
When you would move, you can expend all your movement to move 5 feet without provoking opportunity attacks.
In addition, you do not need to use the object interaction you receive as part of your turn to draw or sheathe your weapons, and you gain two object interactions on your turn (up to two).
Finally, you can sacrifice your equipment's integrity to end a fight before you can come to harm:

items: When you take damage, you can use your armor to gain resistance to one of the damage types indicated by the triggering attack, reducing the damage taken from that attack.
When you land a hit with a weapon you are proficient in, you and your fighter level to the damage roll.

entries: You can use each of these options once per turn.

When you use one of these options, the affected weapon or armor takes a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to its Armor Class or attack and damage rolls. If this penalty drops to -5, the object is destroyed. Ranged attacks after all ammunition is consumed and the weapon, and the ammunition is destroyed after one use.

Magical items and items made of supernatural materials such as adamantine or mithral are not broken. Instead, once these items reach a -5 penalty, they maintain that penalty, lose any magical properties, and cannot be used to activate its feature. When you finish a long rest, the penalty on these items decreases by 1. If you are proficient with a set of tools that corresponds to a damaged piece of nonmagical equipment, you can spend an hour as part of a short or long rest to reduce its penalty by 1.

subclassFeature.name: Solo Operative
entries: Starting at 7th level, you become a master of adventuring in harsh conditions with limited resources. You require half as much food and water to survive and are immune to all diseases. You automatically succeed on all Wisdom (Medicine) checks to stabilize dying creatures and Small or smaller creatures, including most coins, gems, and art objects only count half their weight against your carrying capacity.

subclassFeature.name: Stall Tactics
entries: At 10th level, you can reposition to increase your chances of survival. When an enemy misses you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to move 5 feet without provoking attacks of opportunity when a hostile creature misses you with a melee attack.
When you do so, you can use your reaction to make one weapon attack against the attacker or attempt to grapple or shove it. You choose whether you do so before or after you move.

subclassFeature.name: Tactical Retreat
entries: Starting at 15th level, you can use the rush of energy from your Second Wind feature to move up to your speed without provoking opportunity attacks after you regain hit points.
You have advantage on the next weapon attack you make before the end of your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Critical Moment
entries: Beginning at 18th level, you choose the point in initiative in which you take your turn each round at any point during the round, including during another creature's turn. You cannot take two turns in a row, such as going last in one round and first in the round immediately after.

subclassFeature.name: Mercenary Specialty
entries: No one, not even your fellow mercenaries, cares why you fight. Only your skills differentiate you from your peers. Consider how you developed your talents as a Mercenary before you became an adventurer, and the role you occupied within a larger organization (if you belonged to one). Roll on the Mercenary Specialties table or choose a result based on your chosen Fighting Style to determine your former duties.

subclassFeature.name: Way of Hate
entries: Monks of the Way of Hate ignore their schools' teachings about the dispassionate use of violence as a last resort, but absorb every bit of anatomical education. These cruel outcasts from more traditional schools of martial arts exploit their knowledge of the body's weaknesses and the flow of ki to fight with cruel precision and vicious delight.

When they fight, these sadistic monks inflict as much pain as possible before their inevitable victory. Their unfortunate targets limp away with broken bones and shattered pride—if they survive the encounter at all.

subclassFeature.name: Eye for Weakness
entries: When you choose this tradition at 3rd level, you can analyze enemy pressure points to identify their most valuable assets. If you spend at least 1 minute observing or interacting with another creature outside combat, the DM chooses a number of the target's features or traits equal to your Wisdom modifier, and shares their names with you.

You can also learn this information as a bonus action if you spend 1 ki point and succeed on a contested Wisdom (Insight) check against the target's Charisma (Deception) check. You must be able to see the target in order to use this feature, and creatures that cannot be sensed through magical means (such as the {@spell nondetection} spell) are immune to this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Ki Disruption
entries: Also at 3rd level, your precise strikes to nerves and chakra painfully sever your victims' access to their innate abilities. Once on your turn when you hit with an unarmed strike, you can spend 2 ki points to choose one of your target's features or traits, such as an {@creature earth elemental|mm|earth elemental's} Earth Glide, an {@creature orc war chief|mm|orc war chief's} Gruumsh's Fury, or a {@creature lich|mm|lich's} ability to cast the {@spell disintegrate} spell.
The target can't use that feature until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: System Shock
entries: At 6th level, your Stunning Strikes deal an additional {@dice 1d6} psychic or necrotic damage (your choice), as do your attacks against a creature suffering from your Ki Disruption. You can deal this damage once per turn, and deal the additional damage even if the target succeeds on its saving throw against being {@condition stunned}.

subclassFeature.name: Vicious Intellect
entries: Also at 6th level, you gain proficiency in your choice of Medicine or {@item torturer's implements|AbiDalzims}.

subclassFeature.name: Below the Belt
entries: At 11th level, you combine your prowess with cruel opportunism. Once per turn when you attack a creature that is suffering at least one condition or suffering from your Ki Disruption, or force it to make a saving throw, you can add a roll of your Martial Arts die to the attack or subtract it from the saving throw.

subclassFeature.name: Maximize Harm
entries: Starting at 17th level, you give in to the temptation to brutalize helpless opponents. When you spend ki points to stun a creature or disrupt its ki, you can spend 2 additional ki points to deal doubled damage to it until the end of your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Way of Transcendence
entries: Monks seek spiritual and physical perfection, and monks of the Way of Transcendence are no different. Unfortunately, they recognize their superior prowess, which makes them haughty and arrogant. Over time, ambition corrupts their determination.

As they reach ever-greater heights, these conceited monks believe themselves the rightful rulers of all things. They needed to work to ascend to a higher plane rather than receiving such gifts when created, and thus have the right to rule the universe. Monks of the Way of Transcendence work to achieve enlightenment for one purpose: to find and supplant a god.

subclassFeature.name: Enlightened Vision
entries: When you choose this tradition at 3rd level, you can open a third eye in the center of your forehead when you roll initiative, attuning your senses to the immortal planes. This eye manifests as a physical eye, a tattoo or brand, a blazing sigil, or another appearance you choose.

When the eye opens, each creature you choose in a 15-foot cone that can see you must make a Wisdom saving throw against your ki save DC, falling {@condition prone} or becoming {@condition frightened} (your choice) on a failed save. This cone increases to 30 feet at 11th level in this class.

The eye is open for 1 minute, and can't be shut again until that minute ends. While it is open, you can see the true form of shapechangers and see through illusions. You can also predict the movements of mighty creatures; if you succeed on a saving throw to take half damage inflicted by a creature with Legendary Actions or the Legendary Resistance feature, you instead take no damage on a success.

subclassFeature.name: Thwart Legend
entries: Starting at 6th level, each hit with an attack granted by your Flurry of Blows feature prevents your target from regaining one reaction or legendary action at the start of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Walker in the Spirit Realm
entries: At 11th level, your body and soul begin to shift between planes. You can use a bonus action to spend 3 ki points and make yourself incorporeal until the end of your turn, granting you the following benefits:

items: Your unarmed strikes deal necrotic, radiant, or psychic damage (your choice).

You resist bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage and are immune to radiant damage. When you would take radiant damage, you gain temporary hit points equal to half the damage you would have taken instead.

You can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. If you end your turn inside an object or creature, you take {@dice 2d10} force damage and are shunted to the nearest unoccupied space. This damage can't be reduced or avoided in any way.

subclassFeature.name: Obliterate Soul
entries: At 17th level, you speak with the authority of the god you intend to supplant. The turn after your third eye opens, you can use an action to spend at least 5 ki and cast {@spell divine word}, excluding creatures you choose. If you use 6 or more ki, the hit point thresholds {@spell divine word} affects increase by 10 for every ki point spent above 5th.
For example, if you spend 7 ki points, you deafen creatures with 70 hit points or fewer and instantly kill creatures with 40 hit points or fewer.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of Conformity
entries: Oaths of loyalty sworn in the name of divine authority bind the promisor by honor and contract to the whims of another. Through such oaths, these charismatic figures amass followers by the dozens to form sects independent of any authority beyond their own, with followers fanatically devoted to their leader.

Paladins of the Oath of Conformity often rule such cults of personality. Their holy presence, fanatical zeal, or hypnotic charisma can transform even the most ardent skeptics into zealous believers. Worshipped by an entourage of fanatics, these paladins find themselves at the center of cults and revolutions that acknowledge no authority but their leader's.

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of Conformity
entries: The tenets of the Oath of Conformity call a paladin spread their message to the masses, and invite every potential initiate to experience the blessing of their presence.

entries.name: One Body
entries: Individuality creates differences that push members of the Collective apart. To promote unity, you should force others to express themselves as you see fit.

entries.name: One Mind
entries: There can be no doubt in your Collective. Encourage forthrightness and honesty to assuage followers' doubts—or force them into compliance.

entries.name: Together, We Are Whole
entries: Fear and flesh are limitations. Bring others together as one, united and subdued by faith.

entries.name: We are Inevitable
entries: Act decisively. Any who refuse your message should be eliminated. Let the tide of your Collective's combined will wash over any who stand in your path.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed in the Oath of Conformity spells table. See the Sacred Oath class feature for how oath spells work.

subclassFeature.name: The Collective
entries: Many of your oath features require members of your Collective. When a creature swears an oath of loyalty to you, you bring it into your Collective and bind it to your will.

A creature in your collective is not {@condition charmed} and it remains free to act as it sees fit. However, it regards you as a mighty being whose beliefs are of great importance. It also has disadvantage on attack rolls against you, and on Wisdom checks and saving throws made to oppose you. You have advantage on all Charisma checks against it.

It is difficult, but not impossible, to break free of your Collective. When a creature that wishes to leave your Collective finishes a long rest, it can make a Charisma saving throw against your paladin spell save DC. If it succeeds on three consecutive saving throws, it breaks free of your Collective. You do not know if and when a creature makes saving throws or breaks free of your will.
For the purposes of your subclass features, creatures that are friendly to you or {@condition charmed} by you are also considered members of your Collective.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity
entries: When you take this oath at 3rd level, you gain the following two Channel Divinity options.

entries.name: Soul Anchor
entries: As an action, you can use your Channel Divinity to begin a sermon that shares your message and attempts to bring others into the fold. Each creature of your choice within 10 feet of you that can hear you must make a Charisma saving throw against your paladin save DC. On a failure, a target can only move if it ends its movement closer to you than it started. A target repeats the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a target fails its saving throw three times, it becomes a member of your Collective.

entries.name: Join or Die
entries: When a target makes a saving throw against one of your paladin spells, you can expend a use of your Channel Divinity to declare it an enemy of your Collective. Any member of your Collective that can see the target and hear you when you take this has advantage on attack rolls against the target until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Unity
entries: Starting at 7th level, you inspire others to new and greater heights. If you aren't incapacitated, you and other creatures of your choice can add your Charisma modifier to ability checks while within 10 feet of you, and you can all communicate telepathically even if you don't share a language.
At 18th level, the range of this aura increases to 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Watchful Entourage
entries: Beginning at 15th level, so long you have at least two members of your Collective within your Aura of Unity, you gain the following benefits:

items: A +5 bonus to your passive Perception

subclassFeature.name: Hivemind
entries: At 20th level, you gain the ability to become one with your Collective. As an action, you can magically disperse yourself amongst a number of creatures equal to your Charisma modifier that belong to your Collective and are on the same plane of existence as you are. Each creature gains 100 temporary hit points.
For the next minute, until all of the chosen creatures lose temporary hit points, or you choose to end the transformation as an action, your capabilities change:

items: You can't be targeted by any attack, spell, or other effect.
You can't take the Attack, Dash, Dodge, Disengage, Hide, or Use An Item actions.
You can't use the free object interaction you receive as part of your turn.
You can take the Help action as a bonus action, targeting one of the creatures you grant temporary hit points to.
You can take the Search action as a bonus action, using either your own senses or the senses of one of the creatures with temporary hit points.

You can speak and cast spells from each of the creatures with these temporary hit points, using its senses and requiring no somatic components. The creatures are your spellcasting focus for this spell, and you can only cast a spell with a material component with a gold piece cost or that is consumed if one of the creatures is wearing or carrying that component.
You can use your action to direct one of the creatures with temporary hit points to move and take actions as it would on its own turn, granting it a second turn in that round of combat.
When one of the creatures with temporary hit points hits with an attack, you can use your Divine Smite on that attack.

entries: Any creature with these temporary hit points emanates your Auras of Unity, Courage, and Protection, gaining its benefits and granting them to all other members of the Collective within 30 feet of it. You are within all of these auras.
When the transformation ends, you reappear in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of any of the creatures you chose, whether or not it retains any of the temporary hit points you granted it.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of Inquisition
entries: Paladins who swear the Oath of Inquisition pledge themselves to the security and law of their church with undying zeal. Some are masters of debate and education who return heretics to the flock peacefully, but most are summoned when the time for mercy has long since passed and decimation is the only option.

Most Inquisitors root out corruption within the church rather than battle its external foes. Divine law is infallible, but the church can be as corrupt as any mortal organization. These paladins crush clerical hypocrisy and decimate the irredeemable. Their magic forces their targets to submit to their ultimate authority, demanding humiliating disavowal before a bloody execution.

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of Inquisition
entries: The tenets of the Oath of Inquisition are as ironclad and inflexible as its paladins' faith.

entries.name: By Any Means Necessary
entries: There is no village too remote, no furtive devil too clandestine, no misinterpretation too complex. Crush heresy and lies and unveil the bloody truth at any cost.

entries.name: Instrument of Wrath
entries: With every word and deed, motivate followers to do better—fearing you'll come for them next.

entries.name: Obey No Sinner
entries: Canon law is the only truth, and you recognize no other authority. Your faith must not be swayed by the foibles of corrupt clergy, even those who issue your orders. Instead, treat them with the same ruthlessness you would any other unrepentant sinner.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed in the Oath of Inquisition spells table. See the Sacred Oath class feature for how oath spells work.

subclassFeature.name: Competent Zealot
entries: When you swear this oath at 3rd level, you gain proficiency in Religion and your choice of Insight, Intimidation, Investigation, Persuasion, or torturer's implements. If you are already proficient in Religion, choose one other skill and gain proficiency in it.
Regardless of your choice, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any check you make that uses the Religion skill.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity
entries: When you take this oath at 3rd level, you gain the following two Channel Divinity options.

entries.name: Submit to Authority
entries: You can use your action to expend a use of your channel divinity and cast the {@spell command} spell without expending a spell slot. When you cast {@spell command} with this feature, you issue both the Approach and Grovel commands to the target, in that order. These effects take place on your turn, rather than the target's. If it ends its movement within your reach, you can make one melee attack against it as part of this action.

entries.name: Firm Censure
entries: As a bonus action, you can expend a use of your Channel Divinity to gain a +5 bonus to all Charisma (Intimidation) and Charisma (Persuasion) checks, as well as ability checks using {@item torturer's implements|AbiDalzims} for the next 10 minutes. You can also see {@condition invisible} creatures.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of Supremacy
entries: Starting at 7th level, your uncompromising presence intimidates others into submission while you aren't incapacitated. Hostile creatures within 10 feet of you have disadvantage on ability checks and saving throws to avoid being {@condition exhaustion|phb|exhausted}, {@condition grappled}, knocked {@condition prone}, {@condition restrained}, or moved between planes.
At 18th level, the range of this aura increases to 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Unbending Devotion
entries: Starting at 15th level, so long as you are moving straight toward a hostile creature, you ignore movement penalties caused by difficult terrain and areas of effect, and have a climbing and swimming speed equal to your walking speed. You also resist all damage from terrain, hazards, and other areas of effect that you move through.

subclassFeature.name: I am the Church
entries: At 20th level, you become the ultimate authority on your faith. You can use an action to emanate an aura of incomparable divine authority, which grants you the following benefits for 1 minute:

items: You can use a bonus action to command all creatures you choose within 120 feet of you that can hear you to kneel, knocking them {@condition prone}. An unwilling creature must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your paladin spell save DC to avoid being knocked prone.
When you take damage, the target that dared strike you takes radiant damage equal to half the damage you took.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Desecrator
entries: Cold, creeping decay accompanies a Desecrator's presence. These rangers are as patient and inexorable as the unstoppable march of time. They aim to reduce everyone they encounter to the same rancid slurry, for all are equally foul in death.

These rangers often hunt ageless, supernatural beings like dragons and celestials, and are just as happy to destroy the forces of good as they are evil creatures. They wield exotic fungi and horrific bacteria to sicken their living foes and digest dead ones.

subclassFeature.name: State of Decay
entries: Rot takes many forms. You determine the appearance of your magic and how it affects the bodies of other creatures. Decide on an appearance, or choose from or roll on the State of Decay table below.

subclassFeature.name: Unsanitary Conditions
entries: Starting at 3rd level, creatures you conjure spread death wherever you go. Whenever a creature you summoned or otherwise created with a ranger spell dies, it emanates magical sickness in a 5-foot radius around the point it died for 1 minute. Creatures you summon can also be undead, instead of their normal creature type, and undead you animate with your {@spell animate dead} spell or similar magic are considered creatures you summon for the purposes of all your Desecrator features.
The rot inflicts the following effects on a creature that enters the area or starts its turn there, ending at the end of its next turn:

items: The first attack you or a creature you've summoned make against it each round deals an additional 1d8 necrotic damage.
It subtracts a d4 from each attack roll it makes.

entries: This die increases to a d8 when you reach 11th level in this class.

subclassFeature.name: Plague Rat
entries: Also at 3rd level, you learn the {@spell find familiar} spell, which counts as a ranger spell for you but doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know. You can cast the spell as a bonus action, without expending material components, three times, and must complete a long rest before you do so again.
You can kill this familiar at any time, no action required, causing it to spread the radius of magical rot described in your Unsanitary Conditions feature at the point it died.

When a creature of challenge rating 1/2 or higher dies within 30 feet of you, you can use your reaction to either cause the same radius of death to emanate from its corpse, or regain a casting of {@spell find familiar}. The creature can't have been summoned by a spell or other magical effect.

subclassFeature.name: Death Never Dies
entries: At 7th level, you can magically transfer the wounds that would bring you closer to death to things already dead. When you take damage, you can use your reaction to transfer the damage to a creature you have summoned or one or more emanations of rot created by your Unsanitary Conditions feature.

If you target a summoned creature, the summoned creature takes all the damage. If you target an emanation, you reduce the damage you take by 5 for each one affected. This damage reduction increases to 10 per chosen radius at 15th level in this class, and 15 at 20th. No matter how much damage each aura absorbs, each one ends, and any corpse targeted by this feature can't be used to emanate rot again.

subclassFeature.name: Sickening Strength
entries: Starting at 11th level, the presence of death grants you power. When you or a creature you summoned deal damage, you can reroll a number of damage dice equal to the number of radiuses of rot within 120 feet of you, and must use the new roll. The number of dice you reroll cannot exceed half your ranger level.

subclassFeature.name: Extant Form of Life
entries: Starting at 15th level, your magical power over death and undeath lets you breathe new life into your fallen allies. The first time a creature you summon dies, it emanates rot at the point it died as normal, then comes back to life and regains half its hit points. It becomes an undead if it wasn't already and gains immunity to poison damage and the poisoned condition and the Undead Resilience trait. It also emanates a radius of rot which lasts until the spell ends or it otherwise leaves your control.

subclassFeature.name: Poacher
entries: Unlike Hunters, Poachers embody waste and excess. These clandestine hunters stalk their targets far from the judgemental eyes of so-called polite society, often slaughtering protected or endangered creatures for their own gain.

However, the same people who shun them are all too eager to employ their services when it suits them. These sellers of ivory horns and exotic hides find themselves welcomed in the backrooms of the corrupt upper class. There, their black-market goods mingle with stolen gems and plundered relics. Thus, poachers are often determined seekers of wealth who plunder the forest and wilds rather than tomb and temple.

subclassFeature.name: Poacher Magic
entries: You learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Poacher Spells table. The spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Trophy Taker
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you learn to forcibly amputate valuable natural weapons from living targets. You can attempt to {@action disarm|dmg} creatures of a natural weapon. On a success, you destroy or remove the weapon, such as a claw or horn.
The weapon's damage dice change to d4s, and the target can't add its proficiency bonus to attack rolls with it.

Creatures that attack more than once with the same natural weapon suffer this effect on one attack each turn, rather than all of them, until you successfully use this feature a number of times equal to the number of attacks it can make with that weapon. If you use this feature on an attack that deals bonus damage, the bonus damage remains unchanged.

For example, you can remove the claw of an {@creature ancient red dragon|mm} with this feature. After succeeding once, one of its claw attacks deals 2d4 + 10 instead of 2d6 + 10, but its second attack remains unchanged until you successfully use this feature a second time. If you remove its bite, then the 14 (4d6) fire damage the attack deals is unchanged.

Once on your turn when you damage a creature with a weapon attack, you can deal an additional {@dice 1d8} damage to it of the same type as the weapon. To deal this damage, the target must be {@condition grappled} or {@condition restrained}, or had a body part removed from it with this feature within the past minute. This damage increases to {@dice 2d8} at 11th level in this class.

subclassFeature.name: Chaser's Reflexes
entries: Starting at 7th level, your experience with traps and snares allows you to better defend yourself against them. You have advantage on saving throws against traps, and any effect that targets the ground beneath your feet. You can set a hunting trap or similar device as a bonus action, rather than an action, are always under the effects of the {@spell find traps} spell, and resist damage from traps.

subclassFeature.name: Twist the Knife
entries: At 11th level, the weapon attack you make to {@action disarm|dmg} a creature deals its normal damage, and creatures larger than you can't have advantage on checks made to avoid being disarmed by you.

subclassFeature.name: Escape Artist
entries: When cornered in the wild, you can escape from pursuit with criminal ease. Starting at 15th level, choose one of the following spells when you finish a long rest: {@spell tree stride}, {@spell meld into stone}, {@spell feign death}, or {@spell animal shapes}. You can cast the chosen spell once, targeting only yourself, and must complete a long rest before you can do so again.
You can also use a bonus action to move up to your speed in a straight line away from a hostile creature that you can see or hear.

subclassFeature.name: Slaver
entries: Masters of hunting humanoid chattel, these purveyors of their fellow creatures are equally adept in the market and the wild. While nobler rangers hunt wild beasts and terrible monsters, Slavers combine a sharp eye for profit with a keen talent for nonlethal pursuit. After all, a dead slave can't be sold.

subclassFeature.name: Slaver Magic
entries: You learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Slaver Spells table. The spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Trip Up
entries: Starting when you select this archetype at 3rd level, you can make an opportunity attack with a ranged weapon at any target that moves more than 10 feet straight away from you. When you hit with an opportunity attack, you can force the target to make a Constitution saving throw against your ranger spell save DC, falling {@condition prone} on a failure.

You can also attempt to knock a creature out with a ranged weapon attack, and your opportunity attacks and the first attack you make against a {@condition frightened} or {@condition prone} creature on a turn deal an additional {@dice 1d12} damage. This damage increases to {@dice 2d12} at 11th level in this class.
Finally, you can use a bonus action, rather than the Use an Item action, to apply {@item manacle|phb|manacles}, ropes, or other restraints to unconscious creatures.

subclassFeature.name: Evaluate Target
entries: At 7th level, your eye for slaves' market value—and their tracks should they escape—grants you proficiency in your choice of Insight, Medicine, Persuasion, or Perception.

In addition, traveling at a fast pace doesn't impose the normal -5 penalty to your passive Wisdom (Perception) score, and you have advantage on Constitution checks made to avoid exhaustion while chasing another creature.

subclassFeature.name: Contemptuous Combatant
entries: At 7th level, you shrug off the attacks of the lesser beings who fall before you. A creature that was {@condition charmed}, {@condition prone}, or {@condition restrained} at any time since the start of its last turn has disadvantage on attacks against you.

subclassFeature.name: Subdue and Submit
entries: Starting at 11th level, when a creature you can see succeeds on an ability check or saving throw to avoid or end being {@condition grappled} or {@condition restrained}, you can make an opportunity attack against it. On a hit, the target must roll again and take the lowest result. You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of once), and cannot do so again until you complete a long rest.
You can expend a ranger spell slot to regain one expended use of this feature at any time during your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Crush Resistance
entries: At 15th level, you can use your Subdue and Submit feature whenever a creature succeeds on an ability check or saving throw to escape the effects of any of your ranger spells. If multiple creatures succeed, you can only choose one creature to attack.
You can use this ability once on your turn without using your reaction.

subclassFeature.name: Vampire Spawn
entries: New to their powers, these servants of mighty vampire lords seek victims to deliver to their master or stalk neighboring regions to expand their influence. Such endeavors are often colored by their own rebellious purposes.

Though at first limited to sharp bites and a love of the dark, these rogues develop powers equal to their creator's—who they are equally likely to join as a peer as they are to overthrow them in a grisly rebellion.

subclassFeature.name: Enamel Daggers
entries: After choosing this archetype at 3rd level, your fangs grow sharp and hunger for blood gnaws at your belly. You can make a bite attack, which is a natural weapon with the finesse property that you are proficient in and deals {@dice 1d6} piercing damage on a hit.

If you deal your Sneak Attack damage with your bite, you can choose to deal it as necrotic damage instead of piercing damage. If you do, you gain temporary hit points equal to half the necrotic damage dealt.

subclassFeature.name: Helpless Prey
entries: Also at 3rd level, after you grapple a creature, you can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action. You also have advantage on weapon attack rolls against grappled and charmed targets.

subclassFeature.name: Creature of the Night
entries: Starting at 9th level, you gain a climbing speed equal to your walking speed and darkvision in a 120-foot radius. You can climb on difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

subclassFeature.name: Feast of Friends
entries: At 13th level, you can borrow vitality from your allies to heal your wounds. During a short rest, you can bite a willing creature and drink its blood. The target loses a number of hit dice equal to your Constitution modifier (a minimum of 1), and you regain the same number of expended hit dice.
You can immediately use these hit dice to recover hit points even if you have already done so as part of that short rest.

You cannot drink the same creature's blood more than once in the same short rest, but you can drink the blood of as many creatures as you desire. After drinking another creature's blood, you can't drink from that creature again until you finish a long rest, even if you take another short rest.

subclassFeature.name: Messy Eater
entries: At 17th level, the orgiastic joy of a successful meal pushes you toward your next with gluttonous fervor. The first time you inflict necrotic damage on a turn, you deal the maximum amount of necrotic damage.

If you bite a creature on your turn and it dies, you can take the Attack action again on the same turn so long as you use your bite to attack. Each subsequent bite attack you make on your turn can benefit from your Sneak Attack, but you roll half as many dice.

subclassFeature.name: Dhampir Bloodline
entries: Your innate magic comes from a powerful forgotten ancestor—somewhere in your pedigree lies the offspring of a humanoid and a vampire, whose power lay dormant for generations. You could also be the child of a vampire's victim attacked while you were in the womb, or even received a transfusion of blood from a vampiric scion.

Regardless of the source of your power, you are a pallid, uncanny creature with supernatural charisma. Your presence turns heads and your words are compelling beyond reason...so others excuse your strange and morbid quirks.

subclassFeature.name: Vampire Magic
entries: You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Vampire Magic spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Resilient Morbidity
entries: Starting at 1st level, your diluted undead blood awakens. You gain a vampire's lesser powers—and none of the weaknesses of a true master of the night. You can hold your breath indefinitely, you don't require food or water, and you age at one-tenth the normal rate for your race.

If you take a long rest atop or within a container filled with dirt from the grave of one of your direct ancestors, you regain additional expended hit dice equal to your Constitution modifier (a minimum of 1).

In addition, you can use your reaction when you take damage to transform into a cloud of reddish gas. This transformation lasts until the end of your next turn, or until you enter natural sunlight. You cannot use this feature while in natural sunlight.
You cannot make weapon attacks in this form, though you can still cast spells. Attack rolls have disadvantage against you, and you have a flying speed of 30 feet.
Once you become a cloud of vampiric mist, you can't do so again until you complete a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Drain Vitality
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you gain the ability to draw strength from your victims, which grants you the following benefits:

items: When you hit a creature with a bite or {@filter melee spell attack|spells|class=sorcerer|subclass=sorcerer: dhampir (aaa)|spell attack=m}, you can spend any number of sorcery points to expend a number of the target's hit dice equal to the number of points spent, or your own hit dice. You then roll the dice, adding your Constitution modifier to each roll, and gain temporary hit points equal to the result. The target must have at least one hit die remaining.
Creatures that you are grappling or whose hit dice you have expended within the last 24 hours have disadvantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} by you.
You ignore immunity to the {@condition charmed} condition.

subclassFeature.name: Crimson Tide
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can use an action to gather strength from nearby spilled blood and transform it into a torrent that whirls around you.

Choose a number of corpses, creatures {@condition charmed} by you, and creatures you targeted with your Drain Vitality feature in the last hour within 30 feet of you, spending 1 sorcery point for each creature chosen. You gain the following benefits for 1 minute or until you choose to end this state as a bonus action, based on the number of points spent.

items: If you spent at least 1 point, you can use your action to conjure a wave of rancid blood that crashes down on an area up to 30 feet long, 10 feet wide, and 10 feet tall, within 30 feet of you. Each creature in the area must make a Dexterity saving throw against your sorcerer spell save DC. On a failed save, a target takes 4d8 necrotic damage and is knocked prone. On a success, a target takes half as much damage and is not knocked prone.
If you spent at least 5 points, you regain hit points equal to the number of points spent at the start of each of your turns.
If you spent at least 10 points, your sorcerer spells are augmented as if you had cast them using a spell slot 2 levels higher than the slot you used (to a maximum of 9th level).

entries: You can use this feature once per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Brood Lord
entries: At 18th level, power flows freely between you and your victims. When you use your Crimson Tide feature, choose a number of targeted creatures or corpses up to your Charisma modifier (a minimum of 1). You can include yourself in this selection.
Each corpse is animated as a {@creature vampire spawn}. The DM has this creature's statistics.

Each target regains 10 hit points at the start of each of its turns if it has at least 1 hit point and isn't in sunlight or running water, and has not taken radiant damage since the end of its last turn. It can also climb difficult surfaces (including upside down and on ceilings) without needing to make an ability check, and its speed increases by 10 feet.
When your Crimson Tide ends, your targets lose all benefits from this feature, and the corpses collapse into a harmless heap.

subclassFeature.name: Mutating Magic
entries: You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Mutating Magic spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Troll Flesh
entries: Ever-growing viscera fills your body. Tumors of flesh not your own clutch your organs with pulsing tendrils, and viscous fluid swells your veins. Though many of these sources come from the unholy unions of trolls and humanoids, a troll's unique biology means you may have gained your powers long after your birth.

You might channel your magic through a troll's arm grafted to your body, or have accidentally swallowed a troll's regenerating blood in the heat of battle. You could have also used the services a troll-chopper, who harvests unlimited meat from the captured giants and suffered terrible consequences for your cursed meal.

subclassFeature.name: Roiling Flesh
entries: Starting at 1st level, your regenerative abilities suffuse your body with sickening vigor. You regain all your sorcerer hit dice when you finish a long rest, rather than half.

When you roll initiative or target yourself with a {@filter transmutation spell|spells|class=sorcerer|subclass=sorcerer: troll flesh (aaa)|school=t}, you can expend any number of sorcerer hit dice and roll them, gaining temporary hit points equal to the result for 1 hour. While you have these temporary hit points, your size increases by one category and your attacks deal an additional {@dice 1d4} damage.

subclassFeature.name: Cancerous Instinct
entries: Also at 1st level, a troll's aversion to the elements causes your body to lash out against your will. When you finish a long rest, choose two damage types other than bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing. When you take damage of that type, you can use a reaction to cast a sorcerer cantrip, targeting the damage's source.
You can use this reaction once, and regain it after you finish a short or long rest or cast a spell of 1st level or higher.
You also add your proficiency bonus to any ability check you make regarding bridges.

subclassFeature.name: Magical Meat
entries: At 6th level, you can regrow flesh within you during a short rest. When you expend one or more sorcerer hit dice as part of a short rest, you can choose one of the hit dice and regain sorcery points equal to the number on the die. Once you use this feature twice you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

In addition, you gain temporary hit points equal to the number of sorcery points expended when you use one of your Metamagics. If you have temporary hit points from your Roiling Flesh feature, you add these temporary hit points to them.

subclassFeature.name: Stone in Sunlight
entries: At 14th level, you turn trolls' weaknesses into strength. When you cast the {@spell barkskin} or {@spell stoneskin} spells on yourself while in natural sunlight, the spell requires neither concentration nor material components.

subclassFeature.name: Regenerative Rampage
entries: Starting at 18th level, you can infuse your body with magical energy when you use your Roiling Flesh feature. You gain 10 hit points at the start of each of your turns unless you took damage of the type you chose in your Tumorous Instinct feature.

This enhanced transformation, and the other benefits of Roiling Flesh, linger for 1 minute after you lose all the temporary hit points granted by Roiling Flesh. After using this feature, you can't do so again until you complete a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: The Coven
entries: Unlike most warlocks, who make a pact with a single being, your patron is a triad of powerful witches whose combined powers exceed their individual strengths. Hag covens, made from uneasy partnerships between capricious female fey, have a tumultuous relationship with mortals. They are as likely to curse entire bloodlines as they are to offer healing and guidance to nearby communities, and offer prophecies equally likely to guide their subjects to either great power or an ironic death.

The situations that bring these warlocks to covens vary as widely as the covens themselves. Perhaps you were a member of a druidic circle that pays tribute for knowledge and protection, or you were an infant stolen from the cradle and raised as their child and servant. You may be a consort of one of the younger and more lascivious hags, sent to do her bidding with the promise of a sensual reward. You may even be blessed or cursed by the coven with a tremendous destiny and are determined to make their predictions come true—or escape them—no matter the cost.

subclassFeature.name: Coven Expanded Spells
entries: The coven lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock list for you. Instead of a single list of expanded spells, choose one of the covens from the list below and the corresponding spell list to represent the current whims of the coven you follow. When you finish a long rest, you can switch your chosen coven to a different coven list; any spell you learned from the previous list is replaced by a spell of the same level from the new list.

subclassFeature.name: Hag's Eyes
entries: Starting at 1st level, the coven's touch allows you to observe the outside world through their eyes. While you are not {@condition blinded}, you cannot be {@condition surprised} and you have advantage on initiative rolls and on attack rolls you make during your first turn in combat.

subclassFeature.name: Three in One
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you gain the power to share your magical knowledge. When you and two willing creatures of your choice finish a long rest within 30 feet of each other, you each gain the following benefits until you complete a long rest:

entries.name: Shared Tongues
entries: You can each understand (but not speak) any language that one of you knows.

entries.name: Borrowed Skill
entries: When one of you makes an ability check, the roller can choose another creature in the trio that is willing, conscious, and proficient in the check; the roller may use that creature's modifier instead of its own for the check.

entries.name: Shared Fortunes
entries: If one of you fails a saving throw, and another succeeded on the same save, the creature who succeeded can choose to fail and allow the creature that failed to succeed instead. Conversely, a creature that succeeded can allow another to fail.
You can use these features only if all three of you are conscious and within 30 feet of each other.

subclassFeature.name: Witching Hour
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can conduct a 10-minute ritual when you cast a spell that has a duration of 1 minute or longer to extend its duration by 1 hour, expending a spell slot to cast the spell as normal. You can use this feature only at night, or in dim light or darkness, and you can do so once per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Shared Spellcasting
entries: Starting at 14th level, your patrons teach your coven to form its own circle and share magic. Choose two other willing creatures that can cast at least one spell to become members of your coven. So long as each member remains within 30 feet of the others for the next 24 hours, you may conduct a ritual that allows magic to flow between you.

When you form the coven, choose two spells of each of 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th, and 5th level, and one spell of 6th level, each of which at least one member knows or can prepare. The chosen spells become the coven's shared spells. When you form a coven, you can forget or unprepare any of your spells and replace them with coven spells of the same level.
Any member of the coven can use any other member's spell slots of an appropriate level to cast a coven spell, so long as the slot's owner is conscious, willing, and within 30 feet of the caster.

You and another member can excommunicate a third member from the coven. If you excommunicate a member, that member immediately loses all benefits from being in the coven and the remaining members lose access to any spells or benefits that depended on that member until you finish a long rest or form a new coven. An excommunicated member cannot join a new coven with you.

subclassFeature.name: The Mummy
entries: Not all mummies—desiccated, preserved undead who draw their power from ancient gods instead of the secrets of necromancy—grant their followers the powers of the Undead or the Undying. Some prefer a more personal touch, and grant their warlocks powers not unlike their own to safeguard their tombs or venture out to do their bidding.

Whether you were a servant of the priests embalmed to serve a mummy lord, a lesser noble who followed a mighty pharaoh in life, or simply an unfortunate archaeologist, the trappings of mummies and their ilk surround you. You conjure dust, traps, and death to slay your enemies, and trap their souls forever to serve your mummy lord. Often swathed in bandages yourself, you bear the symbols of your patron wherever you go.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Mummy lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock list for you.

entries.caption: Expanded Spell List
rows: {@spell Mordenkainen's faithful hound}, {@spell Mordenkainen's private sanctum}

subclassFeature.name: Deathly Entanglement
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can use a bonus action to summon aid from the depths of spectral tombs to claim new bodies for your patron's service. You can use your action to launch spectral wrappings from your body at a creature you can see within 30 feet of you, attempting to grapple it. When you do so, you can use either your Strength or Charisma modifier when you make the check to initiate the grapple, and on later checks to maintain it. If successful, you can move as normal, but your target cannot.
