You can cast spells with a range of touch on creatures you grapple in this way. If you move more than 30 feet away from the target, you drag it with you using the normal rules for dragging a grappled creature. You can target an additional creature with this action when you reach 5th, 11th, and 17th level in this class, though the number of creatures you grapple at once can't exceed your Charisma modifier (a minimum of 1).
If you use these wrappings to move an object, you can use your Charisma score, rather than your Strength score, to determine the amount that you can push, drag, or lift.

subclassFeature.name: Restless Dead
entries: At 6th level, your patron's power impedes decay, allowing you to embalm creatures the moment they die. When you kill a creature or a creature you are touching dies, you can immediately place its body under the effects of the {@spell gentle repose} spell.
In addition, your maximum hit points cannot be reduced, and after you take necrotic damage, you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to your warlock level.

subclassFeature.name: Cryptkeeper's Instincts
entries: Starting at 10th level, you become an instinctive explorer of the ornate tombs that guard your patron. You are always under the effects of the {@spell find traps} spell, have advantage on ability checks and saving throws against traps, hazards, and creatures' lair actions, and resist damage from falling and traps.

subclassFeature.name: Mummia Infusion
entries: At 14th level, your touch prepares bodies to serve your patron in death—even though those bodies' inhabitants are still alive.

Once per day, you can use an action to cast the {@spell flesh to stone} spell without expending a spell slot. The spell targets every creature you are grappling and requires no concentration. Each target continues making saving throws against this spell even if you stop grappling it.

subclassFeature.name: The Parasite
entries: Your patron is no enigmatic inhabitant of a far-off plane, forever out of reach. Instead, your patron lives inside your body. Few of these patrons, such as embryonic slaads, mind flayer tadpoles, and parasite fungi, consider their host's consent when they choose a victim. These victims—like you—realize too late that their body is no longer entirely their own.

Unlike most, your body resists your parasite's maturation. Instead, you two maintain a delicate symbiosis. Though it preys upon you, your patron has a vested interest in your continued well-being and grants you the necessary powers to defend yourself as it slithers beneath your skin and uses your body to reproduce. Most of its young are short-lived weapons that the two of you inject into the bodies of your mutual foes; these parasites act as a magical conduit that accepts magic on behalf of its unwilling host, allowing you and your patron to violate the sanctity of the spells you cast as it has your own body.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Parasite lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock list for you.

entries.caption: Expanded Spell List
rows: {@spell Evard's black tentacles}, {@spell Otiluke's resilient sphere}

subclassFeature.name: Implant Embryo
entries: At 1st level, your patron uses your body to spread itself to others. When you hit a creature with a spell attack from one of your warlock spells or touch a willing creature, you can choose to implant a lesser parasite inside it. The target makes a Constitution saving throw against your warlock spell save DC. Whether the target succeeds or fails, you can cast warlock spells targeting that creature regardless of the spell's range or your line of sight, as long as the embryo lives inside it and you are within 300 feet of each other.
On a failed save, the target is considered a willing creature for your warlock spells as your patron's spawn channels magic into its body.
After you bypass a spell's range, sight, or willingness requirements with an embryo once, it dies.

The number of embryos that exist at once cannot exceed your Charisma modifier (a minimum of 1), and a creature cannot have more than one embryo inside it. If you create an additional embryo, you choose an existing embryo, which shrivels and dies. The embryo also dies after a number of days pass equal to your warlock level multiplied by 5, if the {@spell lesser restoration} spell is cast upon the target, it regains hit points from a single source of healing at least twice your warlock level, or it is subjected to any effect that ends a disease or magical contagion.
The target is also aware that it has been infected with the parasite, and can use its action to make an Intelligence (Arcana) check against your warlock spell save DC to learn its effects.

subclassFeature.name: Brain Worm
entries: Also at 1st level, you can inject mind-numbing toxins from your patron—or even your patron itself—into other creatures. So long as you are touching a creature, you have advantage on Wisdom (Insight), Wisdom (Medicine), and Charisma (Intimidation) checks targeting it.

subclassFeature.name: Two Minds, One Body
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you cast a warlock spell that requires concentration, your patron can concentrate on the spell instead. Its infant mind can only concentrate for a number of turns equal to one-third of your warlock level, after which the spell ends.

You make saving throws to maintain concentration on the spell your patron concentrates on for you as normal, and roll separately for spells you are concentrating on. If concentration ends for either spell, then both spells end.

subclassFeature.name: Flesh Puppet
entries: At 10th level, your patron takes control of your body when you are {@condition charmed}, {@condition exhaustion|phb|exhausted}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition paralyzed}, {@condition unconscious}, or {@condition stunned}. You can move, speak, and take actions while in this state, but still suffer all other effects of these conditions. You also continue to act according to the condition—for example, you may not be aware of your surroundings while unconscious and speak favorably regarding a creature that charmed you.

If you are reduced to 0 hit points, you can continue to act while your patron takes control, but make death saving throws as normal. Once your patron controls your body for an accumulated 10 minutes, it can't do so again until you finish a long rest.
In addition, you can target embryos with spells so long as you and the target are within 1 mile of each other.

subclassFeature.name: Parasitic Domination
entries: At 14th level, your matured patron uses you as a vector to break into the minds of others. When you damage a creature with a critical hit, you can target it with the {@spell dominate monster} spell, using your warlock spell save DC. The spell requires no action to cast, does not expend a spell slot, does not require concentration, and lasts indefinitely until you choose to end it. If another creature fails its saving throw against {@spell dominate monster} cast using this feature, the spell ends on the first target.

If the target dies while under the effects of {@spell dominate monster}, its corpse can be used in place of your own to restore you and your patron to life. If you are resurrected using one of these corpses, you violently emerge from the body in a shower of gore without any of your equipment.

subclassFeature.name: Flux Mage
entries: With incredible improvisational skill and a sickeningly masochistic approach to magical combat, Flux Mages have an exquisite understanding of the flow of magic—by painfully channeling it through their bodies.

Far from the stereotype of fragile mages who flee at the first sign of a knife, Flux Mages open their minds and bodies to injury. Pain is not a distraction; it grants them moments of cold clarity that they use to master the spells wielded against them.

A Flux Mage shines in combat against other spellcasters and relishes the multifarious agonies magic can inflict upon them. But they are far from helpless when facing mundane foes, as they absorb and supplement the powers of their magical allies. They learn their teammates' specialties—and present one less source of collateral damage. Their skill transforms their pain-addicted insanity that drives them into the thick of combat from a liability to an invaluable asset.

subclassFeature.name: Nerves on Fire
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can learn from the agonizing experience when you are targeted by, damaged by, or otherwise affected by a spell of 1st-level or higher. You can also do so if you are in the spell's area and are unaffected.

If the spell is of a level you can cast, as shown on the wizard table, then the spell appears in your spellbook. It is considered a wizard spell for you (even if it isn't on the wizard spell list). The spell is un-prepared and disappears from your spellbook when you finish a long rest.

The spell doesn't count against the number of wizard spells you have prepared. You can't use the spell for wizard class features such as Spell Mastery or Signature Spell, or copy it to another spellbook or a spell scroll.
In addition, when you take damage, you gain advantage on the next spell attack roll you make before the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Spell-Like Effects
entries: Many campaigns include few spellcasters, which prevents the Flux Mage from using their core abilities. In these cases, consider allowing the Flux Mage to learn spells similar to the effects that strike them. A red dragon's breath could teach {@spell burning hands}, and the lightning strikes conjured by a cloud giant could inspire the Flux Mage to improvise {@spell call lightning}.

The DM is the ultimate arbiter of which effects teach spells. Flux Mages can also study their allies, learning {@spell cure wounds} after a cleric heals them or {@spell hail of thorns} when intentionally caught in a ranger's volley.

subclassFeature.name: Strength Through Pain
entries: At 6th level, injuries make you stronger. When you take damage, you can use your reaction to gain temporary hit points equal to half the damage taken. You can use this feature three times, and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
You can use this reaction on spells and other magical effects, but you don't expend a use of this feature when you do.

subclassFeature.name: Residual Magic
entries: Beginning at 10th level, when you cast a spell of 5th level or lower that was added to your spellbook in the last hour, the spell is cast as if you used a slot one level higher than the slot expended.

subclassFeature.name: Flow of Energy
entries: At 14th level, you can not only absorb the knowledge of spells that affect you, but redirect and multiply their power. When you take damage from a spell or other magical effect, you add the same amount of damage to the next spell damage roll you make before the end of your next turn.
If you take damage from multiple effects, you choose which amount you add to your next roll.

subclassFeature.name: College of Deceit
entries: The self-taught bards of the College of Deceit are sinister and selfish manipulators who use well-crafted half-truths to serve their own ends. At first, they appear charming, charismatic, and even friendly, but they reveal their true nature as they peel away their victims' emotional defenses.

Many of these bards operate in royal courts, where they use words as lethal weapons. They direct sovereigns to disastrous decisions, poison alliances with hearsay and speculation, and manipulate the flow of information between authority and its subjects. Others take a more personal approach and relish the thrill of gaslighting their loved ones into corrupted, imbalanced relationships.

subclassFeature.name: Nothing but the Truth
entries: When you join the College of Deceit at 3rd level, your endorsement of others' lies allows you to cheat even the most insightful victims. When another creature adds your Bardic Inspiration die to a Charisma (Deception) check, it uses the highest possible result on the die instead of rolling. A target can't benefit from this feature more than once per long rest.

Additionally, when you would make a Charisma (Persuasion) check, you can make a Charisma (Deception) check instead, and you gain proficiency in your choice of {@item disguise kit|phb|disguise kits}, {@item forgery kit|phb|forgery kits}, or {@item torturer's implements|AbiDalzims}.

subclassFeature.name: Gaslight
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can expend a use of your Bardic Inspiration when you cast an {@filter enchantment or illusion spell|spells|class=bard|school=e;i}. Roll the die. If the result is equal to or greater than the spell's level, you alter the target's understanding of reality so it remains unaware of being affected by the spell, even if the spell's effects say otherwise. The target also does not realize the spell's components as normal.

You can use this feature whether the target succeeds or fails on its saving throw against the spell (if it has one). Each die expended affects one creature, even if the spell targeted multiple creatures. You can expend any number of additional dice to affect more targets, rolling the die separately for each target, provided you can see each chosen target.

subclassFeature.name: Honeyed Words
entries: Beginning at 6th level, the lingering effects of your influence weigh on the minds of your foes. A creature {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} by you, or a creature against whom you have used Bardic Inspiration, has disadvantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma checks targeting any illusion or enchantment you cast or effects you create until the spell ends.

subclassFeature.name: Corrected Recollection
entries: Starting at 14th level, you lie with such conviction that others doubt their memories. You learn the {@spell modify memory} spell, which doesn't count against the number of bard spells you know, and if you spend an hour in conversation with the target prior to casting it, it requires no components and doesn't expend a spell slot.

subclassFeature.name: Never Punished
entries: Also at 14th level, you can use your reaction when a creature succeeds on a saving throw against one of your spells to become {@condition invisible}. This invisibility lasts until you make an attack, cast a spell that affects a hostile creature, deal damage, or your next turn ends. You can become invisible a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier, and you regain all uses on a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: College of Enticement
entries: The sinister singers of the College of Enticement use their voices to captivate and terrify their spellbound audiences. They learn the haunting fundamentals of their music from carnivorous sirens, watchful banshees, and the frigid yuki-onna, and adopt the same goals as their malicious tutors—to lure victims to their doom.

subclassFeature.name: Alluring Voice
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to charm away wits with a haunting song. You can use an action to expend a use of your bardic inspiration to begin a song audible within a number of feet of you equal to 10 × your bard level, which requires concentration and lasts for 1 minute. Choose up to three creatures that can hear you, which must make Wisdom saves against your bard spell save DC.

On a failed save, a target is charmed by you until the song ends. While charmed, it must move up to its speed straight toward you on each of its turns, taking actions of its choice. It moves around obstacles that prevent it from getting closer to you, such as walls or pits, but moves through fires, shallow pools of acid, and other harmful areas of effect.

If fewer than the maximum number of targets are charmed at the start of your turn, you can attempt to charm additional creatures up to the maximum. For example, if you charmed one target, you can attempt to charm two more. The maximum number of creatures you can charm increases to four at 5th level, five at 10th level, and six at 15th level in this class.
When a target takes damage or ends its turn, it can repeat its saving throw. On a success, it is no longer charmed by you.

subclassFeature.name: Commanding Voice
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can use your voice as a spellcasting focus and learn the {@spell thaumaturgy} cantrip, which counts as a bard cantrip for you but doesn't count against your number of cantrips known.

subclassFeature.name: Sound of Silence
entries: Starting at 6th level, creatures you choose under the effects of your Alluring Voice or a bard spell you are concentrating on are deafened, but can still hear your song and other sounds that you permit. The first attack roll made against a creature deafened in this way is made with advantage.

subclassFeature.name: Perish Song
entries: Starting at 14th level, your voice marks your victims for death. The first time a creature takes damage after you charm it by any means, the damage is doubled. A creature cannot take this doubled damage more than once per day.
Your Alluring Voice also ignores immunity to the {@condition charmed} condition, though creatures immune to being charmed have advantage on the saving throw.

subclassFeature.name: Neuromancer
entries: Determined scholars can replicate anything with magic, including the biological processes of alien creatures. Neuromancers study the powers of mind flayers, aboleths, and other psychic horrors and learn to rip knowledge from the brains of their targets.

Kinder members of this school admire others' proficiency in academic arts and copy their abilities without doing harm, but most treat their foes' minds with the delicacy of a sledgehammer, rather than a scalpel.

subclassFeature.name: Mindbreaker Savant
entries: Beginning when you select this tradition at 2nd level, the gold and time you must spend to copy a spell that deals psychic damage or that inflicts an Intelligence saving throw is halved. You also gain proficiency in Medicine.

subclassFeature.name: Brain Drain
entries: Also at 2nd level, you gain the ability to steal your enemies' knowledge and add it to your own.

When a creature fails a saving throw against one of your wizard spells of 1st-level or higher, you can choose one of the target's proficiencies in a skill, tool, or weapon, or one language it knows. You gain that proficiency or learn that language, and the target loses that proficiency or language.

You can possess three stolen proficiencies or languages (or one of the additional options you gain at later levels in this class). If you steal a fourth, you choose which option you lose, which immediately returns to its original owner. If you die, all stolen proficiencies return to their original owner.

subclassFeature.name: Mental Gymnastics
entries: At 6th level, your mastery of the inner workings of the mind allows you to substitute mental acumen for physical dexterity.
When you make a Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check, you can add your Intelligence modifier to the roll instead of your Strength or Dexterity modifier.
In addition, divination, enchantment, and illusion spells you cast do not require somatic components.

subclassFeature.name: Intellectual Overload
entries: Starting at 10th level, when a target fails an Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw against a spell you cast of 1st-level or higher, you can spend an additional spell slot of any level to stun the target until the start of its next turn. If the spell targets multiple creatures, you stun one.
You can also use your Brain Drain feature to steal spells on the wizard spell list. The spell stolen must be the same level or lower as the spell slot expended to steal the spell.

subclassFeature.name: Mind Eater
entries: Starting at 14th level, the information you suck from the minds of others nourishes and strengthens you. A single use of your Brain Drain feature provides you with enough nourishment and water for one day, and grants you immunity to psychic damage until the end of your next long rest.
Whenever you use your Brain Drain feature to steal a spell, you roll a number of d6s equal to the spell level and gain temporary hit points equal to the result.
Finally, you can use your Brain Drain feature to steal proficiency in saving throws.

data.name: Preface
entries: AAA is a compendium of additional character options and items written by members of the Fungalbrewery Discord server, created to empower players to be the worst they can be.

The contents of this compendium are intended to be balanced for play in a regular Dungeons & Dragons Fifth Edition group. It was written prior to the release of the revised Player's Handbook released in Fall 2024.

entries.name: Other Media
entries: The contents of this book are available on the following services.

entries.name: Avrae Discord Bot—Coming Soon!
entries: Avrae is a Discord bot which facilitates D&D online play, and supports homebrew, items, monsters, and custom commands. You can subscribe to the AAA alias and run !aaa install in a Discord server with Avrae once we complete the pack.

entries.name: CritterDB
entries: This {@link CritterDB|https://critterdb.com:443/#/bestiary/view/64a08b389fba0cc1270f12cc} link contains the creatures found in this book, which can interact with other online tools.

entries.name: Latest Version of the PDF
entries: This {@link Google Drive|https://drive.google.com/file/d/1qcyABNIokvzSM6PEKltiE5wKQlJVVgzc/view?usp=sharing} link contains the most recent version of the PDF and updates automatically.

data.name: Content Warning
entries: This book contains sensitive material that some readers may find disturbing: blood and other bodily fluids, body horror, branding, cannibalism, desecration of corpses, disease, drugs and substance use disorder, human sacrifice, mob violence, mutilation, natural disasters, parasitism, prostitution, psychological abuse, public execution, self-harm, slavery, stalking, suicide, terrorism, torture, and catastrophic loss of life.

All players must participate in a transparent and honest conversation before they implement any of the content in this book. Dungeons & Dragons features noble heroes and provides fantastical escapism. Abi-Dalzim's Abhorrent Adventurers instead gives players the tools to create morally reprehensible characters and empowers them to reach their full narrative potential. Groups that use this book must recognize their characters' villainy and incorporate this acknowledgement into their game.
Depiction is not endorsement. The creators do not condone the real evils discussed herein in any capacity when present in reality.
Reader discretion is advised.

data.name: Races
entries: This chapter presents five new races to supplement those in the player's handbook: elder things, the half-giants, myconids, regarders, and skum. These peoples engender fear and hatred among others, even compared to the hated races in the Player's Handbook. Even their essential biological processes are alien and terrifying.

entries.name: Elder Thing
entries: {@race Elder Thing|AbiDalzims|Elder Things} are an interstellar civilization of radially-symmetric creatures with utterly-alien biology. Their mastery of genetic manipulation guided the evolution of many creatures on the Material Plane.

entries.name: Half-Giant
entries: {@race Half-Giant|AbiDalzims|Half-Giants} are the offspring of humanoids and lesser giants, such as oni, ogres, and torlls that live outside the Ordning. Their lives are often nasty, brutal, and short.

entries.name: Myconid
entries: {@race Myconid|AbiDalzims|Myconids} are converted from the fungus creatures featured in the Monster Manual, and should be treated like the {@filter monstrous races|races|traits=monstrous race;!npc race} from Volo's Guide to Monsters.

entries.name: Regarder
entries: {@race Regarder|AbiDalzims|Regarders} are human-shaped beholder-kin that form when a beholder dreams of itself as a humanoid. They have their parent's cunning and arrogance, but little of their power.

entries.name: Skum
entries: {@race Skum|AbiDalzims} are the slaves of aboleths, twisted into a hideous slime creature with only a vague resemblance to their former selves.

data.name: Subclasses
entries: This chapter presents twenty-eight new subclasses to supplement those in the Player's Handbook. These new options are available when you make a character, provided your DM allows them in your campaign. Many subclasses are inappropriate for some groups. Carefully discuss them before using them.

entries.name: Artificer Specializations
entries: At 3rd level, an artificer gains the Artificer Specialist feature. The following additional options are available to an artificer: the {@class Artificer|TCE|Hellraiser|Hellraiser|AbiDalzims} and the {@class Artificer|TCE|Vector|Vector|AbiDalzims}.

entries.name: Primal Paths
entries: At 3rd level, a barbarian gains the Primal Path feature. The following additional options are available to a barbarian: the {@class Barbarian|PHB|Path of the Addict|Addict|AbiDalzims}, the {@class Barbarian|PHB|Path of the Meltdown|Meltdown|AbiDalzims}, and the {@class Barbarian|PHB|Path of the Zombie|Zombie|AbiDalzims}.

entries.name: Bard Colleges
entries: At 3rd level, a bard gains the Bard College feature. The following additional options are available to a bard: the {@class Bard|PHB|College of Deceit|Deceit|AbiDalzims} and the {@class Bard|PHB|College of Enticement|Enticement|AbiDalzims}.

entries.name: Divine Domains
entries: At 1st level, a cleric gains the Divine Domain feature. The following additional options are available to a cleric: {@class Cleric|PHB|Awe Domain|Awe|AbiDalzims} and {@class Cleric|PHB|Wealth Domain|Wealth|AbiDalzims}.

entries.name: Druid Circles
entries: At 2nd level, a druid gains the Druid Circle feature. The following additional options are available to a druid: the {@class Druid|PHB|Circle of the Gale|Gale|AbiDalzims} and the {@class Druid|PHB|Circle of the New Moon|New Moon|AbiDalzims}.

entries.name: Martial Archetypes
entries: At 3rd level, a fighter gains the Martial Archetype feature. The following additional options are available to a cleric: the {@class Fighter|PHB|Executioner|Mercenary|AbiDalzims} and the {@class Fighter|PHB|Mercenary|Mercenary|AbiDalzims}.

entries.name: Monastic Traditions
entries: At 3rd level, a monk gains the Monastic Tradition feature. The following additional options are available to a monk: the {@class Monk|PHB|Way of Hate|Hate|AbiDalzims} and the {@class Monk|PHB|Way of Transcendence|Transcendence|AbiDalzims}.

entries.name: Sacred Oaths
entries: At 3rd level, a paladin gains the Sacred Oath feature. The following additional options are available to a paladin: the {@class Paladin|PHB|Oath of Conformity|Conformity|AbiDalzims}, and the {@class Paladin|PHB|Oath of Inquisition|Inquisition|AbiDalzims}.

entries.name: Ranger Archetypes
entries: At 3rd level, a ranger gains the Ranger Archetype feature. The following additional options are available to a ranger: the {@class Ranger|PHB|Desecrator|Desecrator|AbiDalzims}, the {@class Ranger|PHB|Poacher|Poacher|AbiDalzims}, and the {@class Ranger|PHB|Slaver|Slaver|AbiDalzims}.

entries.name: Roguish Archetype
entries: At 3rd level, a rogue gains the Roguish Archetype feature. The following option is available to a rogue: the {@class Rogue|PHB|Vampire Spawn|Vampire Spawn|AbiDalzims}.

entries.name: Sorcerous Origins
entries: At 1st level, a sorcerer gains the Sorcerous Origin feature. The following additional options are available to a sorcerer: the {@class Sorcerer|PHB|Dhampir Bloodline|Dhampir|AbiDalzims} and {@class Sorcerer|PHB|Troll Flesh|Troll Flesh|AbiDalzims}.

entries.name: Otherworldly Patrons
entries: At 1st level, a warlock gains the Otherworldly Patron feature. The following additional options are available to a warlock: the {@class Warlock|PHB|Coven|Coven|AbiDalzims}, the {@class Warlock|PHB|Mummy|Mummy|AbiDalzims}, and the {@class Warlock|PHB|Parasite|Parasite|AbiDalzims}.

entries.name: Eldritch Invocations
entries: When you choose eldritch invocations, you have access to these additional options.

entries.caption: Eldritch Invocations
rows: 15th level, {@optfeature Pact of the Brand|AbiDalzims} OR {@optfeature Pact of the Chain|PHB}

entries.name: Arcane Traditions
entries: At 2nd level, a wizard gains the Arcane Tradition feature. The following additional options are available to a wizard: {@class Wizard|PHB|Flux Mage|Flux Mage|AbiDalzims} and the {@class Wizard|PHB|Neuromancer|Neuromancer|AbiDalzims}.

entries.name: Optional Class Features
entries: You gain class features in the Player's Handbook when you reach certain levels in your class. This section offers additional features that you can gain from one (or more) classes. Unlike the features in the Player's Handbook, you don't gain the features here automatically. You and your DM decide whether you gain a feature in this section if you meet the level requirement noted in the feature's description. Campaign tone, the content already featured at the table, and suitability for the character are all important considerations to discuss before selecting one of more of these features. These features can be selected separately from one another; you can use some, all, or none of them.
The features are presented in order of class and level. Features granted at the same level are listed in alphabetical order.

entries.name: Optional Artificer Features
entries: The following additonal options are available to an artificer.
{@optfeature Devilish Dealer|AbiDalzims}
{@optfeature Replicate Magic Item|AbiDalzims}

entries.name: Optional Cleric Features
entries: The following additonal options are available to a fighter cleric.
{@optfeature Entrance Undead|AbiDalzims}
{@optfeature Dominate Undead|AbiDalzims}

entries.name: Optional Fighter Features
entries: The following additonal options are available to a fighter.
{@optfeature Opportunist|AbiDalzims}
{@optfeature Body Block|AbiDalzims}
{@optfeature One-Two|AbiDalzims}

entries.name: Optional Sorcerer Features
entries: The following additonal options are available to a fighter.
{@optfeature Inescapable Spell|AbiDalzims}

data.name: Chapter 3: Backgrounds
entries: The most grandious tyrant and the foulest wretch both have an origin. Your back-ground reveals where you came from, how youbecame a villainous adventurer, and your place in the world. Your warlock might have been astudent of forbidden occult lore or a member of amaniacal and murderous cult. Your fighter could have deserted a mercenary company or been outcast for their actions in a brawl. Your bard might have learned prison songs or entertained clients as a prostitute.

Choosing a background provides you with useful story cues about your character's identity. The most important question to ask about your background is: what changed? Why did you stop doing whatever your background describes, and start adventuring? Where did you get the money to purchase your starting gear, or, if you come from a wealthy background, why don't you have more money? How did you learn the skills of your class? What sets you apart from ordinary and moral people who share your background?

Each of these backgrounds provides an alternative to the sam- ple backgrounds listed in the Player's Handbook. They are designed to help players adopt the mindset of the dregs of society—villains, criminals, cast-offs, and undesirables. Carefully consider whether each background is appropriate for the table; not all groups can stomach certain character archetypes, and should avoid any backgrounds that trouble any players.

data.name: Chapter 4: Feats
entries: This chapter presents new feats to supplement those in the Player's Handbook. Some DMs allow the use of feats to customize a character, under the optional rule in Chapter 6, Customization Options, of the Player's Handbook. These feats are suitable for a campaign that utilizes the Races listed earlier in this book in Chapter 2: Races, as well as some races available in other books. The feats are presented in alphabetical order.

data.name: Chapter 5: Equipment
entries: Tools are not evil. Anyone can use any item for good or ill. The objects in this chapter are no different. However, certain items cross a moral line that few heroes are willing to consider. Such items are often banned, their possession frowned upon, or are only acquired at terrible cost. Villainous characters often create these items themselves; in many cases, their decision to manufacture and distribute such items spurs or accelerates their descent into evil.

entries.name: Adventuring Gear
entries: Each item in this section has additional mechanics. Their prices, weights, and other statistics are listed in the table above.

entries.name: Drugs
entries: Each item in this section has additional mechanics. Their prices, weights, and other statistics are listed in the table above.

items: {@item Gelatinous Cube Extract (1 teaspoon)|AbiDalzims|Gelatinous Cube Extract}

entries.name: Addiction
entries: Abusing drugs, especially powerful drugs, has a debilitating effect on the mind.

entries.name: Becoming Addicted
entries: When you fail a saving throw against a drug to gain its effects, roll a d100 and add your Constitution or Wisdom modifier (whichever is lower) to the roll. Subtract 1 from the result for every dose of the drug you took in the last seven days (whether you gained its effects or not). If the result is lower than the drug's saving throw DC, you are addicted to the drug.

entries.name: Addiction and Withdrawal
entries: While addicted to the drug, you gain a level of exhaustion after you go a number of long rests without failing your saving throw against that drug equal to your Constitution modifier + your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of 2). These levels of exhaustion are removed when you fail your saving throw against the drug, but cannot be removed by any other means short of the greater restoration spell or similar magic. You cannot suffer more than 5 levels of exhaustion from an addiction, even if you have more than one addiction.

entries.name: Tolerance and Rehabilitation
entries: While addicted to a drug, you have advantage on saving throws against its effects.

When you would suffer your 6th level of exhaustion from withdrawal and at the end of each long rest afterward, you instead make a Constitution saving throw against poison with a DC equal to 20 - your Constitution modifier. On a failure, you drop to 0 hit points. On a success, you are cured of your addiction.

entries.name: Addiction Example
entries: Baldwin the rogue pickpockets doses of {@item Dwale (1 bottle)|AbiDalzims|Dwale} (DC 16) to enjoy, and has a +3 Constitution modifier and +1 Wisdom modifier. He uses one dose and fails his saving throw, which allows him to enjoy the high. He also rolls {@dice 1d100 + 3}, and rolls a 33. After the high wears off, he enjoys a second dose and succeeds on his save. With no high, he becomes frustrated, and immediately takes a third. He fails his saving throw, and rolls {@dice 1d100 + 3 - 3}, with a result of 12. Baldwin is now addicted to dwale.

He is unable to locate more dwale for 4 days (3 from his Constitution and 1 from his Wisdom), and so suffers his first level of {@condition exhaustion} after he finishes his next long rest. The disadvantage imposed on ability checks keeps him from stealing more as his condition worsens. He goes another 12 days without a dose, for a total of 16 days. He now suffers 4 levels of exhaustion, and a friend takes pity on him and purchases two doses.

Due to his tolerance, Baldwin has advantage on the saving throws against dwale when he takes it, even though he would ordinarily have disadvantage on saving throws due to exhaustion (so he instead rolls normally). He succeeds against his first dose, which grants him no benefits from the drug. He fails the second, enjoys a high, and his four levels of exhaustion disappear until another 4 days pass, and the first level of exhaustion returns.

Baldwin decides enough is enough, and swears off dwale. After 24 days without a high from dwale (and 5 levels of exhaustion), he makes a DC 17 Constitution saving throw with disadvantage thanks to his levels of exhaustion. He fails, drops to 0 hit points, and is revived by his sympathetic friend.

The next day, Baldwin makes another DC 17 Constitution saving throw with disadvantage, but succeeds. He has now recovered from his addiction, though some psychological scars and powerful cravings may remain.

data.name: Chapter 7: Spells
entries: This chapter presents new spells to supplement those in the Player's Handbook. These new spells allow your character to commit horrific sins against those they face in combat and bring about cataclysms with powerful Reckoning rituals. Your DM might allow access to these when you create your character, or leave them for you to discover in the spellbooks of evil wizards or to invent yourself as you descend into villainy. Your DM might also decide that such spells aren't appropriate for your role as a hero, and reserve them for the most despicable of villains.

entries.name: Reckoning Spells
entries: Certain spells in this chapter have the special tag: reckoning. Each spell with the reckoning tag also notes a number of spell slot levels, which be expended together to cast a spell as a reckoning.

Each spell with the reckoning tag also contains an addendum: As a Reckoning. You can cast a spell with the reckoning tag normally, but each of these spells have a special effect when cast a reckoning. The rules for casting a spell as a reckoning are listed in {@book Chapter 8, Reckoning Spells|AbiDalzims|9|Reckoning Spells}, later in this book.

data.name: Chapter 8: Reckoning Spells
entries: This book has certain spells with a special tag: reckoning. Each spell with the reckoning tag has two effects: the first as listed in the spell's text, and the second when cast as a reckoning. A reckoning is a special ritual by multiple spellcasters to enhance the effects of a spell far beyond its normal levels, with catastrophic and Biblical results. To cast a spell with such power, multiple mages must combine their strength and follow precise instructions utilizing cripplingly expensive material components. These requirements are listed in the spell's description under the As a Reckoning section. Most reckoning spells are not meant to be readily accessible to most adventuring parties; players must leverage every social and financial asset at their disposal to cast even a single reckoning spell. These spells, whether wielded by heroes or villains, have the power to change the world.

entries.name: Casting Reckoning Spells
entries: To cast a spell as a reckoning, the casters choose one creature to act as their leader. The leader must know the spell, have it prepared, or have a scroll or other magic item able to cast it.

To begin the ritual, the leader expends a spell slot of the appropriate level, channeling the magic into a focus within 30 feet of it, such as a cistern, circle of runes, sacrificial altar, or sphere of magic. Such a focus often is or contains the additional material component required when casting a spell as a reckoning.

Another spellcaster within 30 feet of the leader or focus can use an action to contribute to the ritual by expending a spell slot of its own. The spell slot can be of any level, but the spell can only be cast as a reckoning when the sum of the expended spell slots' levels reaches the number listed in the spell's reckoning tag. Each contributing spellcaster, including the leader, can contribute only one slot.

Once the required sum of spell slots is reached, the reckoning ritual begins. It takes 8 hours longer than normal to cast a spell as a reckoning, and each participant must concentrate on it for the full duration, as though concentrating on a spell.

If a spellcaster's concentration ends or it moves more than 30 feet away from the leader or focus, its contribution is removed. It, or another creature that is not currently participating in the ritual can take its place in the ritual instead within 10 minutes.

In either case, the entrant expends a new spell slot of a level necessary to meet the spell's reckoning value or higher. If 10 minutes pass and the total required number of spell slots is not re-attained, the ritual is interrupted and the spell may fail, create a partial effect, or otherwise go awry, at the discretion of the Dungeon Master.
A participating spellcaster, including the leader, can take other actions while concentrating on the ritual, but cannot move more than 30 feet away from the leader or focus.
After the spell is cast, the leader of the ritual determines its effects any time the spell references the caster's decision to choose the spell's target, area, or duration.

Dispelling a reckoning spell with a duration of "until dispelled" is difficult. The caster cannot affect the reckoning with {@spell dispel magic}, {@spell counterspell}, or similar magic unless it targets or affects the space the ritual leader stood in when the spell took effect. An {@spell antimagic field} spell and similar magic has no effect on rituals to cast reckoning spells. The DC of the ability check to stop or end the spell, if required, is 30.

entries.name: Existing Spells as Reckonings
entries: In addition to the spells listed in {@book Chapter 7: Spells|AbiDalzims|8|Spells}, the below spells published in other Dungeons & Dragons books can be cast as reckonings. The spells are listed in alphabetical order.

items: {@spell Bones of the Earth (Reckoning)|AbiDalzims|Bones of the Earth}
{@spell Create Food and Water (Reckoning)|AbiDalzims|Create Food and Water}

entries.name: Homebrew Reckoning Spells
entries: In addition to the spells listed in {@book Chapter 7: Spells|AbiDalzims|8|Spells}, the below spells published in other Dungeons & Dragons books can be cast as reckonings. The spells are listed in alphabetical order.

entries.name: Impact
entries: A reckoning spell should be an historical event discussed for decades. With one spell, the party and their allies forever change the area or nation affected. The right target can consequently change the world.

Unlike most spells, reckonings should last far longer than a single combat. A reckoning should also not affect a single enemy; instead, reckonings should affect targets within a broad area, such as an army camp or city.

Consider how NPCs and monsters might use these reckonings. A dangerous cult might use modify memory to erase any trace of their existence or gate to open a portal to the Far Realm where the subjects of their worship lie. The aberrations pouring through this portal would forever alter the course of the Material Plane's history, changing the petty politics of mortal kingdoms and stalling the battles between good and evil to face this new threat.

{@spell control water (reckoning)|AbiDalzims|Control water} could wipe out a critical trading port, {@spell miasma|AbiDalzims|miasma} would force ancestor worshippers to abandon their beloved crypts, {@spell damnation|AbiDalzims|damnation} can send a mighty {@creature solar} to Hell, {@spell locusts on the wind|AbiDalzims} might consume an entire eleven cultural center or turn a druidic forest and its inhabitants to dust... judicious, intelligent applications of these reckoning spells should change the setting, often for the worst.
Be cautious when giving the party access to these spells, and prepare for players to act contrary to your expectations and plans.

entries.name: Frequency
entries: Few campaigns see more than one or two reckonings, so create new ones sparingly. A reckoning spell represents a climactic moment in a campaign; either the player characters gather many powerful allies and change the world forever, or desperately race to stop a group of evil magicians from ending the world. If overused, they lose their narrative impact and become routine, even boring.

entries.name: Similar Spells
entries: Before creating a new reckoning spell, review the existing reckoning spells. Do any accomplish something similar? If so, use that spell instead. If necessary, change its damage type or tweak its effects.

For example, instead of making an acid rain reckoning, use {@spell storm of vengeance (reckoning)|AbiDalzims|storm of vengeance's} mechanics. Reduce its reckoning value, require an alternate material component such as a living {@creature black dragon wyrmling|MM|black dragon}, and use only the "Round 2" effect each round, in which each creature and object under the cloud takes {@dice 1d6} acid damage.
Similarly, to create a reckoning spell similar to a nuclear bomb, simply change {@spell meteor swarm|PHB|meteor swarm's} fire damage to radiant damage.

entries.name: Difficulty
entries: Reckoning spells require careful, extensive, expensive preparation. The process of gathering allies, materials, and other resources to cast just one can be the focus of an entire campaign. Choose material components that make the custom reckoning impossible to cast on a whim; the party should go on a long, difficult quest to find the necessary monsters or treasures, or hire a world-class artisan at exorbitant cost to create the art object. For especially impactful reckonings, consider a living creature for the component—is the result worth ritual murder?
During this time they must also gather allies. An adventuring party with three or four spellcasters with 9th-level slots should expend all their resources to cast even the weakest reckonings.

Thus, most reckoning spells should have a value of at least 30. This number requires the 9th-level spell slots of three full casters and a 3rd-level slot from a half-caster such as a paladin or artificer; doable for some high-level parties.

Parties with fewer spellcasters, or parties attempting to cast spells with higher reckoning values, must gather like-minded allies able to contribute spell slots. The more weak spellcasters they gather, the more they risk interruption or discovery.

Only the weakest reckoning spells should have a value at or lower than 30. Most should have a reckoning value of 40 or higher. Spells below that range have either a major drawback—for example, {@spell starlight spear (reckoning)|AbiDalzims|starlight spear} arms a group of creatures with a powerful weapon, but a thousand peasants with magic spears will still fall to a dragon's fiery breath. {@spell animate claw (reckoning)|AbiDalzims|Animate claw} is easy to cast, but has obvious consequences.

Alternatively, weaker spells can affect a smaller area ({@spell rust metal (reckoning)|AbiDalzims|rust metal}) than other reckonings, or become more powerful when spending additional slots ({@spell weight of years (reckoning)|AbiDalzims|weight of years}, {@spell meteor swarm (reckoning)|AbiDalzims|meteor swarm}).

data.name: Chapter 9: Bestiary
entries: This chapter presents new monsters to supplement those listed in the Monster Manual and other books. Most of these monsters suit any campaign, and include a variety of oozes, aberrations and mischievous irritations.

While Abi-Dalzim's Abhorrent Adventurers is a book of villains, feel free to adjust the lore for thesem onsters in any way you see fit. For example, a {@creature dunwich horror|AbiDalzims|Dunwich horror} could be a pitiable mutant, a {@creature swarm of rust monsters|AbiDalzims} could a malevolent, existential threat to the plane of Mechanus, or a {@creature Hemwick Hag|AbiDalzims|Hemwick hag} could be a helpful fey patron. Adjust the stories and dispositions of creatures in this chapter however you see fit.
